This is genuinely one of the most fascinating things I‚Äôve ever watched on YouTube.
I notice that diagnosed sociopaths and psychopaths consistently talk about compassion and empathy as something learned or false. They don't have an internal sense of the genuine pleasure that comes with kindness, so they only connect it with the external pretty that also comes with it. It's like watching a blind person describe the color red. It's good to hear from someone on the mild to moderate spectrum to disown the myth of inherent criminality.
As an autistic person with ADHD, I was shocked how many of her experiences I can relate to. Not 1:1 but masking, understanding something intelectually but not REALLY feeling it, acting out to release an undescribable pressure inside... Sociopathy is mythologised as something non-sociopaths can NEVER understand but it turns out that other neurodivergent people deal with very similar issues. I'm so glad I watched this!  EDIT: The amount of people in the replies trying to tell me she is in fact evil and dangerous and I shouldn't sympathise with her or compare my conditions to hers is bonkers. You have watched an interview with a person trying to explain how challenging living with sociopathy is and then rushed to the comments to warn people who sympathised with this to stay away from those dangerous 'freaks'. You should be ashamed.
Due to my place on the spectrum, I have always been the family member to call on for funeral arrangements. My 'secret joy' was meeting with a funeral director with a family member who was distraught from the death; it was just like in the movies; he tried pushing my relative to paying for a $15,000 or $20,000 casket. My relative turned to me, 'What do you think?' Now, this relative knows I don't feel things like other people, but I am considerate of others; I pointed out the cheapest casket, around $4,000; the simplicity would 'feel' more appropriate to our deceased and their surviving significant other, as well as pointing out the religious symbolism in the corners matched the deceased and surviving significant other's religious beliefs. 'Oh, yes, that would be better,' my relative said. I looked at the funeral director, and he had the most pissed off look on his face that I ruined his big pay day. I stared at him blankly, but inside, I felt good that I got to stick it to this vulture preying on the vulnerable. I've always wondered how many people overpaid due to an emotional vulnerability.  I'm not going to lie; I would have preferred a more destructive or violent reaction to this disgusting person.. But I understand it was just one moment, it would've only made things worse; I can't look out for everyone all the time, but I got to look out for my own relatives.

Exactly. She says she doesn‚Äôt know the cause of her sociopathy, but it sounds to me like her parents made her feel like she couldn‚Äôt express any negative emotions. She said she felt emotionally suffocated as a child, probably from having to stuff down her feelings. The problem is, that when she push down one, you also repress all the others, until you become disconnected from all your emotions.
üéØ There‚Äôs a whole subset of abused kids won‚Äôt disclose their abuse because a parent‚Äôs emotional reaction would be too painful or too heavy to navigate alongside the original wounding. When a parent can‚Äôt/don‚Äôt/won‚Äôt emotionally self-regulate, they recruit all the energy in the room for their own emotional chaos, abandoning their child in the process. I was one of those abused kids, with an unhealed parent who could not suspend their own process to create room for mine.  It intensified my suffering by orders of magnitude, and isolated me in shame and secrecy. Folk like me will delay healing by decades just to protect the healing process from being consumed by a parent lacking in self-awareness or boundaries.   Moral of the story: Half of parenting is emotional self-regulation. Let your children have their own experiences and processes. As the adult in the room, you‚Äôre there to hold space and provide maturity and safety, not to consume the space by reacting to your own triggers. Do adult reacting and adult unpacking later, among other adults.   Loved this part of the interview

¬†@jbjacobs9514¬† I understand where you're coming from, however, the last part of what you said isn't a good perspective IMO. ‚Äã¬†@sjennica¬†Oh!! This is interesting! I have this when I hug people to help them feel better about my situation.. the hug doesn't help me.  I learnt about this as an adult because my husband would want to hug me when we were arguing and I got to a pint where I flat out refused.  It came down to me saying, I understand you want to hug me, but hugging me doesn't make me feel better, it makes you feel better, and at this time I resent having to be responsible for and override my own feelings. But here's a small example. Around 7:00 into the video she compared her relief of pressure when doing something destructive to OCD, and she says:   "They don't know why they do it but it relieves the pressure."  That is completely false and anyone with a rudimentary understanding of psychology knows that, and someone with a doctorate definitely knows that people with OCD very much know why they do what they do, because in their mind, if they don't do it terrible things will happen, and regardless of whether or not bad things happen your brain fears it. It's a  bit like how availability heuristics works, where it wouldn't even matter if you knew with certainty that your feelings have no basis in reality your brain still feels it as if it is real because it responds to thoughts and not to external reality.  It's also excusing her destructive behaviour as something taht is outside of her control, which she explained it is not. She knows it is more practical for her to play nice, but none of you noticed that she constantly avoided acknowledging that there are still real world consequences that are to her own disadvantage. That is one of her pathologies and it makes her a very lousy psychologist.  It's also comparing being destructive toward other people, potentially putting them in the hospital, deliberately to feel relieved when she destroys something meaningful like someone's life, with washing hands compulsively, which is harmless to other people and mostly harmless to the person who washes their hands. OCD can be very disruptive and even painful for a person suffering from it, but it doesn't deliberately put other people in danger or in a hospital. ¬†@DerGrueneBaron¬† The idea that emotions alone separate humans from AI is an oversimplification, as human cognition and decision-making go beyond just feelings. Consciousness, free will, creativity, moral reasoning, and deep interpersonal connections, also play a role.  While sociopathy (or antisocial personality disorder) is characterized by a lack of typical emotional responses like empathy or guilt, it doesn't necessarily make someone "less human." Their humanity isn't defined by what they lack but by their ability to think, act, and make choices like any other person. The distinction between sociopaths and "normal" people is more about emotional processing and moral reasoning rather than humanity itself.

OCD is an anxiety disorder. it‚Äôs a neurodivergence of the brain and so is sociopathy/anti-social personality disorder. They are bound to have similarities.
‚Äã¬†@brianna094¬† No, that's simply untrue. OCD patients suffer from sudden intrusive thoughts (mostly "what if" - imposing an irrational fear) that cause sudden anxiety and need action to be neutralised. First the brain malfunctions in misdiagnosing danger where there is none, and then not giving relief when doing the action. This results in convulsive actions that take a lot to "break out of". Sociopathy thoughts rather suggest how to get relief (mostly "I should" - imposing action). Someone with very bad OCD might be stuck in loop actions all day and have no "self restraint" whatsoever, yet they are not on the brink of "sliding" into sociopathy as you suggest. Sociopaths don't have loops to break out of. The sole fact that they are very DIFFERENT illnesses yet have similar coping strategies is what is so fascinating. Don't spread misinformation.
¬†@Parvahti¬† "Only that the acting out with ocd is to NOT harm others,"‚ÜêHuh? Pretty sure there is OCDs that involves harming others. Or harming themselves.
It‚Äôs cognitive behavioural therapy. CBT is used for many different mental illnesses. The structure of the therapy is the same, (your thoughts, feelings and actions all affect each other), but the verbiage will be slightly different depending on the disorder that‚Äôs being treated. So, yes, it‚Äôs basically the same coping strategy for OCD. It‚Äôs good that you can recognize that. It means you‚Äôve been receptive to the therapy and it‚Äôs working for you:)
¬†@Parvahti¬† OCD absolutely can involve intrusive thoughts to harm others. So can most psychiatric disorders, it doesn't mean you are inherently bad for having bad impulses, it's how you handle them, and a lot of how you handle them is through learning better coping mechanisms. But to do that, we need to allow people the space to talk about what and how they are thinking and feeling without this immediate judgement of "evil, bad."

¬†@mpGreen03¬† I can just tell you, how it worked for me. I am no professional and no native speaker. Sorry. I tried to keep my journaling simple by focusing on things that gave me trouble. And that was negative thoughts and anxiety builtup. So I started journaling with two main topics: 1.) at least write down one positive thought/event/whatever no matter hiw shitty the day seemed and 2.) writing down what stressed me that day and kept spinning in my thoughts. Identifieing the stressors and writing down what feelings they evoke. and then trying to find solutions how tto avoid the stressors or how to cope with them in another way (for example giving some tasks away to other people, canceling dates/events if it puts too much pressure/ etc.) . that was basically it in my case. the mere fact that I wrote things down and found a bit of a distance to my thoughts and emotions made me handle them better and gave me more of a "friend" perspective on myself. I used to beat myself up for small things so reading my problems on a neutral medium (paper) gave me a more loving and constructive approach to solving problems. I hope this made a bit sense.

‚Äã@Tespri  not true. Bullying can be  quite a complex behavior pattern. This is fascinating because sometimes I am kind exactly because it makes me feel like a good person. Yesterday, after getting groceries, I returned two shopping carts to the designated spot in the parking lot. One cart was mine, the other a cart abandoned in the middle of a parking spot. After doing that, I had a moment of saying, "yay, you did a good deed. You're being a good person" and I felt really good about myself for the rest of the day.
‚Äã¬†@vinsura8211¬†I'm not sure if this is what OP had in mind, but this is how I think of human connection. It is when you do something nice for someone you care about, and get a warm feeling. For example you notice a friend's phone is on low battery so you let them use your charger. It is a manifestation of your care for them and feels good to be able to express. Emotionally it feels kinda like a hug.  I have a harder time forming this connection with strangers. In your example (helping a stranger reach an item). I would feel panic and go into autopilot mode (people talking to me when I don‚Äôt expect it is jarring). From the outside, I would be personable, smile, and ask if they needed any other help (this is me on autopilot while internally I'm questioning if I'm being socially awkward and am panicking). Afterwards, I will do everything possible to avoid them (I dont want to have to talk again üòÖ) but emotionally I'll feel proud of myself. Proud I helped someone and proud I did not make a social blunder.   On the rare occasions I feel confident and am not internally panicking, there is a bit of human connection. It feels like I'm a real member of society. I feel a sense of belonging and satisfaction that I could show my care for humankind (cuz I really do think humans are pretty great on the whole). Though I also get satisfaction with the thought that I am being a good person lol
And seeing someone else being blessed. That brings a dopamine hit not because you necessarily caused it, but responding to someone else's joy. Laughter is contagious.
Personally I don't get my feel good 'boost' from a personal connection, or their reaction. First, I get my boost from knowing someone are relieved from a burden, want, ailment, or suffering, etc.  Second, I just  feel so thankful that I  (worked, studied, exercised, equippedvmyself such  that I) could "provide" some cheer or help when it was needed (even if its only a smile, or holding the door for a rando). Autistic, possibly low affective here and depressed. Gonna focus on that last bit, as a lot of advice about how to deal with depression includes going out and doing some charity work or things like that. I have tried this quite a bit, and I can say that I definitely know what the emotion of guilt feels like; I feel horrible when the event ends, and I realize that I have felt none of the positive social emotions that I have been told time and again that I should feel from doing this kind of activity. Putting a smile on some stranger's face doesn't seem to do anything for me.   I still engage in various charity activities, but I look for ones that aren't as forward facing, like helping a food shelter sort their donations or getting a community garden in shape for the people who will actually use it.   I didn't develop subversive behavior coping mechanisms the way that Patric did, but I can easily see how I could have if I had a slightly lower desire to not be seen and maybe just a few more chance events had pushed me towards that kind of thing. As a child I did delight in some mischief, but mostly it was in creating a mess or simply moving objects around in ways that would confuse someone else later.  The flat speaking tone came naturally to me, but at this point I have masked it to the point that I don't think I would feel any more comfortable by dropping the mask. Figuring out things that I can do with my voice has been a long standing special interest, so I look more for people who will accept and/or enjoy sudden changes in the voice I am using, to help convey what I am expressing (anything from one sided caricatures of people that we have a mutual distaste for, to multifaceted roles that have a very different perspective on some matter.)

¬†@milkyway_939¬† with autism, there have been some studies about the double empathy problem. Neurotypicals in a room full of autistic adults are generally just as blind and unempathetic as we tend to think autistic people are, except maybe a little bit worse, because they have never had to navigate that environment. There may well be circumstances where other neurodivergence work together better with each other as well.

¬†@apex_prey¬† Wow that is quite the statement. Altruism can exist even if it is not part of every good deed.
@user-uy8xf9tm5h¬† That‚Äôs an interesting assertion, but it crumbles under scrutiny. Altruism, as it's typically defined, is selflessness‚Äîdoing good with no personal benefit. But that‚Äôs a fantasy. Every action, even the most seemingly "selfless" one, has a personal motive, whether it‚Äôs alleviating guilt, feeling good about oneself, gaining social approval, or reinforcing a personal moral code. Even if someone gives money to a homeless person expecting nothing in return, they still gain something‚Äîrelief from guilt, a sense of righteousness, or just the satisfaction of helping. If a person donates anonymously, it still aligns with their internal desires or values, meaning it wasn't done for nothing. If true altruism existed, it would require a person to act against their own interests in a way that brings zero personal satisfaction. But humans don't function like that. Every decision is rooted in motivation, and motivation inherently serves the self. The moment a deed benefits the doer in any way‚Äîwhether emotionally, socially, or psychologically‚Äîit ceases to be truly "altruistic." So no, altruism doesn‚Äôt exist. The best we can do is acknowledge that our good deeds, however beneficial to others, are ultimately driven by self-interest in one form or another.
@  People do things for others all the time that are not in their own self-interest. Motivation and intention do not need to be self-focused.
¬†@user-uy8xf9tm5h¬† That‚Äôs just naive. Even when people do things for others, there‚Äôs almost always some underlying self-interest, whether it‚Äôs feeling good about themselves, reinforcing their beliefs, or gaining social approval. True selflessness doesn‚Äôt exist in any meaningful way‚Äîmotivation always comes from something internal. Even martyrs don‚Äôt die for nothing; they die for a cause they believe in, which aligns with their values. If you think people act with zero self-interest, you‚Äôre just ignoring human nature.

but that's why people do it really*, that's the point, she's describing the unconscious thought process. of course if someone is *consciously thinking of doing good things only to get the rush of feeling like a good person, there's probably a diagnosis to that in itself, because that's an unhealthy thought process. but most people do good deeds because of the mental reward for doing so, the unconscious dopamine hit of being a good person, that the average person does not even recognise for what it is. when you boil down human behaviour, we are often just very complicated pavlov's dogs, and the brain's dopamine reward system is extremely effective when it works correctly. it trains us from the time we are young that doing certain things gets us a dopamine hit the way we train a dog to behave using treats. our higher mind may rationalise it however it likes, empathy, connection etc, but at the heart of it we do good things because they make our brain feel good. a sociopath's brain doesn't do that for the things it should do. it doesn't reward her for doing the things she's "supposed" to feel good for doing, and so she doesn't get that unconscious "I'm a good person" hit.

Right?  As intelligent and insightful as she is, she doesn't "get" that that's not what's going on, most of the time.  Like when I play with my cat and she is enjoying herself, I'm not getting dopamine from thinking that I'm a good person to play with my cat.  I feel joy watching her feel joy, and it's magnified because I was able to give her that happy feeling.  It's so satisfying to bring joy to another being, or help them to find peace, or relief from pain, sadness, anxiety, etc.  It's really not about me. It feels good to be able to help another to feel good.  It also feels good to see another person or being enjoying themselves or finding relief from negative feelings if I had nothing to do with it.  It simply feels good to witness others feeling good.  For someone like this woman, this is inexplicable.  It's like trying to explain what colors look like to someone who is entirely colorblind.  A sociopath or psychopath, through no fault of their own, is incapable of understanding this.  For them, prosocial actions are essentially transactional; if I do this, it gets me that.  While I do get to enjoy positive emotions from helping someone else, that's really not the motivation behind it. When I anonymously drop off food in the donation box at my local food bank, nobody knows but me.  I never see or know who was helped by those donations.  But I've used food banks before, and I've gone hungry before, too.  So, it feels good knowing that some other person will (hopefully) have enough to eat, even if only for a few days. When it's bitterly cold out, I feel a lot of anxiety because there are so many homeless around me, living in tents all over the city.  I don't know these people, yet I care.  I want them to be okay.  I want them to be safe and warm.  These are feelings that just don't math for a sociopath!

First off, very interesting interview. I like to challenge myself to see multiple perspectives on things. What i take out of this is that i see a person who must be having a very lonely, puzzling life...having to mask to fit in and later mask to "not be seen", uncomfortable with name and/or the image of the diagnosis/disorder and that the general publics reaction towards it could be unbeneficial for her to drop the mask (like; Why would the wolf reveal his true self to the flock of sheep while he's trying to make a snack out of them?).   Keeps me honestly thinking: What is the real reason/motive of the fact that this person is doing this interview?  - Revealing themselves to the sheep to raise awareness so the sheep can sympathise and the Wolf can pray on them more easily while their guard is down?  - Revealing themselves to finally show themselves because of tiredness of masking (and maybe also make it into a powerplay or to get little joy of the sheeps reaction or insecurities when they tell them that they are a wolf)?  - Revealing themselves so they can easily spot other wolves they can connect with (is it pain of loneliness?) and/or forming an entire wolf-pack with (to increase the chances of having a succeeding 'hunt/gain'? instead of being a lonely wolf? - ....? ....so many questions...  Unmasking to  At the last part she talks about (maybe) helping others like her ... sounded almost like that little girl inside her: "See me for me", "I want to be seen" vs. possible other intentions like "I chose to let myself be seen...I demand it, celebrate it or despair it but I'm superior to you (and get a kick out of it when you react)?"     Brainfart of an Ethical (whimsical/silly) question: Would this woman with her diagnosis/disorder and working as a psychiatric physician (treating, teaching about emotions/feeling/coping and way of thought etc.)...., be the equivalent of 'a blind person actively working as a driving instructor'?  - Are they not 'blind' in a similar way? Would it be Ethical/ responsible/how much risk or accidents could there be involved?   Questions...questions...questions....any thoughts? ¬†@klownofkether6996¬† Hard agree.  I'm a mom of two.  My eldest, now 4, has shown signs of being deeply empathetic since he was less than a year old.  He's highly sensitive to other people's emotional states, especially mine.  He can read me like a book and tell me how I'm feeling--if I'm tired or sick or frustrated or happy.  He's incredibly gentle with animals and younger kids and, again, has been since he was less than a year old.  It's not that he's never mean--like any little kid, he gets a power kick out of taking toys away from his little brother, for example.  But he still innately feels what other people are feeling, and he has a deep drive to respond to that.  In this regard, I see a lot of myself in him.  I always cared how people around me felt.  I didn't always instinctively, maturely grasp how my actions affected others, but whenever I realized a behavior was actually hurtful, that was an immediate reason to abandon it.  I grew up in a family that did not nurture the value of kindness.  They didn't have time for kindness.  It's weak and mushy and impractical.  I turned out this way anyway.  To me, that says these emotions can be matured, but they are innate rather than learned. (My youngest, on the other hand (age 2), is similar to my husband in that he'll notice big emotions and be kind of react to them, but mostly he's just kind of benevolently living his life without spending tons of energy on being attuned to the emotions of others.)

¬†@camilledabert¬† The notion that empathy, compassion and selflnesness are purely learned just is not true. For neurotypical people those are innate tendencies that develop alongside brain. HOW (how much, to whom, and in what situations) you use these tendencies is the learned part. In other words, usually small child feels empathy simply because it's part of their brain function BUT might not feel for example shame in certain situations that we have socialised as shameful just because the toddler has no yet learned that it's a thing to be shameful about. Or hasn't yet learned that certain action causes other people to feel bad etc. Also, being rude doesn't equal no empathy. ¬†@camilledabert¬† Now, I'm a beavioural biologist and I can say, human children are highly empathetic and helpful out of their own accord. Of course they can be 'mean' and self centered too - but mistaking that for a lack of empathy and kindness is just outright wrong. Human children cooperate naturally, they share the spoils of that cooperation willingly, if some of them don't do it they call each other out over it and correct themselves over those verbal cues. Empathy and kindness are actually key to humans being successful in their ecological niche. Of course there is always a nurture component to those capacities: They need to be formed and shaped according to the specific environment they live in, which is totally crucial as humans live in vastly different environments that are also quite severly subject to human niche construction. But that they can even learn depends on that very inborn capacity.  People who have ASPD are generally have not fully developed those capacities and the abilities to use them, because they lack in that inborn fundament. In itself their behaviours are what one would call an evolutionary instable strategy. That is, if everyone would feel and act like them, human populations would be extinguished. Their existence is only possible in a population that is mixed and in which the normal human behaviour and feeling is dominating. Because as soon as too many sociopaths (or psychopaths) are around, you got a collapse of higher level cooperation. Sociopaths are basically more on the level of chimpanzees in regard to their ability to cooperate, because they lack the preconditions that are basically inborn empathy and tendency to being kind and helpful - which is key to keep on cooperating when there is a personal cost to doing so or when it is temporarily leading to a detriment.  Humans are the most empathetic, most kind, most helpful, least mean, least selfish, most cooperative mammal species - and arguably overall animal. And that is ingrained in our very nature from birth.

¬†@camilledabert¬† I think your way of viewing empathy is quite similar to Patric and sociopaths in general. A very rationalized way of viewing actions and repercussions and ethics. Empathy is an emotion. You actually feel close to similar emotions that the other person is feeling. It is not transactional meaning that in a very logical way you do something and you get something in return, nor is it limited to this aspect which you perceive as transactional. Empathy is in a way mirroring other people's feelings, which means that many times a person gets distressed by seeing someone else's distress. That's not something learned. Even if there were learned ways to activate this emotion, this reaction itself obviously exists, which means that it's part of our biology. And there are indeed studies and they show that the same areas of the brain are activated when people experience their own emotions and when they observe such emotions in others.

¬†@camilledabert¬† that is...wrong and a generalization. Empathy is an intuitive emotion and it serves us as a tool to navigate the world from the moment we have agency. Empathy is part of our evolutionary traits, so it comes natural to us. Social environments value and enhance empathy (this enhanced version is what most people understand as "kindness") because it is useful for us in order to coexist together in a collaborative environment.  You can argue that some children show cruelty, jealousy and selfish behaviour, but that is because children are still learning to manage their emotions, so often those negative emotions are experienced and manifested in an uncontrolled way. Also, their minds are not focused on being attuned to their surroundings, but on ensuring their needs are met by their caregivers, cause they are inexperienced, smaller, and weaker, therefore, they are at a disadvantage.  People will reach the ability to feel empathy throughout their natural development, while also learning it from their social surroundings. Some people are able to feel empathy sooner, others later, but its is part of our genetic code, evolved to be a tool to ensure our surviving, as it is being able to feel fear, affection or curiosity.

Ok but empathy and compassion are learned, I experience both easily, but we're pretty confident that infants, particularly newborns, don't experience these feelings. They learn them by being shown them by their caregivers and later by their peers. The main difference between neuro-normative people and "sociopaths" is that neuro-normative people easily and naturally pick up these social emotions, and sociopaths don't. It's the same way people with autism don't automatically come to understand things like context appropriate behaviour or implied meaning when most other people do. It doesn't mean that it can't be learned or understood by sociopaths, it just means that it takes longer, is harder to pick up, and often requires conscious thought and effort (aka masking) to accomplish.
‚Äã¬†@RioRav¬† and how do you know that "sociopathy" is not a neurodevelopmental disorder? ASPD (the diagnosis that replaced "sociopathy") has impulsiveness as one of its diagnostic criteria, "sociopaths" do show noticeable difficulty in controlling their impulses. But its also even younger than that, babies who cry their parents into sleep deprivation to the point of hallucinations aren't particularly concerned by the wellbeing of their parents. If their mother cries because they won't stop crying, they don't care, they will only stop crying when they feel their needs have been met. They won't do it out of any sense of empathy or compassion. It takes time for them to learn those things, if whatever mechanism that allows that learning to occur is not functioning properly in the mind of someone with ASPD, that would prevent them from being able to learn those social emotions. They would remain with the same emotional capacity they had as a newborn infant.

Empathy is learned. Even the feeling she is describing is a learned behavior. Remember Pavlov's Dog? That is where that emotion comes from. We are taught that kindness elicits good rewards, that it boosts our character and is simply the right way of things, hence why when we do a "good" act, we feel "good." Its the dog salivating at dinner time. A lot of the things she's talking about when learning how to mask is how we learn to internalize ideals of morality, ethics and empathy. Yes, even your 1 year old toddler can exhibit learned behavior, even babies can monitor their parents reactions and emotions and learn the "correct" way to act to get what they need (famous example, a baby can learn to be silent if it knows no one will listen.) Here's a thought, if empathy and compassion are just innate things that all neruotypical people have, that never needs to be learned or practiced, why is there always such a stress on children's media to instill moral and ethical lessons into their audience?
That's exactly what it's like. I don't call people on their birthdays because I want to wish them a happy birthday or because I want them to have a good day. I'd rather just go about my business. But I've learned that if I don't perform that kind of social ritual convincingly, my relationships with people become strained and awkward and that ends up being more of a hassle for me than just wishing them a happy birthday. Now apply that to people getting engaged, having children, losing parents, getting fired. Faking empathy takes way more energy than just having it. That's why we withdraw from people.

‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†¬†@MK-mt4kn¬†she‚Äôs speaking to the reality she wants to be in control. As you point out her feelings on not wanting to get caught, go to prison, be without relationships, etc. To be sure, no it‚Äôs not a morality in the way you mean it here, but she‚Äôs self-aware enough to understand that she can mutually benefit with society by not being destructive to it.
I'm autistic and I think a lot of other people's empathy is fake. People seem to think "I can imagine what you might be thinking" is empathy. As someone autistic, I'm all too aware that people are not mind-readers but a lot of NT folks seem to think they are.
¬†@dixiemixie5386¬† Because empathy is an instinct, but children need to be taught how to measure their strength, for example, so they do not hurt others. The word empathy is being used with different meanings in this discussion. Empathy is just a natural instinct towards caring about others‚Äô feelings and being affected by their emotions. It is the ability to imagine how you would feel in another‚Äôs place. Children do have empathy, however they do not have a good sense of cause and effect or the ability to understand how their actions impact others, either in a positive or negative way. For example, children need to be taught to touch animals softly, because they are not aware of their own strength and the animal cannot say if something feels uncomfortable. Children who are not sociopaths and are emotionally well regulated will be distressed at the idea of truly harming another person or animal. A sociopath is unable to care for another person or animal in that way.
That‚Äôs because that‚Äôs how we really experience it. I genuinely wish i could feel empathetic like how i see others experience it. It looks fulfilling and for the most part enjoyable. I only get to fake it and that makes it very tiresome. I have to remember that ‚Äúoh i should act happy because what they just said is something good that happened to them‚Äù. I just can‚Äôt connect my emotions like that.

¬†@gauner1312¬† Hm, not sure I understand what you mean, also ASPD is not a mental illness, it's a personality type/trait, you can't take some pill to stop being ASPD except maybe some psychoactives that are banned - if even they work that is. ¬†@Roneish1996¬† Yep, I think it is dangerous to try to lump together ADHD and/or autism spectrum disorder or however they call it right now with the more explicitly popularly "bad" things. I respectfully disagree that non-sociopaths can never understand...  Rather, those with extremely high EQ - emotional intelligence...(which might take years to develop...) have progressed through sociopathic stages.  At some early point all children are emotionally undeveloped and behave sociopathically.  Thus, as well developed true Super Empaths later in adulthood, high EQ people have the emotional memories and ability to re-live or re-feel those emotions and assess them objectively in context , after we are no longer that person.  This means the very few of us who are "super empathic" actually contain you.  Just as a person with 150 IQ "contains" all the logical processing power of someone with an IQ much lower...say 80 IQ.  Super Empaths DO understand and can revisit that stage of out emotional development that we believe you are experiencing.   We do understand how a person living on the autism spectrum feels because we can imagine (and if we have personal experience wth autistic people) even feel what the experience is like to have a sensory processing system that is not as functional as ours.  Again, compare to IQ.  The person with a super high IQ of 150 will know how to solve the very simple math problems that a person with a 85 IQ score can solve.  That person with a 150 IQ contains all the computational abilities and "logical scope" of the person with a 85 IQ.  SAME AS WITH EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE.  A high EQ person contains all the emotional capacities, the emotional processing abilities of those who have lower emotional system capabilities.  This is just life, my friend.  We have our strengths and weakness, our capacities to learn and evolve.  No journey through life is worth more or less than anyone else's.

It's fascinating how many overlaps there seem to be in all the different forms of neurodiversity. As my psychiatrist likes to say, there's nothing inherently good or bad about being neurodiverse - it's just a different way of being human. Yes I'm autistic and I've often wondered if I'm a sociopath especially when I'm very depressed, because I just don't really connect or understand another person feeling emotions a lot of the time. I'm not completely devoid of empathy especially for cute animals and young children haha, but it is a struggle often especially when I'm getting burnt out and overwhelmed. But at the end of the day even if it's a struggle sometimes to connect, I do care for other people and feel bad if I hurt them. Heck I even feel bad about inanimate objects sometimes. ¬†@LDJ-r8e¬† If you want to interact with humans, you're going to meet and interact with some people on the sociopathy spectrum.  They don't all do crimes, and you can't just imprison them for thinking a certain way.  Like she said, sometimes we're talking about children.  It's just an aspect of being human, and living in groups.  Some humans are more low-affect/low-empathy than others, that's just how it goes.  It's healthy to care about these people, because they are people too, and we all have to live together.  It's good to learn about what it's really like to have such a low affect, so we can help children like this grow up as happy and pro-social as possible, and so we can avoid being hurt by them.  Seeing them as all monsters, completely different from normal people, can only make it worse.  She talks about this in the interview.  It's a great interview, you should listen to it.

This makes me feel like sociopathy isn‚Äôt a thing. It‚Äôs a certain pattern of coping mechanisms to deal with difficulties regulating thoughts and emotions. Well, actually that might make it a legitimate diagnosis if it‚Äôs a specific pattern. But I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a lack of empathy I think it‚Äôs a different approach to dealing with difficulty and stress. Some people turn to drugs, which similarly blocks off emotion and empathy, because it‚Äôs often too much to deal with sober. Her description of her behaviours sound very similar to those of people prone to addiction. I wonder how much of it is her ability to recognise emotions, and how much of her not recognising emotions is a defence mechanism. She says she doesn‚Äôt have a desire to engage in pleasurable activities, but she does: she describes her destructive behaviours brought her relief. Not going to the toilet at the right time is a sort of behaviour: clearly she got something from that, she delights in telling the story. And it fits with her ‚Äúbeing in spaces she shouldn‚Äôt be‚Äù description of her relief behaviours. In general it seems like she delights from the relief of being able to identify as a sociopath. It explains her difficulty in resolving her emotions and feelings, or lack thereof. It makes that difficulty okay, socially and mentally. Empathy is a difficult thing to feel. And when one struggles to shut off feeling empathy for everything, it is exhausting. So having a reason to shut it off is a relief. It is comfortable, compared to living in that undiagnosed unknown.
¬†@austinhernandez2716¬†I think we all are, but how we respond to the extreme emotions is the end result here. ¬†@useful-engine¬† perhaps! I suppose what you describe could be in a similar position. It comes down to, as you say, the empathy and emotional awareness. Pyschopathy/sociopathy is like a complete rejection of the emotional/empathatic body. (Which, because of the craziness in our cultures, pretty much every one done does to some extent, but we don't take it as far.) This means the psychopaths have to learn empathy intellectually, and mimic the behaviors. But learning data is not the same as actually feeling empathy. This is similar to autistim types, but it's in reverse: they feel a lot empathatically, but because the world is crazy, they have to learn to adapt to it in order to fit in with others, which causes intellectual development and behavior mimicking to become a good coping strategy.
¬†@useful-engine¬† to put it simply. One end of the horseshoe, are people with no empathatic feelings, and on the other are people that feel a lot of everything. Big hearts, vs no heart.  Most people are in between those extremes. But because we have to all get along together in this world, we have to act like the people in the middle (masking).

¬†@evelynbeverley2277¬† Children are not sociopaths, they lack an understanding of the world around them, how their actions affect others, and how to identify more complex feelings in other people. Conversely, it is actually difficult for people who have a strong degree of empathy to ‚Äúreturn‚Äù to a time where they had no empathy, because normally, that doesn‚Äôt exist. It‚Äôs not like IQ, where you can learn multiplication and still remember how to add to find the solution. There is no natural progression between one state and the other in the case of sociopathy and non sociopathy.
¬†@StrayChoom¬†She is literally talking about how hurting another human being gave her a ‚Äústate of euphoria‚Äù. A person with autism might accidentally say something rude, because of a missed social cue, people with schizophrenia can become dangerous if they are having a hallucinatory episode, though it is no more their fault than if it was anyone else reacting to anesthesia for example. A person with Sociopathy or Psychopathy intentionally and knowingly hurts and manipulates people, not because they lack awareness of what they are doing or that it has a negative impact on the other person, but because they derive pleasure from causing others pain, or they simply do not care if they are hurting other people. You can try to class sociopathy as just another way that people are ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù, but it‚Äôs hardly the same. There is a reason most people have an instinctual aversion to sociopaths, and it‚Äôs because of it developed as a survival mechanism over millions of years of evolution.

Apparently I thought this analogy was only fitting for a small part of OCD and rituals and thoughts happening with it. During the "ritual" mostly the patient doesent have a feeling of control or even it, whatsoever. Due to the immense emotional stress the body and mind are going through. But its no magical, misterious unknown thing, especially after a few sessions of therapy. Its, within the disorder, a totally explainable prozess, its roots within the patients psyche and life and experiences, the  problems behind the compulsive thoughts and rituals as a coping mechanism for deeper problems (in most cases). My only concern was the point of OCD being inexplainable for patients, which is only true mostly during the stressfull ocd-situation and without therapy/information/education and self reflection

When I was six, new people moved into our neighborhood and they had a son the same age as me. We met on the street when we both went out to ride our bikes and, hoping to be friends, we started playing together. Not long into that, I started to realize something was a little off with my new friend.  Then, one day, as we were playing on the side of a dirt hill behind his house, he pointed to a boat in the bay some miles away and said that his dad was on that boat. I casually mentioned that we couldn't tell which boat we were seeing so we couldn't know if his dad was on that very one. He came walking up to me and when I turned to look at him he tried to stab me in the eye with a stick. Left a small scar on my left cheek. That was more than 40 years ago.  He's an insurance salesman now.  *Amendment to this post - Looked him up for the first time in years. He's an "insurance company executive" now.
I once knew a funeral director whom I suspected was a sociopath. He was incredible at his job, mastering not only his own duties but also the specific needs of various religions. If a pastor or a priest was not available as far as possible, he stepped in.  He made people feel safe and heard, earning the admiration of the community. Yet, he didn't seem to truly understand many "normal" emotions. Still, he knew exactly how to respond in a way that gained him friends, prestige, and a lot of money.
This is so interesting! I'm autistic, and there's a lot of misinformation about how autistic people experience emotions, especially empathy. We get called sociopathic sometimes because we ALSO mask around neurotypical people. But the major difference is that, when you ask us, "How do you feel your feelings," a lot of times, it's very deeply. We DO feel shame; we DO feel regret. We tend to have high emotional empathy, but struggle with cognitive empathy. We tend to have low affect not because we aren't feeling something intensely, but because we don't automatically emote the way that neurotypicals do. When I talk to someone, I have to devote a lot of energy to making a "listening face" and changing my expression appropriately. When I'm with people I know well, I usually look away from them often during the conversation and will just SAY what I'm thinking/feeling rather than trying to express it with my face. Looking away from people's faces actually helps me process what they're saying because faces are SO expressive and so intense that my nervous system gets overwhelmed with all the incoming information--but when you do that with neurotypicals, they think you AREN'T listening. And if I just say what I mean rather than trying to convey it with my face, most neurotypicals will project meaning onto the words as if I have a hidden agenda because that's how NTs typically communicate. But as an autistic person, I REALLY AM just asking when you're planning to start on dinner, not insinuating that you should do it NOW or that you're not doing enough around the house or that your schedule should be on my terms üòÖ I'm literally just asking for an estimated time so I can figure out whether to eat a snack or not. So, I get what she means about just acting to try to survive, enough though my internal experience is completely different--people just really don't like when others behave differently than they do, no matter the reason.
I had a dating rule: "never date a psychologist/psych major". Because very often it's people with unusual psychological issues that turn to psychology to learn about themselves.   This woman is an inspiration in a weird way. Had an issue, found a way to conquer it the best way she could.

I wanted someone to just talk to me as a blank state and give helpful feedback. And this would‚Äôve genuinely been incredibly refreshing.

Her parents were highly respected, successful professionals and kind people , her younger brother was an angel, so we were never able to figured why she was so different from them. The most clear and accurate explanation of this condition. I felt especially relieved when she talked about how people are self diagnosing and have taken clinical terms as typical human behavior. Anxiety is not being nervous. Depression is far beyond sadness. Neurodivergence is not being quirky or unique. Social media has made people want to use these real diagnoses as excuses for behavior. Psychological disorders are far beyond mental challenges. It is an entire physical and mental situation. I am neurodivergent with many health conditions and all three of my children are as well. The truth needs to be revealed about the complexity of our lives. I have been searching for a neurodivergent therapist. To live it is to know it. Plain and simple. This was a brilliant interview.

@I‚Äôm not sure you‚Äôd find an answer in the survival-through-social-value frame here, if that helps alleviate some of your confusion. The success (and even their air of danger) that many functioning sociopaths are able to achieve through a combination of their traits can make them very attractive to lots of non-sociopaths. One reality of humanity is that neurotypical does not mean rational. Neurotypical can include a lot of commonly-held emotionally-rooted biases, distortions and delusions, that work for us because they are commonly-held/accepted.

@SergeantSucrose That's a really interesting scientific question you raise. Keeping in mind that not all variation within a large population is necessarily positively adaptive (ie some persists evolutionarily because it is just part of statistical distribution along a particular spectrum within our species, not necessarily because it provides a specific benefit?)  I do note that there's been some interesting research indicating that sociopathic, psychopathic & narcissistic personality traits may be far more common amongst big-firm C-suite personnel than amongst their employees. There's obviously a huge amount of nuance that needs further exploration, but one could speculate that perhaps there may have been some environments within human history where being less empathetic has proved valuable for specific individuals, at least? And because the positions they achieved have been ones of power/influence/high resources, that has contributed significantly to its genetic persistence as a trait?  NB: I can't speak to net benefit/loss to society as a whole arising from such leadership, sorry, definitely don't have the knowledge for that! But it's an intriguing question nonetheless.

@slimsonite2111¬†lol well tbh sometimes the people we think are NTs actually aren't... they have severe mental illnesses too but just ACT like they are NT as we have seen. ¬†@slimsonite2111¬† sorry for the typos and oversharing lol but I care about you because I know how rough it is. Big virtual hugs and genuine well wishes to youüíû
Yeah, it's interesting what we have in common. We're both masking, we're just masking different things. I feel all the emotions neurotypical people do, but expressing them is a learned behavior, because my natural responses would either be flat and hard to read or somehow inappropriate. You can't change what's inside, but you can work on what comes out. So I can, ironically, empathize with this.
I'm actually thinking there is no neurotypical. Everybody has something unique going on. I wonder sometimes if neurotypical is just another way of saying conservative, compliant, and excellent at masking. I think, as a society,  we need to re-evaluate "normality'. Everybody seems to agree on the surface that "there is no normal" but we still have these conventions where we perceive someone is "not normal". I think most of it comes down to judgement and the self projection it causes. And also that most people are just not  good at listening and thinking outside their own box. I know I had to learn to look at people in conversations as a kid. I just couldn't concentrate on the conversation if I looked at them and it took a long time to learn. I became practiced at holding my focus on their face while they're talking, but still look around when I'm speaking to them. But I'm a good listener.  I'm still very good at picking up audio cues in conversations. Very good.  I know my ability to have empathy comes mostly from personal experience. I'm very good at finding something in my past that had the same dynamics as whatever the other person is going through and I use that memory to respond, even when I don't feel it. So I'm still viewing from my own box, but I do care and don't like to see suffering. But when it comes to animals or small children I experience empathy emotionally, very strongly and mostly reactively. It's kind of weird. I also used to work in intellectual disability services and everyone agreed I had a real  knack for it. I had no idea I was on the spectrum at the time, but something in me must have known I had found "my people" LOL. But back to judgement and projection. I have learned that being "not neurotypical" is hard socially. Really bloody hard. Especially when you lived 41 years having various diagnoses for things you never ticked over half the boxes for (I'm now 57 and have had time to explore autism from a personal perspective a bit). So I am hyper-aware of people having their quirks and that they may be on the spectrum, and at least attempt to hold off judgement until I work them out a bit, regardless of their neuro-status. (I have also discovered I find people on the spectrum more likable ‚ò∫‚ò∫).   There are leaps and bounds happening in societal awareness (at least in the Western traditional social context) of just how unique people are and how it's mostly ok. We don't insist on rigid conformity in the way we did when I was growing up. Our amygdala wants to identify friend or foe and do risk assessment very quickly, but I think, thanks to enormous amounts of info on how prevalent "not neurotypical" is, we are evolving to a point where the rational mind can compete much more fairly with the amygdala. The flip side, the yin and yang, of the narcissistic trends apparent on much of the internet, is that people are becoming more self aware, which  then facilitates a deeper awareness of what others are going through mentally and emotionally. And THAT is something I am very grateful for and try to learn from as much as I can. There might be a time when we can just let people express themselves naturally (as long as there is not harm being done) and not project our own limited perspectives onto them prematurely. That'll be nice I think.
If it's important, I was diagnosed with ASD a year ago, and I wouldn't say that this woman looks like the right specialist for me. I just don't understand how she gets away with it, she doesn't sound convincing.  Speaking about the teacher's satisfaction with the child's work and the circumstances of getting the car key: this woman has logic, but it seems to be very short. For example, she doesn't understand that your grades will depend on whether the teacher is happy with you or not, parental approval and admission will depend on grades, and so on. That the reaction of people's emotions is important not for its own sake, but for the sake of the consequences that life in society and communication and sanctions for compliance bring.  It's the same with cars, it's not enough to say that you were given the keys. You need to figure out why you were given them. For example, "I got the keys from my friend Alex, he entrusted me with the car for a while so that I could ride and relax, because it helps me relieve tension after an argument with my girlfriend. Alex and I are good friends. he trusts me, and we haven't discussed it in the chat, and we don't have any other contract document, because we're as close as a family. I can call him and he will confirm" ‚Äî you take the phone, change the contact of the liar friend to "Alex", call him. Alex, hi, I'm still riding in your car. Is this normal? Yes, it is. Confirm this to the police. Thank you.  Voila. Convincing cause-and-effect relationships.  I don't care if she's a sociopath, but her inability to understand the lingering effects of communication makes me wonder how anyone could possibly believe her lies. Many seven-year-olds don't know why they need to get good grades, and that's okay. Just tell them that you will give them frightening, painful, or harmful negative sanctions for not meeting expectations. Do not believe in the honesty of children, they are not your friends, they are only concerned about their well-being, and it always depends on how adults treat the child.  Therefore, I have little idea how she got her education and realized herself in society. Are all of you satisfied with the extremely inconclusive and short explanations she provides?

"But as an autistic person, I REALLY AM just asking when you're planning to start on dinner, not insinuating that you should do it NOW or that you're not doing enough around the house or that your schedule should be on my terms üòÖ I'm literally just asking for an estimated time so I can figure out whether to eat a snack or not." I think I'm realized something while watching this. As an autistic person, one way I'm similar to a sociopath is that I often don't care about social expectations, but I think I learned that as a way to cope with the fact that, at least as a child, I simply was not going to be accepted by my peers. As a "weirdo", I simply was unable to meet their expectations, and often I didn't even understand what the expectations were. Also, when I knew what they were, I often didn't understand why - it's hard to care about expectations that seem stupid (which is how I often judged those expectations then). Conversely, because older people were often more accepting, I did care more about their social expectations. My Dad could simply say he was disappointed in me (something he didn't often say, and only if I tangibly did something wrong) and I would be devastated with guilt and shame.

It's really weird because I was recently diagnosed with autism (the whole process started quite late, at 32 years old), and I don't feel like I'm masking like so many other people on the spectrum describe.  I would say that I am over sensitive when it comes to emotions.  I do find I have to look away sometimes, as eye contact might make me a little uncomfortable. I struggle to create or maintain relationships and I don't know how to develop interests or hobbies.  I can't handle pressure. Which has restricted me to a basic supermarket job, meaning I cannot afford to move out of my dad's apartment. Which for me, is deeply shameful.

i have begun to clarify when asking questions like this with pretty much everyone around me. if i ask "is there a plan for dinner tonight?" because i want to know if i need to make my own dinner, they assume i am hungry and expect them to make dinner. in reality i would often prefer them to say "no there's no plan." but they feel pressured to come up with a plan for dinner and make it themselves. it has the opposite effect of what i intend, and i realized that the phrasing as well as the timing are pretty important to achieving a desired outcome.   instead, asking early in the day what the plan for dinner is eliminates the assumption that i want to eat dinner right now. or, asking something like "im thinking about making (meal) for dinner tonight, does that sound good?" gives them opportunity to bring up what their dinner plan was, if they had one, and also doesnt pressure them into thinking i want them to make me food.  there's just a lot of mental chess around discussing things with people that i dont think people appreciate when they have been doing it automatically their whole lives. my default when asking a question isnt to change the question to prevent them from assuming things, so if i dont have a pre-planned phrase like with dinner, its usually best to over-explain my question and leave nothing up to them to assume or misinterpret. which is apparently not the normal approach for neurotypicals.

I also make efforts to manipulate my facial expressions when someone is telling me something important or serious because I don‚Äôt want them to think that I‚Äôm not listening because in my mind, that would upset them and I don‚Äôt want to make people upset. ¬†@sallybalkin8507¬† There is a difference in the way Neurotypicals process information and the way Neurodivergent processes information. NT's frontal lobe functions better so the NT has an executive function which is why they can do stuff easier and not get overwhelmed. Their brain is thinking multiple thought processes at the same time where as the ND's brain is Monotropic. Hence the hyperfocus of the ND brain. Even with ADHD although their brains may jump from one thing to the next it is only thinking one thing at a time. Which is what makes them seem so scattered and chaotic (I am AuDHD, so both autistic/ADHD). The reason NDs struggle to learn in the school systems we have now is that we process information in the opposite direction from the NTs. Because NTs have so many thought processes running at the same time, they only burn shallow neuropathways causing them to not remember information for very long.  Because NDs have hyperfocus we store information long term to permanently. It may take NDs slightly longer to process the new information, but we keep it longer.   My point is that there is a brain type called neurotypical and a brain type called Neurodivergent (the overlap in the different neurodivergent brains tells me it is probably one type with different presentations. Our ND brain type is just as normal as the NT brain type even though we are a much smaller section of society. Within both brain types, each person is an individual. NTs have their own struggles, but they deal with them often more easily because they have natural support systems. Society is not set up to support NDs, because we are the minority and the NT society prefers to label us as broken. That is changing slowly though.
As an autistic, you feel it, but sometimes fail to show it.  Sociopaths are the opposite.

ADHD is having too much of everything and trying to dull it down for the neurotypicals. That difference is so interesting!

It's uncomfortable to admit it but I can relate. From a young age I've had psychology as an interest because it helped me understand other people and myself. Then I majored in psychology and realized that I might in fact be autistic, now I'm awaiting a diagnosis.   But I've met a lot of people that went into psychology for no particular reason, almost randomly or because it's what fitted their grades, I've noticed that some of them lack the passion though (in my opinion you need passion for this, especially if you become a therapist, like doctors and nurses).   I've also met people that got in it because they've seen suffering, or the wonders of the mind and just want to know more and help people. Like my professor in psychopathology, he is a psychiatrist and chose that path because as a teen he lost his best friend out of nowhere and it left him in a huge mental shock, that's what made him want to know more about the mind. I have another professor, in developmental psychology that got into it randomly and lacks purpose (in my opinion), the difference is obvious, they both know their subjects but their attitudes toward the Human are different, the second one is also less empathic and understanding, not much different from laymen (I've experienced it first hand bc I also have a sever stutter and he treated me badly because of it), so the normal ones can also be wicked. As a special educator who specializes in Autism spectrum, I agree.  I did not baby or caudel them. They were still expected to do the same work as the other students. But, the way the goal was accomplished may be altered depending on the individual child's likes and dislikes.  For example, in KG, I had a student who refused to do his coloring sheets with crayons. But he would color them with his pencil. I wondered why.ü§î So I started coloring with both a pencil and a crayon to figure out what's the difference?ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è  It was a texture thing.  It feels slightly different rubbing a pencil across a piece of paper than a crayon. ü§î So I explained to his teacher and asked if instead of crayons, he could use colored pencils? The next day, I brought him colored pencils.  Problem solved. üëç  It wasn't that he was unable or unwilling to do the assignment. It was just a sensory issue with a simple solution. üòâ

And as someone autistic I disagree and do not want sociopaths for doctors. ¬†@RioRav¬† I think this is a very interesting and valid counterpoint. I'm autistic, and a therapist, and through my own research I know that we are disproportionately targeted for abuse because we are more vulnerable in certain ways. We tend to stand out as different, which often isolates us, and those who are already isolated are generally easier to abuse. We also tend to have a harder time discerning the motives of the people around us, and so may be less likely to pick up on the red flags of dangerous or manipulative people. The risks of abuse goes ever upward the more evident it is to potential abusers that we may have difficulty communicating to others, because it means we're therefore less able to communicate about the abuse too.  By a strange and unfortunate coincidence, I can say I was also sexually abused by a female doctor at about 13. I won't speculate on why she was the way she was, but it just highlights the risks of being from a more vulnerable population with a health provider who may get some inherent thrill from destructive or antisocial behaviors. At the same time, I do believe sociopaths (and similarly maligned neurodivergent people) deserve help to live the most successful life they can, and coping skills to avoid harming others. I feel safer and more comfortable with higher empathy healthcare professionals as a patient or client, but at the same time I can understand and respect why some people would actually feel more comfortable working with someone like Dr. Gagne.

The last thing I want is a pat on the back and a box of tissues, that is a waste of time. Too many therapists out there seem to think their job is about soothing feelings and building self esteem. I don‚Äôt want false self esteem, I don‚Äôt want to feel good about myself if Im acting like a turd. Autism and sociopathy are two different disorders. Sociopathy is an anti-social disorder. Autism is a Neuropsychological disorder. People with autism do have empathy, but the theory of mind is often lacking. Theory of mind and empathy are often equated, incorrectly.

It's the same with cars, it's not enough to say that you were given the keys. You need to figure out why you were given them. For example, "I got the keys from my friend Alex, he entrusted me with the car for a while so that I could ride and relax, because it helps me relieve tension after an argument with my girlfriend. The main difference between someone with HPD and NPD is that histrionic individuals do in fact feel guilt and shame especially if they realized that they had been socially rejected or embarrassed. Only difference between narcissists and sociopaths is that narcissists tend to get excited about being the center of attention or being socially admired, but sociopaths are just completely anti-social, they really don't care what people think about them, just self-centered things that they can get from interacting with people (such as money or sex). ¬†@hirsute-of-happiness¬† But narcissism isn't always a diagnosis either. There IS NPD, but there's also narcissism just as a personality style. For someone to have Narcissistic Personality Disorder they need to be uncomfortable with how it affects their life and feel the need to look for help and stop the behavior.  People who don't feel like anything is wrong with them, and to whom narcissism actually seems to be working, they're just narcissists, that's their personality style, not a disorder, it's an antagonistic personality style for sure, but not a disorder. They can slide  along a spectrum that has the potential to make them more dangerous at times of high stress or different phases of life. Such as when a spouse chooses to leave an unfeeling sociopathic partner. The sociopath can become more dangerous in thought and action as a result of the increased stress they are experiencing.  In her scenario not experiencing human emotions is seen as a positive thing, but that is not the experience of people around a sociopath. The word "anti-social" is colloquially used in the technical sense of "asocial"  The first time I heard the word "asocial" was when learning a different language. In my "dialect" anti-social means precisely "asocial" so I dont blame anyone for "confusing" the two terms.
¬†@Ichinin¬† As a psych major this was one of my pet peeves. I gave up on trying to explain it to people. They've made up their minds about it and usually come up with the same "colloquial" crap you see here. Clinically, they are two entirely different concepts.
Being asocial ("not social") and being  "against socialness/society" are two vastly different conditions!
Plus, there's a difference if you're indifferent to society or outright hate it...

32:45  The idea that being a child to a parent and having to prioritise the parents reactions and emotions to something, over how the problem is affecting you (like how a bad grade might make future work harder for you, or you need to do something important but it has to go through a parent first) is such an interesting concept. Her description of feeling relief with getting her diagnosis is probably pretty universal for neurodivergent people. I was also very relieved when I got diagnosed with GAD. Finally getting an explanation for why I felt so awful gave me hope. It also made me feel validated. I knew it wasn't my own fault that I was anxious. I wasn't just crazy. But until I had my diagnosis, I felt like I really was crazy. Having panic attacks all the time for seemingly no reason made me feel totally crazy. So my diagnosis was a big relief.

¬†@NikedaNinja¬† Thank you for the work that you do! I hope you find a balance. I've noticed that the more empathetic therapists I've worked with usually had more impactful trains of thought and words of confidence to offer me, while the more removed therapists felt safer overall but barely said things that resonated. With removed therapists, I didn't have to learn to understand the responses/microresponses and figure out if I was safe or not, they were just blank and receptive, but with empathetic therapists I felt like something was said almost every session that jolted me into thinking about things differently - because they actually resonated and came from a place of really hearing me and taking on my point of view. I think balanced therapist have the ability to really be remarkable. Good luck!
¬†@lisaloreign485¬† So well said. I am studying to be a therapist and I think balance is key. I don't think have a therapist give you blank stares is helpful. I want someone empathetic and to have the capacity for vulnerability.
Just be keenly aware of 1) transference; it happens with us and with our clients. It happens all the time, outside of work as well. Some guy is suddenly cranky with you in a check out line, bc you remind him of his cheating ex wife. üòÇ or is kind to you bc you remind him of his oldest daughter. It‚Äôs much more subtle and nuanced but you understand. 2) practice putting up a shield, and showering off everything you‚Äôve taken on. Let it all run down the drain. ‚ù§ it‚Äôs hard. You‚Äôre very right to say: ‚Äúwait. Why am I taking on this emotional labor and the other person isn‚Äôt?‚Äù I think there‚Äôs a way to not lose our empathy but also not be sucked dry. Of course, there‚Äôs always a few clients who get under our skin and who we root for more than others. ‚ù§ but, draw up that shield a bit, journal, and let the worry wash down the drain.

¬†@a.sch.1261¬† Thank you for your response. I genuinely read through it all, and agree with some. Low to moderate sociopaths that can function in society deserve love, even if they cannot give it themselves. It would just take someone who is fine with not receiving it, but sociopaths do deserve it. But I‚Äôm going to have to disagree with you on calling this an ableist approach. Mute, deaf, poorly regulated emotions, etc. are all in an entirely different basket than sociopathy. Humans at their core are social creatures. Since the first humans, groups and villages and cities and countries have all stuck together to depend on one another. It takes a village to raise a child. We cannot do everything on our own, and we desperately need to depend on each other to thrive. Humans are social beings. Sociopathy is the antithesis to this. It‚Äôs literally called anti-social personality disorder, because those with sociopathy feel zero need to be part of the social fabric that ties humanity together. That‚Äôs not being ableist, that‚Äôs just acknowledgement. Sociopaths should and do mask themselves to fit in with other social humans. If they operated the way they truly felt, the rest of everyone would absolutely despise them for being remorseless and unempathic. Me saying the capacity for compassion is what makes me human does not mean I think sociopaths are not deserving of love. But don‚Äôt get me wrong. They don‚Äôt deserve love because they are sociopaths. Rather, they deserve love in spite of being sociopaths. They are not on the same level of social humanity that you and I are. And that‚Äôs okay. The ironic part is your empathy allows you to feel bad for them and uncomfortable with my phrasing, whereas an actual sociopath could not care less how I phrase it because the validation of others is not something they give a damn about. I respect sociopaths. I would never choose to love one. (that wasn‚Äôt related to me).
‚Äã@dominicharlow747  she never said she doesn't feel emotions, but that he feelings aren't as intense as that of her husband and others. She wanted a family when she grew up, but she also knew she couldn't be with just anyone. She may not experience remorse or guilt in the sense that you or I do, but she doesn't go out of her way to intentionally hurt people.   At least she got help when her father suggested it. She could have completely rejected the notion altogether that she needs help. She stuck with the therapy and put in the work to better understand herself, and to change how she copes with the need to release pressure. She found healthy ways to relieve that pressure.   The fact that she also recognizes how parents respond to something like a child getting a bad grade and handling it in a way that focuses more on the child's feelings and thoughts over it, as opposed to making them feel bad for the bad grade, is a plus for her in the parenting department. Her kids probably feel like they can express their feelings better and that means she can get to the core of why they got said bad grade and help them to do better in the future.   Emotional responses from parents about a bad grade do more harm than good. Most kids already feel bad about that bad grade. They don't need their parents to heap more guilt on them. That's never done any child any good. They just feel worse about themselves, and end up with a complex.

I wish more therapists initiated open discussions (upfront and during therapy) about interpersonal communication preferences and different therapy modalities. *I* didn't know I had cptsd from childhood trauma, and kept ending up with "blank slate" therapists whose lack of empathy or input actually set me BACK by evoking the lack of attunement in my childhood.  üòü  I know now that therapists staring at me with no expression as I shared vulnerable experiences was triggering Emotional Flashbacks to growing up in Childhood Emotional Neglect (CEN) with an unempathic narcissistic, alchoholic, depressive mother (and with a similar lack of constructive guidance or tools). üò∞ I was hardwired to be hypervigilant to every flicker of emotion on my mother's (and by extension every person's) face for SAFETY, brainwashed that I'm inherently bad and need to constantly adjust myself to be more acceptable to others, gaslighted that my emotions and perceptions were wrong, and programmed that I'm not ALLOWED to validate my own feelings, thoughts, reality, etc. Of course emotionless "blank slate" therapists felt unsafe and anti-helpful to me!¬†  It took a LOT of healing for me to get to the point that I can honestly not care what someone thinks of me (huzzah! üòÄüèã), and I'm so glad that along the way I realized that I can choose to not allow people into my life (including therapists) who trigger me or just lack expressive empathy and attunement. Consciously giving myself what I missed out on in childhood feels good! :face-red-heart-shape: And I think the reprieve from constant triggering was pivotal in giving myself the emotional space to get in touch with MY feelings and inner wisdom about what works best for me or not. Healing rocks! üòÉüíÉü§∏üåàüåøü§ìüòªüòÑüçÄüíñ
