Late diagnosed sociopath here  For the first almost 25 years of my life, my therapists/psychiatrists and me myself were convinced my being "different" was because of my unusually troubled childhood. Son of an affair, which got found out before i was born, alcohol and drug abuse in pregnancy, my mother then finding a new  - very violent - guy with an alcohol problem we lived with for 8 years and that she had 2 more children with, who i as a kid also acted out on - physically and psychologically then when i was 10, i got taken away from home to live in a "foster home for troubled children" kind of thing, there just locked myself in a room for most of the 4 years i was there, spending my time learning instruments, drawing, programming, and when i was forced to do something where i had to interact with people because what i was doing "wasnt healthy", i chose soccer, and hyperfixated on that as i did on the other things - to an unhealthy degree. Genius level intellect at school, horrible behavior and constant trouble with other students and teachers.  this all to say, ive been misdiagnosed with other disorders which could explain away some of my behavior, but none really fit. then, after i did something i dont think i should talk about and went to jail, i had another assessment and the psychiatrist who happened to be a diagnosed sociopath saw what was actually going on.   I have since come to understand myself and what makes me different from most people, and integrated back into society well. Sociopathy needs to be studied more so cases get identified earlier. Thank you for this video.
I hope people don‚Äôt take this video the wrong way and lower their guard against sociopaths because this woman actually took the time to analyze what was wrong with her and was effective in countering her destructive behavior. Most sociopaths, in fact a huge majority of them don‚Äôt even believe there‚Äôs anything bad or wrong with their behavior. Very few of them will ever try to understand, much less address this behavior.  I understand why this woman feels like the condition is stigmatized, but there‚Äôs a reason for it. Until actual proper research is done into the condition and how to address and mitigate it, people should try to stay away from sociopaths. You can‚Äôt fix them even if you want to, unless they want to fix themselves. And most of them WILL ruin your life if you don‚Äôt keep far enough away.
Ok, here's the thing. (warning: long and triggering post ahead)   As a psychiatrist, it is such a hard line to tread diagnosing someone as a sociopath or a psychopath without risking the entire therapeutic relationship because even sociopaths feel offended when you call them sociopaths. They would rather be labelled autistic or borderline personality disorder than be called a sociopath. In most cases, to get treatment on the way, I'll go with whatever label they feel most comfortable with, even though the treatment they receive may be suboptimal due to a misdiagnosis.   The entire health system treats the individual differently when they see the label of a 'sociopath' on their file. As a healthcare provider, you have to be cocksure of yourself to do that to someone. It is a death sentence sometimes, and I almost have to feel no guilt (aka be a sociopath myself) to be dishing out these diagnoses; therein lies the dilemma in mental health. You'd get a lot more sympathy for autism than you would for BPD than you would for sociopathy. Oftentimes, we rely on our colleagues to read between the lines when reading our reports. But you'd never know who you'd meet at the clinic that day.   Sometimes, just because a mental health diagnosis is accurate, doesn't mean it's helpful.   Another thing she didn't mention is the factor of intelligence. Generally speaking, high-IQ sociopaths are articulate and have better impulse control. The opposite is true for low-IQ sociopaths, who are overrepresented in prison populations. A high-IQ sociopath will seek help from a therapist before things get out of hand, while a low-IQ sociopath will turn to far more destructive and maladaptive coping strategies, like violent or sex crimes. Therefore, this isn't just a question of diagnosis; it is also a matter of context.  EDIT: Some people may wonder, if misdiagnosing someone, for the sake of protecting them from an inhumane health system, is unethical. These are people who behave like a mindless cog in a giant faceless system until they suffer injustice themselves.   There isn't a SINGLE DOCTOR I know, who doesn't fudge or embellish patient records, for the sake of helping their patients access care. They get in trouble sometimes, I know I do, but we all keep doing it.   As far as I know, calling someone a 'sociopath' on file does nothing good for them, as opposed to calling them neurodivergent or depressed. They might access help quicker if they are depressed, in which case, it might pay to label them as depressed rather than calling them a sociopath, which will only garner scepticism and stigma.  EDIT 2: For those who think they have ASPD, or sociopathy, and would like to seek help, here are some tips.   You need to understand what 'help' actually means. Currently, there is no evidence-based treatment that has successfully increased prosocial behaviour in ASPD. In fact, some studies even suggest that teaching ASPD individuals empathy only helps them weaponize it against others. The evidence for CBT or other forms of therapy is also extremely limited.   Like autism, there isn't a 'cure' per se to ASPD. An autistic individual might wear noise-cancelling headphones to avoid sensory issues, and an ASPD individual might channel their destructive urges into something more productive. See a therapist to openly discuss strategies that can relieve tension associated with masking, and educate your friends and family about your disorder so they don't get caught off guard.   Many high-functioning CEOs, ruthless bankers, police officers, firefighters, and other high-risk professionals have ASPD, even if they don't know it. ASPD individuals process risk and reward differently, and they usually thrive in autonomous positions and high-stakes environments. A huge part of relieving tension and preventing misunderstanding is to avoid dealing with clueless neurotypical people in general. You either educate the people around you, or you avoid them altogether.   ASPD is the most stable personality disorder across populations and cultures, more so than BPD, OCPD, and other personality disorders. This suggests that ASPD confers an evolutionary advantage to a group by allowing them to make difficult decisions that a purely neurotypical group couldn't. ASPD individuals are NOT likeable, and if they appear that way, it's because they are manipulating you. But they are not there to be liked, that's not their modus operandi.   ASPD individuals can be good providers, just don't expect them to meet your emotional needs. They might be fantastic colleagues, but they don't don't make good friends. Stop seeing them as how you'd like them to be and start appreciating them as they are. Use them for what they are built for. Afterall, they are using you too.   If you want to get a formal diagnosis, stay away from the public health system, and just see a private therapist or psychiatrist. That way, you can keep your records confidential. Alternatively, you can forgo this process and just go by gut feeling. Most people who believe they have ASPD, are usually right about themselves.   If you ever find yourself talking to the likes of me either through the health or judicial system, well, you ****ed up. You weren't very smart. I'll do my best to help you navigate the system, but pitting your destructive urges against the system is a surefire way to end yourself. So turn on your charm, play your cards right, and get out of the system ASAP. You want to live a better life? Remember what I've said above and start working.   Hope this helps.

A lot of what Patric says here is very relatable to me, in that she describes thinking (as a child) "helping is supposed to feel good, but it doesn't and I don't know why."  It sounds a lot like my experience of AD(H)D. Helping makes me feel very good, but you know what doesn't? Completing tasks. I finish emptying the dishwasher or loading a van or writing a paper, and I don't get a dopamine hit and only rarely a sense of pride. Instead, if it was a task that was stressing me out, maybe I'll feel a release of tension, a removal of a negative stimulus. In fact, I often have to use my overactive desire to help others to compensate, to find the motivation to complete "simple" tasks. ¬†@lw498¬† I get that, it was in reference to the two versions of the PCL (PCL/PCLD) & the medical requirement to have a criminal record in order to take the PCL as explained @ 15:24. As she correctly asserts her admission is the only proof of her criminal versatility.  Basic logic easily shows despite their misassociation to one another, there is no way there can be an actual cognitive correlation.  Criminal records are applied according to the laws established BY the governing forces, whereas sociopathy deals with the regulation of emotions used in relation TO criminal behavior. Or In other words; People can only determine the legality of something not the morality of something.  Laws change, morals don't
The two are often conflated due to the disproportionately higher propensity to engage in criminal activities. The universe is inherently lazy nothing exerts more effort than is necessary, this is commonly referred to as the law of conservation of energy. On its face, It is easier to pollute than to properly dispose of environmentally hazardous material, to steal your resources than obtain my own, and far simpler to kill someone & absolutely guarantee their compliance, then attempt to force / convince them to think / act in a particular manner. It is morality that prevents the typical person from pursuing the path of least resistance in all these instances. Be it empathy for others, Ethics of ill attained gains, or a general sense of wrongdoing, there are associated feelings of remorse that accompanies types of decisions in a neurotypical person. However these are replaced in the sociopath's mind with a simple probability matrix incorporating the limitations placed upon them in the event they are caught (Imprisonment or the inability to effectively deploy deceptive methods and tactics in the future). Therefore, if there is even a modicum of possibility, they are able to successfully "get away" with their actions, the sociopath is exponentially more inclined to engage in criminal activities.

¬†@majorpwner241¬† The idea of sociopathy/psychopathy? Those are most definitely real conditions. Also, while environmental conditions can trigger sociopathy, it is heavily impacted by if you have the gene for it or not.
Hard agree. Seeing this video might make people feel like they can understand this disorder better, and make them feel compelled to work to dispel it's "myths". That notion comes from a good place, but it's actually misaligned here, because what you've seen is coming from one of the rare people who've been diagnosed with the disorder, and seems to have been rehabilitated to a large degree. This is not the person most people encounter with such a disorder, and to think that it's something you can combat with knowledge and awareness, is a gross underestimation of the condition.  The woman in this video was successfully rehabilitated, because she came from a family privileged enough to be able to deal with her, and likely low to moderate on the spectrum of sociopathy. Most of these people with this disorder will never be diagnosed, and will use their traits successfully to gain positions of power. They'll never even attempt to stop themselves from seeking out that euphoria that comes from causing someone harm, because there will be no drawback from doing so. You can't understand someone out of having this, or any other dark tetrad disorder. Very few of them are going to come after you with a chainsaw in the middle of the night, rather, they're going to use their intelligence to harm you in ways you won't see coming, and won't be able to stop.   Whatever you take away from this video, don't think it's your responsibility to rehabilitate this condition to others. Leave that to be something debated among the professionals, because you truly don't have a good understanding of how manipulative, and destructive such a person can be. If you meet one, I'd advise you to walk the other way. If you choose not to, I hope you'll be spared the hard lessons I, and many others have had to learn otherwise.

I think that labeling someone you believe to be a sociopath as autistic is taking things too far. Telling an insurance company that a sociopath has BPD to get them coverage for certain treatment programs that you believe will help them makes sense, certainly. Because insurance companies are awful and looking for any opportunity they can to deny care. But I would never misrepresent these things to the client. Of course, as a therapist I have the benefit of more frequent/longer periods of time with my clients upon which to build a very strong rapport. I feel it's more important to be honest with them about my clinical observations, for the sake of their self-understanding, than to be afraid of rupturing the relationship. I've never had a client stop seeing me over such a thing, even when they didn't like what they were hearing, because it's also my job to empathetically and non-judgmentally explain my observation and trust that I've laid the groundwork for us to navigate a difficult conversation.  Withholding the fact their experience is accurately described by a particular stigmatized diagnosis robs them of the opportunity to recontextualize their past and move forward with greater awareness, in my opinion. I'm concerned that your readiness to label a sociopath as autistic is indicative of an outdated view of autism, especially with regard to how autistic people experience their emotions and crucially, their empathy.

1. achievement (who are we comparing ourselves to? past, present, or future? positive drivers or negative drivers ? ) twins >>> envy, greed, and fear OR recognition, pride and mastery  2. significance (I want to help other people, but who to help, and what i want to do for it? an internal and external choice) twins >>> fairness, generosity, and caring [external] OR power and selfish  3. happiness (me and now) twins >>> contentment, fulfilment OR  laziness gluttony 4. legacy (other people define our legacy, our impact in the future) are uncorrelated. twins >>> altruism and generative desire OR fear of death and need for control  Paradox example: an increase in legacy means a decrease in achievement.   > impact about me alone or others?  > context: ski to where the puck will be not where it is now. > values: family influences. > juggling and not balance  * Life has a timeline, as in we have different focus at different stage. Wikipedia: "In 2014, after three doctors declared him healthy, Stevenson experienced unattended cardiac arrest on January 5 in the middle of the Harvard campus. i didnt understand juggling vs balance concept can you elaborate ?
¬†@ShahzadHassanBangash¬† Your comment is 3 months old, but maybe this will (still) help:  The diaglog stats at 27:00  He saying that he doens't like balance because it reminds him of a seal balancing something on his nose.  He is also saying that juggling is about having several balls to hold up, and that holding them up is harder than balancing them. He is saying have to swich focus between balls and watch all of them all the time. He is saying that you especiallly watch the falling ball, and give it positive engery each time you touch it. Lastly he is saying that some balls are like rubber and bounce (like a carreer, it will bounce in a new (Okay) direction if you make a mistake) and that other balls are like glass they will shatter beyond repair (Like your family, or your health).  The main difference in Juggling vs Balance is that in balance you seem to view life as one big thing that needs focused attention all the time to maintain (which sounds overwhelming), while jugglin is about having different separated subjects with different caracteristics and needs, that you keep an eye on all the time but focus on seperately.

Actually in juggling the most important ball is the one you are throwing. If you throw them properly they will just fall into your hand. There is literally no conscious focus on the falling ball. Especially with more complex patterns and more objects the need for placing the balls very precisely increases tremendously, while the catching part remains trivial even in the most advanced patterns. (Certainly every now and then your hand coordination messes up the catching process, but mistakes are random and rare and nothing thats ever gonna need deliberate practice.) Therefore I would say: the most important ball is the one you are about to throw, because its the one thats gonna either fall to the floor itself or mess up your coordination, causing failure further down the line, if thrown poorly. The ball thats already falling will land in your hand effortlessly if it was thrown properly. I hate when people build their metaphors on false assumptions about matters they dont know anything about.

She created him, carried him, birthed him, and she and he will forever share traits, ethnicity, heritage, ancestry, blood. That is real and it matters. ¬†@lvt2050¬† The mother is a biological parent. Epigentics has nothing to do with that.  ‚ÄúDNA MIGHT give you who you look like (not all children look like their genetic parents).‚Äù  If offspring look or behave like the biological mother or not (phenotype) is irrelevant. Children always inherit their physical features from their genetic parents‚Äîthey may just resemble a mix of relatives rather than looking identical to their parents. Recessive genes, genetic variation, and random recombination explain why some children don‚Äôt look exactly like their parents. Behavior is also fundamentally built on the basis of genetic predisposition, then later changed by environment and learning.  You know what you‚Äôre talking about to some degree but massively overestimate your insight in the subject.
¬†@fabianlindberg7051¬† thats what I said, children might or might not look like their genetic parents. However, with egg donor babies we see that often (not always) babies look like their birth mothers. At the moment epigenetics is the only explanation, with time maybe other explanations will be developed.    Please share studies where they successfully  decoupled genetic and environment as influence on behavior, and come to conclusion that its genetics in the basis?
¬†@lvt2050¬† Now you are making things up.  The claim that babies conceived via egg donation or surrogacy often resemble the birth mother (the surrogate) is not supported by genetics or scientific evidence. The genetic blueprint of the child comes entirely from the biological parents (egg and sperm donors), not the surrogate.  While the gestational environment (womb) can affect gene expression, this does not alter which genes are inherited. For example: The surrogate‚Äôs diet or stress levels may impact metabolism, but it will not make the baby look like her.  There is no biological process where a surrogate can transfer her own facial features or physical traits to a baby. This is a myth or at least cognitive bias where people tend to see patterns and resemblances where none exist. Many people share features, doesn‚Äôt mean they are related.

¬†@AnnA-jd4xm¬†The donor is the genetic parent or mother.  The biological mother is the woman whose womb the fetuses grew in.  She provided the biological environment for cell replication. When I watched this and listened to James telling his story, I remembered a phrase that was popular at the onset of the pandemic: "All alone together." James will never see this, but he perfectly represents it. Nine million people, and you can be alone in a crowded room. Tragic, isn't it? Everyone so deeply suspicious of each other, skeptical of each other, contemptuous of each other almost automatically, because you can't know which smiling face wants to hug you, and which wants to put a knife in your back. You can't know--not quickly, anyway--which people offer you a hand up, and which just want to reach out to shove you further down.   Not a globe hopper and I don't see myself crossing an ocean, but should it happen fate permits me to stumble onto this guy, I'm going to say hello, I'm going to shake his hand, and let him know that there are many millions of people who understand what it's like to have nobody. I'm not there anymore, but I was, and it hurt every single day. God bless you, James.

I met a homeless man in America which must have been in similar circumstances. He asked me for  change which I gladly gave him but then he ask ‚Äúcan I hug you‚Äù. I was stunned and said of course and he hugged me and just held onto me. I knew, I could tell, he hadn‚Äôt been      hugged in years, maybe decades. It was a terribly cold, windy evening and he was an elderly man. I hope he made it somewhere warm, I hope he is still alive.

I had an argument with my father about ten years ago. He doesn't drink, I do and everything else with it. I was living at home, came back from the pub and he was in the kitchen waiting for me, and boy did he leave me have it. Told me exactly what he thought about how I carried myself, how I made my money at the time, how I was wasting my life etc. My mother was there, scared that it would go to blows. But I let him speak, listened to what he had to say, accepted some of it, countered some of it but overall told him not to doubt me, that I'd get there in spite of being far from perfect. He cried and hugged me. I'm since sober, back in legit work, a homeowner, etc.  I told that story to a friend of mine one night and he didn't cry but went quiet and said he never had any moment of love and care like I had that night, even my father giving me a bollocking was out of care, and the hug was a genuine moment between father and son. He said his dad walked out when he was 8 and the rest of his childhood was written off.  I don't have any kids, but for anyone reading this who does - remember they need your care, your interest and your respect.

Without healthy connection between you and at least one person in your childhood. Without healthy connection between you and you enviroment. Without that you can not be a healthy human and you will feel bad. And if you live this way long enough there will be nothing left of you except a empty shell.  I think this is perhaps proof that how you relate to someone else, and how you relate to the world itself, is part of what it means to be human. If the attachment between you and your parents and enviroment is unhealthy, it means its unsafe. And if its unsafe, that means you are and feel unsafe. And if you feel unsafe, all other things in life become irrelevant to you because having a sens of safety is perhaps the biggest basic need you need besides food/water/shelter. Care/attachment, play and seeking vs fear/panic/rage and grief are the only emotions a child has from birth to age 3 or 5. The predominant emotions it receives during this period of time control the release of dopamine/serotonin vs cortisol. Theses chemicals ‚Äúwash‚Äù the child‚Äôs brain, imprinting them for life. If the proper care is not provided it can result in permanent damage to the child‚Äôs brain to where the adult cannot property emotionally regulate.  Allowing your child to cry itself to sleep, neglecting the child, abuse or separation (daycare), will all facilitate a negative consequence.
@yaniswashington8828 That‚Äôs quite a callous response. While it‚Äôs true that some people are more susceptible to being traumatised than others, it‚Äôs nothing to do with being ‚Äúweak‚Äù.  In fact, it takes incredible strength to survive childhood abuse.

¬†@redbirddeerjazz¬† I don't think this is true. If anything, it makes you more sensitive to your surroundings ("hypervigilant"), it makes your nervous system more sensitive. I think it is no coincidence that the most troubled individuals are usually the most sensitive and at times euphoric. I most certainly have been.
‚Äã@yaniswashington8828 It has nothing to do with strength or weakness.  We're all living organisms with brains and nervous systems that react to our environment.  Our bodies learn to react a certain way to the environment based on the things we experience, especially trauma.   Complex ptsd is a very real thing that shapes who we are as adults.  You have a very outdated view of how the human body works.

¬†@TheDavveponken¬† I agree and I don‚Äôt see how that contradicts anything I wrote.  Trauma makes your nervous system more sensitive by causing certain brain structures to be bigger or more active than they otherwise would have been. The amygdala for example is the part of the brain that governs the fear response, and trauma causes this to grow bigger, causing, as you say, hypervigilance.

I can attest to that. Ripped away from my birth parents around 2-3 years old. DK why, didn't then either. Old enough to have felt genuine parental love/caring, yet not old enough to understand why it was torn away to never see them again. I can feel lonely in the company of my own friends and family...

Yeah... My mom was mercurial. On one hand, I'm a Mama's boy. We would snuggle when I was young, and it was solid bonding, but, at the same time, she could flip like a switch. My dad worked as a bus driver and his shifts were noon to midnight for a lot of my childhood. Mom would handle most of the day to day disciplinarian roles. She was a screamer, and a hitter. A call home from the principal's office meant I get it the moment I walked in the door, then I'd pray dad didn't find out the following morning before school, or on Saturday. But they talked about me. I put a lot of stress on my parent's marriage from 4-12, when they got divorced. But when my dad's shifts changed before they split, I would get the worst of it from him. But my mom gave me a bloody nose once when I was about 8.   Eventually, my mom ended up getting electro shock treatment in order to get off certain medications (this is what my aunt told me one day when I was in college). When I moved up north to be with her afterwards, she was this super docile woman, very chill. Like a declawed cat. Of course, I had repressed a lot of resentment for my parents that all came flooding back when I was living with her at this stage. And I would dredge up the past and she would cry a lot... She wasn't the same person and here I was fighting her like that version of herself still existed.   I walked out of her apartment in February 2017, and she moved. I regret this every day. I don't know where she is or if she's alive.
I see it more as depth in character. There is a more profound meaning to destitution and loneliness, compared to the cliche life that Hollywood tells you, you should aspire for. I can relate to James. With the only difference being I am able to reconcile with myself and be content in my times of loneliness. And even if I can turn back time, I would not trade my times of solitude for anything else in this world.

@yaniswashington8828 It depends on your past experiences. Some people get stuck in life.
What's fascinating ( and confusing ) is how complex individuals are, including within one's family system.  Given a very dysfunctional home, two siblings might have very different takes on their experiences.  One not deeply impacted to where it severely negatively affects their work life and marriage, the other is profoundly scarred to the point of not marrying and riddled with anxiety over pursuing vocational dreams.  Then, to make matters worse, the former sibling judges the latter as being a loser.  Or the latter can be judgmental and envious of their sibling's progress in life.  It partly displays how selfish we can be in basically insisting others be like us ( with similar success or not ), and it also reflects how different our respective journeys are.  ( I am personally learning to still not be caught up in harsh self-judgment while comparing myself to others' lives.  It's a deep-rooted influence.  Some days are better, some days are worse.  Feelings and thoughts similar to James in the video.  )  What is also interesting is how a person from a severely dysfunctional home can be rather immature in some aspect of their character formation, YET MORE MATURE in other aspects of character compared to peers who look the part according to conventional social expectations.  ( $$$ / home / marriage / kids )  IMHO, it would serve humanity better if we each consistently manage and discipline our respective hypocrisies.  Every person is flawed, we are prone to pride, we are prone to stepping back into hypocrisy.  Which hurts us all, the more "successful" and those deemed "less so".

‚Äã¬†@chihirostargazer6573¬† many circumstances in life are beyond our control but  these events are not sources of regret. By definition a regret can only occur in a situation where a person did have a choice but failed to exercise their agency in a beneficial manner or at all. For example they had failed to make a good choice,  had made a bad choice, failed to act, acted poorly etc. My comment was in reference to regrets but not uncontrollable circumstances.

What if someone told you the opposite was true and they could prove it? Would you listen?  I believe we are all conditioned by our upbringing.   In most cases, it's the misplaced expectations of a life of 'shoulds' that end up messing with us the most.   We compare our current reality with a way that the world should be...  I should have more money. I should have had kids. I should have friends. I should own my own home.  I should have done more with my life.   This is you comparing to an unrealistic fantasy of the way life isn't and will make you feel down.   Now, let's say I sat down with you. We listed out all the things you have. You mentioned health and interests so that's a good start.   Keep creating that list until you see that you do bring value. An insecurity is a perception within your own mind that an attribute or characteristic you posses is not quite ''up to par,'' so to speak. All insecurities begin, and end, in your own mind. Anytime you 'compare' what you have to offer, to what other people have to offer, you're setting youself up to develop a number of egotistical insecurities. This is why you should never base your sense of self-confidence and self-esteem on one specific thing. For example, if 90% of your self-esteem is based on your looks, guess what's going to happen if you're in the company of another person who you perceive as more handsome than you? You're going to feel insecure. Same thing goes for your level of wealth, your sense of humor, your level of education, your degree of success and so on and so on. Your confidence and self-esteem has to come from your ''total package.'' Every quality about you combined together should be the basis for your sense of confidence and self-esteem, not just on particular attribute.

OK, I clearly don't know you nor the guy in the video - but there is one tiny advice I would like to give: GET TESTED FOR ADULT ADHD. I found out when I was 55 and it made a HUGE difference. I now know that a neurological barrier exists between my imagination and my ability to execute. It's been there all my life, I just found ways to trick myself into doing things - and that got harder over the years. Knowing the root cause stopped me being angry at myself all the time. (BTW brain trauma can lead to "pseudo" ADHD/ADD... but the good news is that in many cases, ADD/ADHD medications work well in those atypical cases too).
For all who say it read, read your Bible or turn to Christ. That sure is important. But the Bible also says that it's not good for man to be alone.   Going to a church where it's not just sitting still for an hour might be a good idea. Or if that's not your thing, you could try football or walking football (depending on your age), or any other sports or club. Make sure you join something where people stay and socialise after the main thing. That gives you time to get to know people.  And don't push things. First get to know those people.  Being alone is better than being together with the wrong crowd (for you).
You could be a multi-millionaire and have made that money through selling arms that slaughtered millions. You could have been married 4 times, cheated on 2 and abused the other 2 terribly. You could have had 5 kids, but they all hate you because you were a terrible father.   Finding meaning is difficult in a world that only seems to value material wealth. Be satisfied that you've caused very little harm whilst you were here, treated people with respect and kindness and lived as honourably as you can.   I doubt that there's a person alive that doesn't have regrets. Don't let the rest of your days be filled with bitterness, do the best that you can at living humanely and you'll find peace within yourself. I had a similar experience at a friend's house.  I saw his mother do the things that a mother should do and be affectionate to him to a degree I hadn't experienced with my own mother.  It didn't take very long in watching their interactions for the idea of "Why couldn't she be my mom?" began to surface in my head.  I went to his house several times that year, and it became more than a chance to have fun, but to live vicariously through their relationship of mother and child.  I came to regard observing their interactions as something coequal to my desire to have childish fun with a friend.  Then I would go home to my own family, and the stark contrast became that much more obvious because I, near the end of that year, fully realized what he had and I would never.  It became easier to dissociate from wanting those personal bonds than deal with the hope of having them.  Sure enough, nothing ever changed, only got worse, and now I am the adult I am.  Like what was said in the video, it isn't crying, it just is.  I don't even know why I just typed all this, it won't change anything anyway.
Not having a proper caring home at a young age, not having friends, and still be this well mannered and kind. It's inspiring and I'm amazed. People with far better starts in life could learn something from this man.  Thank you James for your honesty <3

I have also struggled for years with overwhelming thoughts of failure and lack of self worth, so I really connect with the video and these comments. I‚Äôve been on quite a journey, and I‚Äôm getting there, but not there yet. The thing is, these are just thoughts and perceptions, made worse by habitually comparing ourselves with others we consider ‚Äúnormal‚Äù or ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù. The thoughts are meaningless and don‚Äôt define us, but they often have a long history and deep roots which make them hard to shift. I have had many rounds of CBT therapy which has been useful and educational, but I eventually slipped back into old ways. The big change for me was incorporating mindfulness into my daily life and becoming more aware of what I think. Becoming a ‚Äúwatcher of my thoughts‚Äù rather than a ‚Äùvictim of my thoughts‚Äù has had a profound effect on my happiness. Really recommend this to others in the same boat.
Live now, not in the past. Forgive and let go of bitterness. Free yourself from the lies you keep on holding on to, in your mind and heart. You are the one that is the key to change, you need to take the step. If you don't do anything different, it will stay the same, because there is no change. If you keep on proclaiming the same things as the man did over your own life, that is what you reap, as you constantly sow it. What are the lies you believe in? Figure those out, write them down, and do what you can to change them. As words have power, start proclaiming and believing something else. Who says loneliness is a truth? Or that why doesn't anyone like me? Who says those things, if not the voices in your mind? What do you do to change that? You can go head first to deal with the issue. That is a challenging road. But ask yourself, what is it that you desire and want? And what can you do about it? Else you will continue down the same road until you die. You don't need a pat on the back and a hug of sympathy, you need action and decision and steps of change, encouragement to move and encouraging support.

This not having friends thing, let me add a little bit to it. I am myself from big family, too many siblings to have much of an attention and father, even tho was providing, was an absolute dick, no role model what so ever. All growing up on a countryside, going to small school etc. Everyone wants to like the same music, same stuff on tv, same type of clothing, hair etc. You try to be a little bit different and here you are the outsider in a small place with no other outsiders pretty much.  In my case, this kind of experience with limited amount of people to choose from as friends, and idea of not having friends rather than having friends within this weirdly uniform, blunt and unoriginal tribe. Life goes on and I become adult, move to another country, meet and become "friends" with new people from new nationalities, we work in industry where we live and work together so we get close, but it just happens naturaly. Once our lives move on I struggle to be able to keep such contacts and generally know how to in fact have a close friendship   So after all, learning this skill as 35 years old is kind of too late, I am very friendly, people enjoy my company, but we do not move past certain threshold. We will have fun, be silly, be genuine, show true colours, but I will never be able to use that foundation to be able to express deeper emotions to such person. Even my to my wife to be frank.  Afterall, life is good, friend would be good, but either this growing up thing messed it up or my personality traits unable me from being able to get all of those relationships from 3/5 to higher emotional connection

I see a therapist periodically, and we talk about those concepts and how I've had trouble with perfectionism. He told me there can be a positive form of perfectionism and achieving, but whether you're a perfectionist or not the important thing to do is to make sure you love what you do in life. In a sense self improvement can be like putting the cart before the horse where you miss the whole point of achieving which is enriching your life right now by doing something good, something that gives you meaning. Chasing after money can become an obstacle to actually having a successful life, and that kind of thinking can make you actually give up rather than being a positive motivation.

Excuse my tangent but I think we should forgive ourselves. There are so many possible paths one could take. Obstacles, or its other extreme, choice paralysis, are both headwinds your sailboat comes up against, and not all of us are great sailors. This particular chap had to deal with a lack of intimacy from a primary caregiver, and as someone who didn't have that issue, I can only begin to imagine what havoc that wreaks on your psyche.   Also in the West at least, due to the influence of film and popular culture, we expect our lives (or perceived chapters of) to reach a certain denouement, so to speak. In reality, while we all hopefully grow, our 'story arc' is more likely to be some kind of messy meandering, coupla squiggles maybe, even a loop-the-loop for some. Welcome to youtube where you can find youtube-psychiatrists putting out random diagnosis based on 2 min conversation.
Yes he is a failure stop making things up you don't compare what you are to someone else
‚Äã¬†@Sm0keddhany¬† You might be wrong, but I don't blame you.  This comment got super long, but I make an actual point and it's worth reading. Like you, I also dislike the overwhelming amount of diagnosing and self-diagnosing mental health conditions online, mostly because of how reductive and simply wrong it gets (Tiktok psychology), with people throwing out buzzwords and labelling everything under the sun as narcissism, borderline, OCD, AHDH and so on. However, there are 2 things to consider that are different from the typical scenarios of the above.  1. The video is 2 minutes long. I am sure that the gentleman in the video is very long-winded and takes time to arrive to his point (no judgement), so this might have been a 30 minute long conversation that was edited down to 2 minutes. Not the same thing as a 2 min conversation or a one-sided account of a situation you see on Reddit. We are able to get a lot of substantial information about James in these 2 minutes.  2. robotandcat8125 isn't talking about a condition that is severely overused (not yet, at least) in the mainstream. Complex PTSD is a very specific condition that gets easy to spot once you know more about it. And it's not as ambiguous and misunderstood as Narcissistic PD or Borderline PD. Here's an example - if someone says "I feel weak. My fatigue is making my every day worse", then you will see comments with diagnoses ranging from chronic fatigue syndrome to vitamin D deficiency to cancer and a bunch of other things, because it can be any of those things. If someone says "I talk to ghosts of famous ppl and currently Leonardo Da Vinci is helping me write a patent for an invention that will change the world", it wouldn't take a lot of effort to spot Schizophrenia or some kind of Psychotic condition under that same category. In this case, James is talking about specific things that are such telltale signs of CPTSD (complex ptsd) that it almost feels like a training video for psychiatry students. CPTSD is a confusing term for people who haven't dived into the topic, because it has almost no connection to PTSD and is a totally different beast. If PTSD is a broken bone from falling off a bicycle, then CPTSD is a chronic calcium deficiency condition turning bones into glass that happened because a person was locked in a basement for years.
¬†@erica6825¬† the original commenter is talking about Complex PTSD or CPTSD. CPTSD is totally different from PTSD and could be described as a maladaptation to prolonged exposure to trauma or multiple sources of trauma. I strongly encourage you read up on it, because it‚Äôs like a trauma response on steroids
¬†@erica6825¬† Yeah really... someone stubs their toe now and they got PTSD. People are ignorant they throw that word around lightly and 99% of people have no clue what trie PTSD is.

I can't even blame my parents, quite the opposite in fact.  They gave me all the support and opportunities in this world and I failed. Sometimes you're unlucky, sometimes you're stupid. I've been the latter.  For me it's too late, but if a young man is reading this, don't do what I did, ok?  Make the most of your chances in life, even if they're scarce. Don't be conformist. Don't go with the flow because it is the easy, efortless way. Plant your feet on the ground, roll up your sleeves and fight for your own stuff.  Don't become a burden for your relatives like I've become at 52.  In short, don't be me.  God bless.

2:04 The beauty in James's eyes in these shots made me tear up. This has made me realise how fortunate I have been in life with my own upbringing and how much responsibility I have now as a dad. I hug my children daily, try to give them fair guidance and correction but mostly, try to impart a genuine non-judgemental love of people, each one of whom has a story - sometimes a sad one like James does. In a fast paced city (we are in Sydney), it's sometimes hard to pause and consider a lonely figure, but it's always very rewarding when you make a connection with a lost soul or someone who just needs a hug. I fail badly at this, rushing around everywhere and this has made me want to slow down a bit and be better at connecting with those who have faded to the sidelines. Love and peace - Dave

You‚Äôre still so young and all is not lost. You are very self-aware, which is a good thing. As someone who is between your age and James‚Äôs age, I‚Äôd recommend a few things. Join a gym. You will be surrounded by happy music and lots of healthy people. I‚Äôm not saying you need to turn into a bodybuilder, but look after your body because what follows from that is confidence that will impact many areas of your life. Please don‚Äôt engage in any illegal substances as that will impact your mental health massively in a very negative way.   I was extremely shy when I was your age and I had to leave all of my friends to move thousands of miles across the world. I survived that major upheaval and I‚Äôm here today. I have very few friends but that‚Äôs okay. I‚Äôm an only child too, which is really tough sometimes.  Find something you are talented at and that you enjoy doing. Become really good at it. That may take time, but the payoff will be immense. It will open doors for you and will help you socially.  I wish only the best for you. You have the whole world at your feet. I can‚Äôt imagine how excited I‚Äôd be to be 18 again. Think of yourself as a time traveller. Yesterday you were 70 and a failure. Today you‚Äôre 18. Think of the possibilities.

He would only pay for it if he was going to take the classes to become a pharmacist and take over the family pharmacy down in Ocean City (NJ). My dad told him that he didn't want to be one. Hie dad cut him off and stopped paying for his schooling. I think that might have been the last time they spoke. But pops found a way to pay for college, got his degree, and was able to enter the army as an officer, lucky for him he was to young to go into WW2, but too old to be made to go to Korean or Vietnam. Or who knows if I would be alive today. Anyway he became an oil/natural gas salesman and was very successful. Though he had another family/son before he met my mom and remarried. His other son, my half brother started visiting our grandmother regularly as she neared the end of her life. Basically, he knew she lead remarried and her 2nd husband was a pretty savvy investor and left her with a couple million. So he manipulates her into writing him into her will and only giving her son a portion of it. My mom tried to tell him what she suspected was happening when we found out how he was visiting her alot. Anyway, my dad couldn't and wouldn't believe his son would basically try to steal his inheritance, but he did. Poor guy, betray by both his father and son. He really didn't deserve that. RIP pops..

¬†@artforz¬† I did pay attention. 1. He was still an adult. 2. They didn't steal it, the trustee is the LEGAL OWNER. My remarks still stand. Here's why. ¬†@Sam-yr8ls¬† well see that's the problem, it's who makes the claim that have to provide the source for it, just telling people to "google it" is not the proper way to make an argument. Especially since services like google are personalized so you and me will get quite different results from the same search.  E.g none of what I wrote I could find on google, I had to first find Alans linked in page where all of his previous businesses was listed and then do new searches based on that info.  The end result, weather you like it or not, is that people will believe that you just made things up when you tell them to "just google it" (because one could argue that for just about anything, from claiming the world being flat to pigs can fly) so it's also in your interest to provide some sources.  Please understand that this is me just explaining why "just google it" is bad, this is not an attempt of attacking you or anything.

I'm not going to say üíØ that it was disingenuous, but there were aspects that hinted towards it. Easily missed on a first viewing and also missed because they bicker incessantly. 1) She doesn't leap to Danny until his mother gets closer. Almost like she didn't want Danny to notice. 2) When the mother asks 'What do you want, Danny?' and Ramsays says it's a good question, Danny turns into a blubbering mess. The mother begins to ask the question again and the girlfriend asks the same question (it's very briefly shown). 3) she is obsessive over the money, not over Danny. Her arguments to the parents were not about Danny. They were about his money. 4) Going by number 1, it could be eluded to that she is maintaining the divide between the parents and Danny. Why would she do that? Because if, if, he got his money back, and he was still separated from his parents, then all the money would be theirs (more specifically hers because Danny is easily pushed around). I am from the city where Sewol victims are from - my house is less than 1 km from the Danwon Highschool, Ansan-si, where all the students belonged. Still remember it like yesterday. Friends lost their siblings, one of the victim's father committed suicide, and so on. But the most horrible thing I remember were the trucks that roamed around the city with loud microphone, saying "Losing your children are not something to brag about or plead justice to the government. Do not try to make a deal with the government with your already dead family, get over it, and shut your mouth about making commemorative space in the park. You victim families are disgrace to our society." I guarantee I heard this kind of truck-speeches until like 3 years ago. To be honest, I hate this country.

Advice I got from a very experienced sailor: If you're ever on a passenger ship and something seems wrong, the crew will always tell you to remain in place.  NEVER listen to them. Always put on your life jacket and go to the deck. Don't let anyone stop you. And if the ship is listing (i.e. leaning to one side), go to the side it's leaning toward, as in the side that's closer to the water. Because the lifeboats on the other side will be useless as they'll be hanging over the hull and likely to capsize if lowered.

South Korea's economy is the exact concept of techno-feudalism talked about by Yanis Varoufakis (Greek finance minister in 2015). He basically conceptualized that capitalism is long gone but we haven't realized it yet because economic shifts happen cross-generationally. He does a good job of pointing out how we, through our own human nature, reverted back to feudalism, where in which the government has become the lord (operating through subsidies), CEOs are the vassals, corporations are the fiefs, and employees are the serfs.

¬†@GameFuMaster¬† Genuinely a baffling statement to me. I mean I can see why it would look this way if you 'zoom in' to the last 10 years or so. But one only needs to take a glance at South Korea's rapid growth of monopoly and finance capital (especially for that region of the world) to see the hallmarks of US influence all over. South Korea being the only first world country east of the Persian gulf isn't a coincidence, it's a result of decades of US financial, cultural, military and economic interference.  The U.S.-backed dictators, starting with Syngman Rhee and later Park Chung-hee, facilitated the rise of chaebols by providing them with state resources, subsidies, and low-interest loans, as well as export licenses for shipping goods and raw materials out of Korea and into the U.S. directly, sidelining labour and democracy in the process, of course. This fact alone makes your statement utterly absurd. The opposition party used its majority state since 2024 March to pass laws to prevent its leader Lee Jae-Myung to go to prison, to impeach ministers and government officials who interfered with their agenda 26 times, to slash the government budgets, etc. to sabotage South Korea's government while increasing their own salary. The opposition party's goal is to align South Korea with China and North Korea by impeaching President Yoon who firmed up the security alliance with the U.S. and Japan since he became President. China and North Korea are behind the 'progressive' opposition party who has been engaged in relentless and ruthless propaganda, lies, fake news, misinformation, and disinformation campaign for decades. They are masters of using these tactics like Chinese Communist Party, North Korea, and Russia. They blamed President Park to be responsible for a ferry company's safety violations and packaged this incident as an impeachable offence and she was removed from Presidency by the Constitutional Court which was packed with the 'progressive' judges. They are using the same tactic. They packaged the short-lived martial law as an impeachable offence and passed the petition for impeachment of the Current President. They have used all kinds of sabotage tactics to stop the normal running of country for 2.5 years ever since they lost election in 2022. They've engaged in relentless, viscous, and ruthless propaganda campaign of fakes news, lies, disinformation and misinformation campaign against President Yoon, his government and his family. They impeached 26 ministers and government appointees in 2.5 years. Not sure if they succeeded because President Yoon removed his martial law declaration according the the request of Congress after 2 hours. 3) Historically, China considered themselves as the center nation in the world and Korea as one of its subordinates feudal states who were inferior to them. They are the products of how South Korea's past leadership relied on in order to mobilize its national resources to bring the nation out of poverty since 1960's. Korea's last king died in 1919 and Japan annexed Korea by force in 1910. Korea was under Japan's brutal and forceful occupation until 1945 and then the Korean War - - the proxy war between the U.S. / UN and China/Russia fought in Korean Peninsula - - broke in 1950. Comat ended with the Korean Armistice Agreement in 1953. 5) President Park Chung-Hee scraped non existing resources together from the war ravaged South Korea  - - wages sent home by Koreans worked as nurses and coal miners in West Germany, some international loans, smart and capable Korean business people - - and launched the miracle of Han River economic development. 6) This program's description of President Park Chung-Hee ruling by iron fist probably makes sense from perspectives of Westerners. This struggle has been on-going since 1945. ¬†@bronson4574¬† And to be fair, the North Korean situation isn't "all their fault". Keeping NK as a permanent threat is more in line with US strategic interests, since it provides a reason for continuous US military control of S. Korea and Japan. The fact that the Korean War could be reactivated is used as a threat to check the opponents and control the allies at the same time. There's a reason NK is made to be the designated villain, almost obsessed with, only in the West. The rest of the world is indifferent, to the extent there isn't gonna be a nuclear war in that region. To think in terms of geopolitical realism instead of ideological labels, NK doesn't have a choice, it is the way it is, a closed-off society, because of very real restraints it finds itself in. Hmm ‚Ä¶ consider me skeptical. Just got back from a cruise and the FIRST thing the crew did was a mandatory, all-hands emergency drill, where every passenger fetched their life vests (from their cabins), met on the central deck, and put the vests on. Furthermore, the lifeboats accommodated more than twice the ship‚Äôs capacity. And two of those lifeboats were the fully enclosed kind (like in  the movie ‚ÄúCaptain Phillips‚Äù). I agree with the premise of trust your gut if you feel unsafe‚Äîhead to the upper decks. But it must be a shady ship operator if being lied to and abandoned by the crew is a concern. Perhaps it‚Äôs once again a case of ‚Äúyou get what you pay for?‚Äù

People on the Costa Concordia survived by sitting on the far side of the ship, further away from the water. The ship never overturned and they were safe.
Passengers on Costa Concordia survived by sitting on the side further away from the water.  Not being stuck alone in your cabin sounds reasonable though.
¬†@thegreatimu¬† It's complicated.  Having a panicked mob running around IS dangerous, and will likely impede any efforts the crew might be making toward saving you.  That said, yeah, it could easily be too late.  It's one of those things where yeah, they're gonna say it, but you have to kind of make your own call on how to proceed.
Obviously, there is a spectrum. Good ships and crews will act accordingly. It's a myth that people always panic in a crisis, but it is universally believed. Apparently believed by your sailor friend, and probably other crew. Still, passengers usually don't know what to do! He was right that if the ship is listing the up-side boats are useless as the davits could be fouled and not able to lower boats. Rescue/emergency lifeboats are usually enclosed and will automatically roll "true" when capsised but rolling down the hull won't be any good for them! Of course if the ships capsises then those on the lower side are in real trouble if they are still aboard. People could sit on the upward hull of the Costa Concordia because it was on the bottom. It would not roll or sink any further, although they probably wouldn't know this.  Compare with the sinking of MV Queen of the North when it ran aground in 2006 in the middle of the night due to crew incompentence. Passengers were immediately instructed to proceed to muster stations but many went to the wrong deck (7 instead of 8) and did not take their lifejackets from their cabins. Crew repeatedly checked crew and passenger deck cabins to ensure they were cleared, but formal procedures were not followed (no chalk marks, organised plan, etc.) The Captain personally conducted the final cabin check. He and the crew boarded the last lifeboat when the evacuation was sounded as it was determined rescue would not arrive in time. Despite some confusion (there was no proper head count when passengers were mustered) 99 of 101 passengers were rescued (by a fleet of local Native fishermen from Hartley Bay First Nation). It is unclear what happened to the 2 that were lost.
¬†@ConfirmedCynic¬† I've seen reports of fully enclosed lifeboats jettisoned from the side away from the list and getting completely smashed to peices or badly holed. It's better than nothing if the list develops so quickly the other side's boats can't be launched but it's not good.

¬†@Shinkajo¬† it is, china is also capitalism but with dictatorship on top, both can coexist
@Shinkajo¬† Capitalism is a broad, almost slang term. Typically, capitalism is used to describe the laissez faire type of free market. When you consider the bureaucratic weaponization of subsidies, bailouts, permits, licenses, and fees, used to suppress small business competition for large corporations, as well as government overregulation which stifles growth, and creating a business landscape that favors the large corporations that line the pockets of politicians in the form of special interests, you now have something closer to either a command-control economy through bureaucracy, or this kind of amalgamation of technocracy and feudalism mention by Yanis. It's easy to just say "bah late-stage capitalism!", but really, our economy and our markets are no longer free, thus no longer qualify as capitalism. The closest type of capitalism to what we have is keynesian economics but since everyone who criticizes "capitalism", demands more government intervention, I don't think keynesian economics qualify as this ever-morphing term we call "capitalism".

I lived in South Korea for two years teaching, and I can't stress enough how much it is an open secret the chaebols are the ones really running the country. Literally, everyone I would talk to about this from young to old knew that the big families were untouchable. Honestly, even just working at one of these companies is seen as a big deal in Korea, because it is understood that there are many benefits besides compensation when you are working for these companies.   As an example, I had a friend in Korea who worked at Samsung, just a mid level position, but soon after joining the company he became close friends with the head of police in the town we were both living in, and whenever there was an issue with the law he would call his friend and then magically the problem would go away. This is just a small town example, so I can only imagine what the top guys are up to on a daily basis.   Edit for the people asking: During my time in Korea, I worked at 2 different Hagwons. The first was in a small town (of about 100,000, by Korean standards that is small) that I highly doubt anyone here would know by name, most Koreans  I talk to about it don't know about it. The second was at a major Hagwon in Seoul in the rich part of town, called Gangnam. I don't want to give the name because many celebrities' kids go to the school, but all you need to know is I met a lot of extremely rich people there. Like, several of my students' parents were CEOs, judges, politicians, etc.  Edit 2 for the people asking: I became friends with this Samsung employee because his younger brother was one of my students. At first, we would just chat in the lobby waiting for his brother. But over time we started hanging out outside of the school. Mostly because he wanted a foreigner friend to practice his English with, since he started going overseas often because of his new role at Samsung. Again, I am not 100% sure what his role was, we would just chat while drinking soju or eating food sometimes after work. That's all.  So for the people who are asking questions regarding his role, I genuinely don't know. And for people who think that is strange, I just want to say, I'm a guy, and like most guys I very rarely talk to my guy friends about their jobs. There are guy friends I have had for more then 10 years that I still do not 100% know what they do for work. All I know is that he told me he was in a "mid-level" position and that he was in charge of his own team. That's literally all I know, that and I believe he was in some aspect of promotion because I know he would go to different type of events around the world and around Korean fairly often. One time he got me into F1 for free when it was in Seoul because he had a booth there, and I was able to go behind the scenes. But that is literally all I know.

I remember watching the ferry disaster in real time. I honestly thought those kids were gonna be rescued. When they weren't the Vice Principle of their school hung himself on a tree down by the docks where the parents were waiting for news on the rescue.
It‚Äôs crazy how the people who were supposed to save them were taking a whole lunch break while watching the boat sink and the American navy were there offered to help, but they were rejected. The only people that helped were locals with boats and on top of that, the parents of children who died were told that their kids were still alive. What makes this case so bad is the fact that the boat not only sunk extremely slowly, but the government had so many opportunities to save them but chose not to.
There are videos of the drowning recorded by the school children.  ‚ÄúAre we going to die?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to die‚Ä¶‚Äù as the situation slowly becomes more and more real you can hear the fear begin to manifest. Absolutely horrifying. Heartbreaking and absurd.   It brings me to tears just thinking about it‚Ä¶ I strongly recommend against seeking it out. It‚Äôs one of those few things that I truly regret having seen.

I'm Korean. First of all, it was very interesting to shed light on the term chaebol that only exists in Korea. Even in Korea, there are views that are wary of the family management of chaebol and the harm caused by it. So expressing negative views on chaebol is not just new. However, it is very strange to link the Ferry Sewol incident with the chaebol. Ferry Sewol is a regrettable accident, but it is difficult to regard it as an accident caused by the widespread management of chaebol in Korea. The Ferry Sewol incident is more like a human disaster caused by the shipping company's complacent response and the government's insufficient rescue activities rather than related to the chaebol. I feel sorry for the students who died in the Sewol ferry disaster. However, I find this video somewhat far-fetched and find it difficult to agree.
The sad thing is, this doesn't even scratch the surface... especially regarding the Sewol tragedy, those involved, those complicit, and those who literally just stood by and allowed it to be worse than it needed to be. If anyone is ever in the need of a good cry, and doesn't mind never being the same again, I strongly urge them to watch a documentary or two on the Sewol disaster
What I learned about South-Korea by a good friend from Busan is that your "shell" is more important than your "core". Like... what kind of soul you have and how good you try to be as a human is just second to the general society standards... your looks, your skin, your eyes, your teeth etc. are more important - and also the prestige level of your education of course. How you shine to the world is number one priority. Most people don't even like that but everyone goes with the flow. On one side this attitude as a base made South-Korea to easily the cleanest and most modern industrial country in the world... it's not like in the USA, in Europe or even Southeast-Asia that you have loads of (teenager) crimes, problems with graffiti or stuff like that. You can sit, go and look everywhere without problems of safety or impurities - even big cities are clean, extremely well managed and maintained and you have the most modern technology for basically every area of ‚Äã‚Äãactivity. On the other side South-Korea is damned with the worldwide highest suicide rate, very bad mobbing statistics for schools, colleges and companies and a very critical rate of people in debth (because of trying to always have the most modern and expensive things, which is hard to do even when having a well paid job). Also the wide spread of plastic surgery and the public urge to change your visuals is extremely concerning, especially because it always stands in connection with the before mentioned mobbing, suicide rate etc. - and even high ranked employees are not immune to that. And all those high standards can be seen in every working field, every niche, all types of media and entertainment - K-POP f.e. is beside of the music a big, big act of this "false perfectionism". But in the end from what I've seen is that South-Koreans (especially the youngest generations) are getting more and more away from these insane society standards, but it's def. still a long journey. A beautiful country with so many smart people and a lot of values and things that I personally would def. love to see in the western world (at leats to a certain extend) - but nothing is perfect and the more a society is built on "perfectionism", the more problems are coming with that.
‚ÄúThe corpos built a system that feeds on human misery. They‚Äôll crush a city if it makes them a buck.‚Äù - Johnny Silverhand
This country has a strong academic society and lookism is widespread, and it is impossible for ordinary citizens to hold high positions unless they undergo plastic surgery or become highly educated.
It‚Äôs interesting how, in some countries, it‚Äôs easy to associate the faces and names of powerful individuals with the companies and crimes they are responsible for. In contrast, in the U.S., we often speak about corporations or institutions in abstract terms, without ever putting a face to those behind them. Companies like BlackRock, Vanguard, or Coca-Cola‚Äîand even powerful agencies like the FBI and CIA‚Äîfrequently make headlines, but the blame rarely extends to the individuals who drive their decisions. When wrongdoing occurs, the public hears the company‚Äôs name, but those truly responsible remain faceless and nameless. This disconnect allows accountability to vanish behind corporate logos and institutional titles, shielding the people at the top from personal scrutiny.

hi. I'm Korean living in Korea for my whole life. And I am working in Hyundai Motors Group. We Koreans say, regardless of the size of company we are working in, employees are nothing but slaves ,even though Samsung, Hyundai  offer more decent paycheck, there is still no difference about the fact that being employed by others will never be a way of being a rich since most of wealth has already accumulated to those who are rich, aka.Chaebol.  so it is not true at least that being a employee of some huge company like Samsung empowers you beyond the boundaries of law of cultural norms.  we, employees,  just regard each others as slaves of Chaebol. but most people take that fact because anyway the form of being hired is permanent in most case of Korea so that we can get a decent paycheck until we get 60 years old. It wasn't just the our Navy; it was also our Marines, specifically aboard the USS Bonhomme Richard.  And what's worse is that was no ordinary aircraft carrier, it was an amphibious assault ship.  Whilst an aircraft carrier is primarily a means of projecting air superiority and fighter aircraft, amphibious assault ships are a means of providing logistical support assets and troops.  These were sailors AND marines who were well trained to respond to emergencies, and they HAD the 31st MEU READY WITH RESCURE EQUIPMENT to rush to that Ferry.  Yes by then a large portion of the hull was below the water by this point but it is well believed that at least some or at least a small portion of the students may have been lucky to find small air pockets in the front of the bow sections where some of the water tight bulkheads resided, which nobody will deny was still worth effort.  And it wasn't just the US Navy and Marines that tried to help, the Japanese Coast Guard ALSO tried to offer sending rescue assets to assist, but were denied by S.K. officials to "wait for additional requests of assistance, if they needed them"  The ENTIRE time the S.K. Government had EVERY means to at least make a stronger attempt to save at least SOME of those aboard but felt it was more important to preserve the image of them being independent of foreign assistance.    304 souls aboard the Sewol that day, was the cost of this ego. It‚Äôs not one person or group in power in most big corporations. Counter example: Tesla and Elon musk. If Tesla were to do something to cause public outrage, it would specifically be aimed at Elon musk. Same goes for CEO owners, you just don‚Äôt hear about it as much because the big newsworthy companies all have shareholders (because taking investments is the fastest way to grow a company to that size).   As for agencies, the leaders also change, and even if we held the leaders personally accountable, people would just think they‚Äôre just using patsies as leaders and that we should punish the agency as a whole. Instead we just don‚Äôt punish anyone unfortunately.
even good ole TJ warned of banks and corporations yet the only thing people seem to want to do is head towards "solutions" that are inherently worse that "never been tried before" because it wasn't "real" that time around
In the western business model, responsability is shared by the company itself, by a board, by shareholders, by switching CEOs and what not, but even if they were held directly responsible for something they would never be punished like that. The S.Korean system is certainly extreme, but damn the sanctions are extreme too. 15 years for corruption, 5 served? Prison for bribes and the like? Sure, the pardons for the powerful are certainly convenient, but the original sentences are harsher than what some rapists and direct manslaughter gets you. Very corrupt, very controlling, but when caught, very harsh sanctions on a few. While probably a lot of others with some responsabilities get away. Then pardon, but still those served more than many in western countries would have.  I'm not saying one system is better or worse, but either way the rich and powerful just always gets away with much. Look at things like the Opioid crisis, the numbers make those Korean scandals look tame. It was clearly intentional and premeditated, clearly just for profit. Is anyone serving a day in prison? Hell no, it's the company that gets into a civil lawsuit for damages and fines, instead of a criminal trial. Then the family company just happens to go bankrupt without paying the damages, but somehow the family is still very rich. Fraud, withheld research, lobbying and disinformation leading to the death of many can be found in many sectors, like obviously the Tobacco industry back in the day, the Automobile industry, etc  It's all pretty dystopian if you look hard enough.

I've only been to Korea a handful of times, so I can‚Äôt say I know it inside out, but from an outsider's perspective, I wouldn‚Äôt call it dystopian‚Äîmore like depressing. Somewhere between all the technological and economic advancements, the old Joseon-Confucian mindset still lingers. People feel the need to maintain face through designer status symbols, there's this strong collectivist culture, and everyone seems to have FOMO. That‚Äôs probably why it comes off as "dystopian," but I think "depressin" is the word for it‚Äîthough people who live there (South korea) probably don‚Äôt see it that way. I grew up in the Italian towns and the Swiss Alps, so going to Korea is so damning different. I love the food, the beauty, and the tech, but I don‚Äôt feel the same warmth or community vibe I get back home.

Ï±ÖÏûÑÏûàÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ Ï§ë Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Ï≤òÎ≤å Î∞õÏùÄ ÏÇ¨Îûå ÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§ ÍµêÏàòÌòïÏùÑ Î∞õÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎèÑ ÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§ ÎªîÎªîÌïòÍ≤å ÏûòÏÇ¥Í≥† ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî
¬†@loopy-q1h¬† Haha, there seems to be a misunderstanding. Korean chaebols don‚Äôt directly participate in politics. In the 1990s, Hyundai's chairman Chung Ju-yung directly entered politics after democratization, forming his own party and running for president. However, he failed spectacularly and faced severe retaliation from the subsequent government. In the end, his son, Chung Se-young, had to go to the ruling party's headquarters, kneel, and beg for forgiveness.  Chaebols are not just ordinary corporations. These are companies that grew under the direct support and favor of the government, starting from the military regimes of the 1970s. Of course, the entrepreneurs worked hard themselves, but in return, they had to provide support to the regime‚Äîwhether publicly or privately.  And what happened if they ignored this relationship or displeased the government? They disappeared. In the 1980s, the Kukje Group, the 7th largest company in Korea at the time, was forcibly dismantled by the government. The shocking reason? They didn‚Äôt pay enough tribute to Chun Doo-hwan and his wife.  This is how the regime nurtured the chaebols, and the chaebols, in turn, paid their dues to the regime. And this relationship didn‚Äôt fundamentally change even after democratization‚Äîit just became somewhat less toxic.

‚Äã @HyunaTheHyena I moved to the Netherlands and it has been a really good improvement comparing it to the US. Not even close tbh. I feel safe here, as violent crime is rare. Mostly its just petty crime like bike theft etc. The quality of life is high, work life balance is good, people stay active and don't worry walking or biking home at night, but I am a guy, so its probably easier for me to say this. Healthcare is great too. Its not free, but insurrance is affordable and covers allot, especially for me coming from the US. Plus the care feels personal and they focus on prevention instead of trying to get as much money out of you as they can. No country is perfect, but the Netherlands is miles ahead in terms of quality of life than the US and I am way happier now than I ever was in the dystopian nightmare I lived through in the US.

¬†@Commander.Starfleet¬† It doesn't change the fundamental problem. Corporations have a motive to maximize profit, while governments ideally have a motive to serve their citizens. In both collective structures, partaking individuals are easily corrupted to serve their own motives (maximize personal wealth) over the interests of the collective. Since corporations are much more powerful than the government in Korea, they can corrupt the government to make structural changes that benefit the corporations, at the expense of the government's fundamental purpose of benefiting citizens. (It happens in other countries too, to varying degrees.) By making corporations more democratic, they would just have a different, more transparent and probably less efficient structure to pursue the same goal of maximizing profit.  Self-policing to enforce national law just won't work due to a fundamental conflict of interest: those people are paid by the corporation, and self-policing is in the way of making more money.

Dumb question: is ‚Äúferry‚Äù pronounced the same as ‚Äúfairy‚Äù? English was not my first language but I was always taught that berry, bury, and Barry are pronounced different lol was I taught wrong?
‚Äã¬†@CantTellYou¬†there is a difference but it ends up being very subtle and washed up in different kinds of accents. For example Australia and British accents place more difference between them but for where I'm from (america) the difference between "fairy" and "ferry" are indistinguishable
¬†@CantTellYou¬† Fairy is pronounced "Fair-ree" like "dairy" so there's an "r" sound at the end of the first syllable. Ferry is pronounced "feh-ree" like "berry" so no "r" at the end of the first syllable. Also "feh-ree" has a shorter first syllable. So fairy like dairy/hairy/Mary, ferry like berry/merry/cherry.
