I'm Korean. "If you get your shit together, you don't have to suffer from depression or anxiety" - that's what my mom told me all my life, being depressed herself for decades.
As a Korean reaching 60, I feel that one of the biggest problems with Korea's education system is the intense pressure placed on students. From age 5-6 to until 19, they are focused solely on entering one of the top universities (SKY). While doing so, almost everyone tells these kids that entering a good university will guarantee them a prosperous and happy life, with good money, a good job, and even success in dating. However, the reality is much different. Once they enter university, the competition continues ‚Äì to get into good companies, land well-paying jobs... it's an endless cycle of competition and comparison with friends, family members, colleagues, and neighbors. I believe this trend will continue for at least another 10-15 years, until the older generation retires. While Korea is in a transitional period, I fear things will get worse before they get better.  Instead of everyone striving to become "someone" special, we need to understand that it's okay to fail, to be average, and to simply be normal. Young people need to be freed from the constant pressure and unrealistic expectations imposed by parents, society, and the media.
I lived in Korea for a little over seven years, teaching for the EPIK Program. From my first year, I saw all the signs of a country emotionally and psychologically going downhill, and there were already issues with the younger generation being financially insecure. I did the best I could as an English teacher and told them that the best I can do is teach them English so that they would at least have one other choice to leave the country if they couldn't take it anymore. My time there was rough. There were a lot of great times, but it was mostly rough.
The Kpop group BTS released  a MV called N.O years ago about students and the harsh school system in Korea. It's well done and gives a voice to the youth. The leader of the group RM explained, that he was one of the top students in Korea but decided to be a rapper. His mom threw his computer and mic away because she wasn't pleased about his decision. And it's true. The people starts getting depressed in early age also because of the school system. They're taught to be always the best and to be the most successful. This is the most important thing for them. Another thing they're focused is the Korean beauty standarts. People that doesn't fit theses standarts are bullied or not successful no matter how good their grades are.
Despite putting in hard work and graduating from a university in Seoul, I felt defeated by the high barriers to employment, leading to the development of depression and anxiety, which I am currently undergoing treatment for. I watched the video with deep empathy as someone going through similar struggles.  While receiving psychiatric therapy, the disheartening view from my parents, perceiving me as a weak and disappointing individual, along with their harsh words, and the ongoing job failures, make each day of job preparation a struggle. I find myself lacking the motivation to continue, feeling helpless, and overwhelmed with thoughts of wanting to end my life.  Amidst this, I'm glad to have come across a video that explains these reasons. Although thoughts of suicide haven't completely vanished, the guilt of being deemed useless by society and achieving disappointing results has slightly lessened. Just realizing that my situation is, in fact, a societal responsibility provides significant comfort.
„Öã„Öã„Öã„ÖãÏ§ëÍ∞ÑÏóê Ï†ïÏã†Í≥º ÏùòÏÇ¨Îì§ ÏïÑÏù¥Ïä§ Î∏åÎ†àÏù¥ÌÇπ ÌïúÎãµÏãúÍ≥† Ïô∏Î™®ÌèâÍ∞ÄÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÌïòÍ≥†Î≥¥Îäî... ÏßÑÏßú ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÄ Ï†ÄÍ≤å Î¨∏Ï†úÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ï†ÄÎü∞Í≤ÉÎßå Í∑∏ÎßåÌï¥ÎèÑ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ ÏÇ¨ÎäîÎç∞ Ìõ®Ïî¨ ÌñâÎ≥µÌï¥ ÏßàÍ±∞ÏòàÏöî... Ïπ≠Ï∞¨ÌïúÍ±∞ÎãàÍπå Í¥úÏ∞ÆÎã§ Í∑∏Îü¥ÌÖêÎç∞ Ïô∏Î™®Ïπ≠Ï∞¨ÎèÑ ÏñºÌèâÏûÖÎãàÎã§..Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏïûÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÄ ÏùÄÍ∑ºÏä¨Ï©ç ÏöïÌñàÏûñÏïú„Öã„ÖãÏùåÏäµÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§..
This video is really amazing and so touching. I am Korean and I lived in another country for several years. My explanation to this emotional and mental crisis of Korea is a long lasting PTSD prevailing in the entire country, which is passing down several generations. As you said in the video, it started by Japanese colonization and Korean war. Everyone who survived, veterans, victims and their family and friends, was actually half way dead in the situation. There was no love, no friendship, no justice left, and they even laught at it when someone talks about things that don't make you survive. This might permanently damaged the brains of all of the people. Children grown up under those mentally injured parents learn the same traits, merciless competition and survival. I am the third generation after the war. My parents were not mentally healthy (for me to see), and that was because of the grandparents. My grand father was physically (and also mentally...) disabled, because he was sent to WWII and forced to work. Many of his neighbors and relatives couldn't come back. I was told that my grand father used to beat my grand mother a lot, and also the kids. At that time there was no word for PTSD, and he was seen as a normal person because everyone else was doing the same. I can say he was not mentally healthy based on current standards, but people like him was so many at that time. My fathers generation did enormous amount of hard work because they were living in the fear. 'Getting 100 or fail' kind of mindset is to survive in the fearful surrounding world. It is inherited PTSD. I say I am also affected. My family and friends are the same. I realized it when I interacted with American freinds, but Korean people in Korea just cannot recognize it. I agree with the Korean psychologist in the video. She said it is promising. I also see it is slowly being healed. The scar was made during about 40 years of period, but it will take much more time to cure, more than 100 years. We are half way there.

It is very arbitrary to simply attribute a complex social problem to the philosophical thought over 2,000 years agoÔºå and it's also difficult for you to hear an objective explanation of Eastern thought from a Western person who produces popular videos but does not study Confucianism. I offer another perspective. First, let me state my conclusion: I believe that this is basically a social problem caused by economic reasons. Eastern Asian societies have basically become industrial societies only in recent decades, before which they were mostly in a closed agricultural civilization society. Confucian thought (here we are talking about the Confucian thought that has been castrated by the ruling class, and we will discuss it later) ran smoothly, and then they all encountered colonial aggression, which was the first collision between industrial civilization and agricultural civilization, as well as the collision between Eastern and Western cultures. The historical trend began to diverge from this point.  When Westerners colonized all over the world, there was no Internet, and there were almost no newspapers in the vast number of colonized countries. At that time, Western newspapers basically did not talk about condemnation of colonial behavior, oppression of women and minority groups, but which colony had wealth and gold. However, when Eastern Asian countries began to develop industrial civilization, the whole world was no longer in the colonial era. You could no longer get the first bucket of gold through plundering to allow future generations to live a high-welfare free life. So how could everyone have a good modern life? It is nothing more than through the initial efforts of one or even several generations, inventing new technologies and improving production efficiency. Therefore, this is basically a phenomenon of the dislocation of the development stages of Eastern and Western societies. Unfortunately, the life of an individual is too short in the context of history and too small in a society, without a God's perspective.  The original Confucianism indeed had a concept of hierarchy and emphasized rules, but this hierarchy was equivalent, that kind of absolute obedience of subordinates to superiors is just the Confucianism castrated by the ruling class later. I believe that this approach is almost similar to the Western establishment of Christianity as the orthodox ideology, just for the convenience of ruling. This topic is too long. Interestingly, Confucianism also has a thought that "‰ªìÂª™ÂÆûËÄåÁü•Á§ºËäÇ,Ë°£È£üË∂≥ËÄåÁü•Ëç£Ëæ±"(when the granaries are full, people know etiquette; when they have enough food and clothing, they know honor and disgrace), which coincides with the phenomenon that the West today, after being abundant in materials, knows the crimes of the colonial period and begins to criticize them.

Then, how many slaves made up of the total population in Joseon? "Academics estimate that about 40 percent of the Joseon population was about 10 million, or about 4 million slaves." Han Myeong-hoe, a famous minister in the early Joseon Dynasty, said, "One million of the public slaves are on the run."  So there was even a state agency called Jang ÊéåÈö∑, which was in charge of arresting slaves or litigating slaves. In the Gyeongguk ÂÖ∏, which was created during the reign of King Seongjong, "One Ë≥§ÂâáË≥§ is confirmed. In other words, the law stipulates that if one of the parents is a slave, the child becomes a slave as well."   What is the basis for Western researchers to treat slaves during the Joseon Dynasty as slaves?  "The most important rationale is that slaves during the Joseon Dynasty were sold, given, and inherited. In other words, slaves were treated like objects."   The Joseon Dynasty was an unprecedented country where its relatives were enslaved. According to the Annals of the Joseon Dynasty, half of the Japanese soldiers during the Japanese Invasion of Korea in 1592 were Joseon people, and in the Annals of the Joseon Dynasty, there is a record that it is worrisome that the people welcomed the Japanese soldiers rather than the Japanese soldiers.  Thanks to Yi Sun-shin, the Joseon people suffered from slavery for another 400 years.   Joseon was a poorest country in the 19th century, that is, 500 years after its foundation, it was only able to keep up with the economic power and production of Goryeo in the 13th century. "How can a country [Joseon] be so poor in this world? It is similar to a woman's poor house, so it is not easy to run a single progressive (Èé≠Â†°). I was very rich in the early days of Goryeo, but I don't know why our country is so poor."  „ÄéThe Annals of Seonjo„Äè as of September 28, 38   Korean history from Gojoseon to Japan.  Sugihara, a professor who published "Japan's Bronze Age from Korea," said, "The Bronze Age came to Japan from 100 BC to AD50, the end of Korean Bronze Age society. In Japan, the Iron Age and the Bronze Age were handed down at the same time during the Yayoi period, and the Bronze Age was only used for ancestral rites, so it seems that it went straight to the Iron Age without going through the Bronze Age."  Around 100 BC ‚Äì Ancient civilization began in Japan when Koreans landed with iron weapons in Japan, where primitive people in the Stone Age lived. Japanese history is the history of the Gaya Baekje Kingdom and the history of the Korean people   "High-tech science has proven historical truths that no one has ever told you. In other words, Koreans moved to Japan and founded the ancient civilization of Japan. Although traces of the Yayoi civilization, which ended Japan's primitive era and opened up an ancient society, appear throughout the Japanese mainland, it is widely accepted as orthodox that it originated in the northern part of Kyushu by the descendants. The study made it clear that the Yayoi people are descendants of people from the southern part of the Korean Peninsula."   The Chinese Han Chinese, along with Vietnam, were grouped in a different lineage, showing genetic differences from Koreans.  O2b: This type can be said to be the core of Koreans' unique Y chromosome. It accounts for 37.3 percent of Koreans, but is rarely found in China. O2b is mainly distributed in Japan (31.9 percent) and Manchu (3.8 percent) outside of the Korean Peninsula, so O2b can be said to be a unique gene of Koreans and Japanese people   "Chinese are cockroaches in the shape of humans"  - Hideki Tojo (Prime Minister of the Cabinet) -  Asked by a reporter, "Do you have any plans to incorporate Chinese into imperial citizens like Joseon?"   At the time of the annexation of Korea and Japan, the Japanese ruling class thought they were unified and granted equal rights to Koreans through an internal integration policy. In addition, a huge amount of 30 percent of Japan's total budget was poured every year for the modernization of Joseon.¬†  There were many complaints from the Japanese at the time about the exploitation of Niigata rice to Joseon because of the lack of rice in Joseon.  The lives of Koreans have become so abundant that the population, which had remained at the level of 10 million without population growth for 600 years during the Joseon Dynasty, doubled during the Japanese colonial era.  "During the colonial period, Joseon's population grew by 12.6 million people, about 69 percent of whom, 8.7 million, were within the Korean Peninsula and 31 percent were flown to Manchuria and Japan."   There were more Japanese in Japanese Military Sexual Slavery. Japanese Military Sexual Slavery was a legitimate job that featured advertisements for Japanese Military Sexual Slaverys in newspapers. Pay and Japanese Koreans were equally paid more than Chinese. Forced labor was also much more Japanese, and it was a high-wage job with higher pay than doctors.  "The wages of Korean coal mine workers were 3.7 times higher than that of Japanese soldiers."   The independent army (Koreans who lived in Manchuria refer to them as the Marjeokdan) that was active in Manchuria was the Northeast Anti-Japanese Alliance, a partisan force under the Chinese Communist Party. As a coalition of the Korean Independence Army and the Chinese Ho-gun, many of them were communists who acquired Chinese nationality, and 339 of them were independence forces in association with the Chinese Communist Party.  On the other hand, at the end of World War II, there were more than 800,000 Korean Japanese military applicants, and the competition rate for enlistment exceeded 62:1. You can see how Koreans perceived Japan at that time   If Japan lost the Russo-Japanese War, all Koreans would be forced to move to Siberia and are now logging.  Both Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries are grateful to Japan. Malaysia's prime minister said he shed tears of joy as he watched British troops being driven away by Japanese troops, and Indonesia still pays tribute to Japanese soldiers every year. China and Korea are the only anti-Japanese countries in the world.   For the future of the Korean people, the Korea-Japan alliance should be strengthened and ultimately merged. The most feared thing among the pro-Chinese is the Korea-Japan alliance.   The north of the Great Wall was not Chinese territory. It was ruled by Mongols, Manchurians, and Koreans. Qin Shi Huang built the Great Wall to block the so-called Northern Orangkai. Later, China was conquered by the Jin Dynasty and Mongolia, founded by descendants of the god line Kim Ham-bo, and ruled by the Manchurians for 300 years after the Qing Dynasty. Manchurian Yuanryu Go (ÊªøÊ¥≤Ê∫êÊµÅËÄÉ), compiled during the Qianlong Emperor of the Qing Dynasty, also identifies the origin of the founder of the Golden Dynasty as Silla, and the national title of the Golden Dynasty also reveals that his surname originated from the last name of the Silla king.   The Gojoseon civilization predates the Yellow River civilization in China by 1,500 years. "The Gojoseon civilization, which appeared 5,000 years ago, was the third ancient civilization in the world after the Mesopotamian civilization (5,500 years ago) and the Egyptian civilization (5,100 years ago). It comprehensively summarizes the origins and birth of Gojoseon civilization, socioeconomic foundations and cultural characteristics, and the foundation, development, and dismantling of ancient countries."  About 12,000 years ago, when the ice age ended, people who started farming on the ancient Korean Peninsula below the 40th degree north latitude succeeded in cultivating rice and beans for the first time in the world. As a result of the Neolithic Agricultural Revolution, the number of groups living in the Namhangang and Geumgang basins increased significantly, and some of them moved to the north, where agriculture became possible. Those who were located in the east of the Liao River became Yejok (ÊøäÊóè), where tigers were totems, and those who crossed the west of the Liao River became Mac (Êóè), where bears were totems.  Professor Shin argues that Gojoseon moved its capital to Liaodong 1,000 years later to absorb the Yejok, and expanded its territory east-west to build an ancient federal state spanning the Korean Peninsula, Manchuria, and coastal states.  He said, "The Korean, Ye, and Macs that led to the Korean people formed the center of Gojoseon, and nomadic peoples that were conquered and annexed, such as Eupru, Hun, Dolgol, and Mongolia, were surrounded."   The reason why Chinese scholars deny Gojoseon civilization is that Gojoseon civilization shakes the fabricated Chinese history by taking root
Don't use the word experiment loosely; it's a strict word that can be used when a number of conditions are met. What you did just looks like fun and it doesn't look serious.
When you use the word experiment, it's only when you follow a very strict set of rules.

¬†@tyyg9469¬† I guess it depends on how you define "dominating in the arts," but if you are talking about so-called K-pops or K-dramas, I would like to mention (although very carefully) that those are not creations based on self-expression. These are nothing more than mass-produced commodities invested by gigantic corporations like Samsung smartphones. It's an outcome of extreme efficiency in capitalism, not a masterpiece of fine arts. This means art is only valued if it makes proper profits in Korea.
¬†@tyyg9469¬† In addition, as Mark has already replied, there's a significant difference between a few artists and the rest of the people. Generally speaking, South Korea is not an ideal country to allow its citizens to express themselves freely in public. That's the reality, even though all those quasi-fabulous-looking K-culture distracts you.

In the ancient Korea (ChaoxianÊúùÈÆÆ , Real historical name - Chinese territory before 1910). It was two different ethnic groups. 1.Chinese (Han Ethnic)(Wear color and pattern clothes) - Ruler and nobleman  2. Korean (White Clothes Ethnic)( Wear white clothes without pattern) - Civilians and slaves    1. Ruler and nobleman (Goguryeo , Baekje, Silla , Goryeo, Joseon=ChaoxianÊúùÈÆÆ ..): Chinese local officials and nobles (royal members, monks, scholars, soldiers, architects, technicians, and their families ...). They are Chinese (Han) and their descendants born in the local area. They have always wore China in China costumes. They speak Chinese language (official and Han dialect) and Chinese characters. They are Chinese officials and represent the Chinese emperor's governance of the ancient Korean Peninsula (ÊúùÈÆÆ). Local Chinese officials (Chaoxian kingÊúùÈÆÆÁéã)  and Chinese nobles in ancient Korea (Chaoxian ÊúùÈÆÆ-Chinese territory). They all Chinese clothes (hanfu), headdress (hat and crown), silk cloth (including embroidery), soldiers (such as: defensive clothing, horses). Weapons (including cannons), Chinese literature books (including Chinese history, Taoism Buddhism), Chinese special architectural materials (including palaces and design paintings). Food materials (Chinese food and Chinese royal food), wooden wheels used, large military ships, etc. are made from other cities in China).  Among them, the Chinese royal's (Chaoxian king /officials and nobles) Hanfu comes from Chinese han clothes, opera clothing, and hat crown headwear. Therefore, the fabric on the clothes is high -level. There are a large number of Chinese official dragon patterns and various traditional Chinese patterns (including Chinese characters) on the clothes.    2. Civilians and slaves (Goryeo, Joseon=ChaoxianÊúùÈÆÆ ..only appeared in history after the 13th century): Civilians and slaves are indigenous Koreans (White Clothes EthnicÁôΩË°£Ê∞ëÊóè). They speak Korean language. Long -term banned learning and use of Chinese characters Êº¢Â≠ó(except a few descendants of mixed with Chinese people).  Korean people cannot use any pattern of Chinese imperial power. Èæçdragon and È≥Øphoenix. In ancient times, this was a beheading and destroyer. * Chinese patterns and Dragon's totem represents the symbol of the ancient Chinese and Chinese power. Korean people cannot use any pattern of Chinese imperial power. Èæçdragon and È≥Øphoenix. Only the Chinese royal family and senior officers can use it. If the  "White clothes Ethnic ÁôΩË°£Ê∞ëÊóè" (today's ancestors of Koreans) use the pattern of dragon and use Chinese characters. They will destroy the tribe and beheaded.  Korean charactersÈüìÂ≠ó are text used by slaves.  Ancient Korean can only use  Korean characters (after the 15th century. Chinese officials - Chaoxian king  and Chinese scholars who settled on the ChaoxianÊúùÈÆÆ . Chinese officials use Chinese characters and Korean language  to create "Korean charactersÈüìÂ≠ó ".) for slaves.  These low Korean soldiers are used to protect the Chaoxian Peninsula ÊúùÈÆÆÂçäÂ≥∂(Chinese territory) to prevent Japanese pirates from invasion. In ancient Korea (ChaoxianÊúùÈÆÆ ) does not have any technologies and processes such as metal , Bend the wood and dye embroidery patterns. Most Korean men became low -level soldiers in the Chinese army (under the command of Chinese officers). There is no armor. Korean only wear pure white clothes and korean women's clothing is exposed nipples (Hanbok - Features of traditional Korean clothes).Westerners Record photos.  All Korean women use their heads to move anything (similar to other primitive tribal culture). Korean houses are cottage built with grass (only Chinese can live in Chinese palaces and temples). Korean people earn food in the market concentrated on exchanging items. They do not have any coins and any metal things. South Korea's national culture and tools for use are very primitive.    Writing history is the tradition and habit of the ancient Chinese official . The history of the ancient Korean Peninsula was written by classical Chinese. This was read for the Chinese and must be approved for the Chinese emperor. Of course, as a Korean, I have also lived under stress, but thanks to the efforts of my parents, my elders, and myself, in a short period of time, Korea has been able to become the developed country it is today, from the ruins after the Korean War, and you foreigners are enjoying it, and on the other hand, you are surprised and jealous, and you are going crazy wondering why, what was the reason...? In Korea, where there were no resources, three million people died in the war, and almost all the facilities were destroyed. There were only people left and the only thing to do was to educate them. Foreigners only know Korea as it is now because they haven't learnt Eastern history, but the Korean peninsula has already perfected its education system over 5,000 years. If you don't study Korean history, you have no idea what the intensity of this is, so our parents' generation, even if they starved themselves, gave their children intense education to produce a high-quality, high-quality workforce, and the people who became intelligent because of this produced a democratic uprising to get rid of the military dictatorship. Stress? Suicide? It's a double-edged sword. An Infamous goverment propaganda must have gotten you as well but us young generations already found out how a post war propaganda maybe associated with the north went and figured out why many if our great grandparents used to say the days under Japan was better than before under our own rulers.   Here's one of many writings that describe how it was before and after Japan. Former US President Herbert Hoover wrote: ‚ÄúI first visited Korea in 1909, to advise some Japanese industrialists on engineering matters. The Korean people at that time were in the most disheartening condition that I had witnessed in any part of Asia. There was little law and order. The masses were underfed, under-clothed, under housed and under equipped. There was no sanitation, and filth and squalor enveloped the whole countryside. The roads were hardly passable, and there were scant communication or educational facilities. Scarcely a tree broke the dismal landscape. Thieves and bandits seemed to be unrestrained.  During the thirty-five years of Japanese control, the life of the Korean people was revolutionized. Beginning with this most unpromising human material, the Japanese established order, built harbors, railways, roads and communications, good public buildings, and greatly improved housing. They established sanitation and taught better methods of agriculture. They built immense fertilizer factories in North Korea which lifted the people‚Äôs food supplies to reasonable levels. They reforested the bleak hills. They established a general system of education and the development of skills. Even dusty, drab and filthy clothing had been replaced with clean bright colors.‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúFreedom Betrayed‚Äù (1965) „ÄÄ  There are lots of testimony by former presidents and university professors as well

¬†@bernkbestgirl¬† u say that India is much happier than SK, i think it's bcz of poverty. In China, there is a popular joke on the Internet, "poverty limits imagination", which means that something exceeds your imagination. When someone is poor, there are fewer options available. On the one hand, it will reduce desires, and on the other hand, a little improvement will be very satisfying. For example, when you are extremely hungry, you will not want a Michelin meal. Instead, a piece of bread made from inferior flour will easily make you feel full. Another example is that when you are in the desert for a long time, you will not want tea or coffee. Just a little water will make you feel no longer thirsty. I also think that's why some people in China now  even miss the era decades ago when material resources were scarce but class struggle was fierce. At that time, there was not a big gap between people, and material resources were generally scarce. There was neither jealousy brought about by comparison nor desires beyond imagination, so everyone felt very happy.

Then, how many slaves made up of the total population in Joseon? "Academics estimate that about 40 percent of the Joseon population was about 10 million, or about 4 million slaves." Han Myeong-hoe, a famous minister in the early Joseon Dynasty, said, "One million of the public slaves are on the run."  So there was even a state agency called Jang ÊéåÈö∑, which was in charge of arresting slaves or litigating slaves. In the Gyeongguk ÂÖ∏, which was created during the reign of King Seongjong, "One Ë≥§ÂâáË≥§ is confirmed. In other words, the law stipulates that if one of the parents is a slave, the child becomes a slave as well."   What is the basis for Western researchers to treat slaves during the Joseon Dynasty as slaves?  "The most important rationale is that slaves during the Joseon Dynasty were sold, given, and inherited. In other words, slaves were treated like objects."   The Joseon Dynasty was an unprecedented country where its relatives were enslaved. According to the Annals of the Joseon Dynasty, half of the Japanese soldiers during the Japanese Invasion of Korea in 1592 were Joseon people, and in the Annals of the Joseon Dynasty, there is a record that it is worrisome that the people welcomed the Japanese soldiers rather than the Japanese soldiers.  Thanks to Yi Sun-shin, the Joseon people suffered from slavery for another 400 years.   Joseon was a poorest country in the 19th century, that is, 500 years after its foundation, it was only able to keep up with the economic power and production of Goryeo in the 13th century. "How can a country [Joseon] be so poor in this world? It is similar to a woman's poor house, so it is not easy to run a single progressive (Èé≠Â†°). I was very rich in the early days of Goryeo, but I don't know why our country is so poor."  „ÄéThe Annals of Seonjo„Äè as of September 28, 38   Korean history from Gojoseon to Japan.  Sugihara, a professor who published "Japan's Bronze Age from Korea," said, "The Bronze Age came to Japan from 100 BC to AD50, the end of Korean Bronze Age society. In Japan, the Iron Age and the Bronze Age were handed down at the same time during the Yayoi period, and the Bronze Age was only used for ancestral rites, so it seems that it went straight to the Iron Age without going through the Bronze Age."  Around 100 BC ‚Äì Ancient civilization began in Japan when Koreans landed with iron weapons in Japan, where primitive people in the Stone Age lived. Japanese history is the history of the Gaya Baekje Kingdom and the history of the Korean people   "High-tech science has proven historical truths that no one has ever told you. In other words, Koreans moved to Japan and founded the ancient civilization of Japan. Although traces of the Yayoi civilization, which ended Japan's primitive era and opened up an ancient society, appear throughout the Japanese mainland, it is widely accepted as orthodox that it originated in the northern part of Kyushu by the descendants. The study made it clear that the Yayoi people are descendants of people from the southern part of the Korean Peninsula."   The Chinese Han Chinese, along with Vietnam, were grouped in a different lineage, showing genetic differences from Koreans.  O2b: This type can be said to be the core of Koreans' unique Y chromosome. It accounts for 37.3 percent of Koreans, but is rarely found in China. O2b is mainly distributed in Japan (31.9 percent) and Manchu (3.8 percent) outside of the Korean Peninsula, so O2b can be said to be a unique gene of Koreans and Japanese people   "Chinese are cockroaches in the shape of humans"  - Hideki Tojo (Prime Minister of the Cabinet) -  Asked by a reporter, "Do you have any plans to incorporate Chinese into imperial citizens like Joseon?"   At the time of the annexation of Korea and Japan, the Japanese ruling class thought they were unified and granted equal rights to Koreans through an internal integration policy. In addition, a huge amount of 30 percent of Japan's total budget was poured every year for the modernization of Joseon.¬†  There were many complaints from the Japanese at the time about the exploitation of Niigata rice to Joseon because of the lack of rice in Joseon.  The lives of Koreans have become so abundant that the population, which had remained at the level of 10 million without population growth for 600 years during the Joseon Dynasty, doubled during the Japanese colonial era.  "During the colonial period, Joseon's population grew by 12.6 million people, about 69 percent of whom, 8.7 million, were within the Korean Peninsula and 31 percent were flown to Manchuria and Japan."   There were more Japanese in Japanese Military Sexual Slavery. Japanese Military Sexual Slavery was a legitimate job that featured advertisements for Japanese Military Sexual Slaverys in newspapers. Pay and Japanese Koreans were equally paid more than Chinese. Forced labor was also much more Japanese, and it was a high-wage job with higher pay than doctors.  "The wages of Korean coal mine workers were 3.7 times higher than that of Japanese soldiers."   The independent army (Koreans who lived in Manchuria refer to them as the Marjeokdan) that was active in Manchuria was the Northeast Anti-Japanese Alliance, a partisan force under the Chinese Communist Party. As a coalition of the Korean Independence Army and the Chinese Ho-gun, many of them were communists who acquired Chinese nationality, and 339 of them were independence forces in association with the Chinese Communist Party.  On the other hand, at the end of World War II, there were more than 800,000 Korean Japanese military applicants, and the competition rate for enlistment exceeded 62:1. You can see how Koreans perceived Japan at that time   If Japan lost the Russo-Japanese War, all Koreans would be forced to move to Siberia and are now logging.  Both Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries are grateful to Japan. Malaysia's prime minister said he shed tears of joy as he watched British troops being driven away by Japanese troops, and Indonesia still pays tribute to Japanese soldiers every year. China and Korea are the only anti-Japanese countries in the world.   For the future of the Korean people, the Korea-Japan alliance should be strengthened and ultimately merged. The most feared thing among the pro-Chinese is the Korea-Japan alliance.   The north of the Great Wall was not Chinese territory. It was ruled by Mongols, Manchurians, and Koreans. Qin Shi Huang built the Great Wall to block the so-called Northern Orangkai. Later, China was conquered by the Jin Dynasty and Mongolia, founded by descendants of the god line Kim Ham-bo, and ruled by the Manchurians for 300 years after the Qing Dynasty. Manchurian Yuanryu Go (ÊªøÊ¥≤Ê∫êÊµÅËÄÉ), compiled during the Qianlong Emperor of the Qing Dynasty, also identifies the origin of the founder of the Golden Dynasty as Silla, and the national title of the Golden Dynasty also reveals that his surname originated from the last name of the Silla king.   The Gojoseon civilization predates the Yellow River civilization in China by 1,500 years. "The Gojoseon civilization, which appeared 5,000 years ago, was the third ancient civilization in the world after the Mesopotamian civilization (5,500 years ago) and the Egyptian civilization (5,100 years ago). It comprehensively summarizes the origins and birth of Gojoseon civilization, socioeconomic foundations and cultural characteristics, and the foundation, development, and dismantling of ancient countries."  About 12,000 years ago, when the ice age ended, people who started farming on the ancient Korean Peninsula below the 40th degree north latitude succeeded in cultivating rice and beans for the first time in the world. As a result of the Neolithic Agricultural Revolution, the number of groups living in the Namhangang and Geumgang basins increased significantly, and some of them moved to the north, where agriculture became possible. Those who were located in the east of the Liao River became Yejok (ÊøäÊóè), where tigers were totems, and those who crossed the west of the Liao River became Mac (Êóè), where bears were totems.  Professor Shin argues that Gojoseon moved its capital to Liaodong 1,000 years later to absorb the Yejok, and expanded its territory east-west to build an ancient federal state spanning the Korean Peninsula, Manchuria, and coastal states.  He said, "The Korean, Ye, and Macs that led to the Korean people formed the center of Gojoseon, and nomadic peoples that were conquered and annexed, such as Eupru, Hun, Dolgol, and Mongolia, were surrounded."   The reason why Chinese scholars deny Gojoseon civilization is that Gojoseon civilization shakes the fabricated Chinese history by taking root

I would call it Confutalism. Yup, it sounds futile and fatal.
Confucianism with a bad attitude rather than a good one! In Confucianism, society should be peaceful. You obey your older siblings, parents and boss. Everyone reveres the ruler. In return, they are supposed to look after you. The ideal is to be led by good rulers and bosses, whom the people will obey easily. The problem is that in South Korea, bosses are often bad. Yet the workers still have to obey. I have been criticised and yelled at by Confucianist Korean bosses. They have illegally withheld benefits like pension and health insurance. They have changed the rules at a moments' notice. In Confucianist Korea you can be fired illegally, even if you have gone past the probation period. Bosses are more likely to break the law.

There was a Korean child, about 12 years old, in my English evening class in South Korea. The Korean manager, when I inquired if the child's health was okay, proudly told me "He is the #1 student, academically in his school!" (his 9 to 5 school, public school). In my class, over months, I FREQUENTLY saw him nearly collapsing, struggling to keep his eyes open and head upright. He appeared on the verge of lapsing into a coma!! I felt tremendous sympathy for him, and said a few silent non-denominational prayers for him, and hoped, against odds, that his health, physical and psychological, could withstand the barrage of classes that he barely endured.

I'm not Korean, but my mom used to tell me that I was sad (I've always had depression) because I wasn't busy and had time/luxury to think about my feelings. As a kid, I thought deeply about it and figured she didn‚Äôt know better because my grandparents were farmers and worked hard their whole lives. We didn't discuss anything, but in the back of my mind, I thought of the best ways to care for myself and my sanity. As for her, I think she worked herself into an early grave. I noticed she had her own mental health struggles, but she hid them well, along with her breast cancer, which we didn‚Äôt know about until it was too late. She kept working and moving, only stopping when she had to sleep.  Watching her and other family members, I promised myself I‚Äôd be happy when I grew up. Now, in my weaker moments, when I compare myself to others, I sometimes wish I had bigger goals than just being happy - maybe I‚Äôd be richer or further along in my career. But honestly? I think I‚Äôm in a really good place, where I‚Äôm reasonably happy and content, even while managing my depression.

Yes but if you fail, it will be much harder to participate in Korea‚Äôs ‚Äòeconomic miracle‚Äô and develop a career in the Chaebol‚Äôs, in Western level jobs, earning Western level salaries.  All the markets, small mom and pop stores alluded to in this video serve Korea‚Äôs ‚Äòunderclass‚Äô of people who live middle income lifestyles, akin to those in much poorer countries like Mexico.  This contrast is much starker than in the West.  In the UK, you can earn middle professional manager salaries by learning a trade, like being a plumber.  That isn‚Äôt the case in Korea, you‚Äôd earn far less.  A professional outside a Chaebol would earn maybe a half to two thirds what the same person doing the same job inside a Chaebol would, the tradesman even less than that.
Plus traditionally in Confucian culture, your status in society determined how the laws applied to you.  There was no concept of universal human rights, it was not a dignity culture where each person had ‚Äòworth‚Äô protected in law regardless of who they were or what they did. Park Jung Hee realised a system like this wouldn‚Äôt sustain a modern industrialised society, so copied Western legal systems to encourage industry.  However, these institutions became an overlay on old Confucian feudal legal systems and their values sustained in culture.  Witness what happens to Chaebol leaders who fall foul of the law.  Prosecuted under the Western legal overlay, then pardoned by the President, because their status makes them above the law.  Status pays, opens doors, determines who you can associate with, which is important  in a 2 speed society dominated by Chaebols.   Sure this sort of thing exists everywhere but its really exaggerated in Korea compared to the West.  You can‚Äôt understand modern Korea without understanding the Chaebol system, there are interesting video‚Äôs on youtube about this.

It is fundamentally due to scarcity of resources. Crowded people should have competed with each other for limited resources in the small territory. Only one solution to this is reunification. The situation you described is almost the same in China, Im Chinese and I used to study in UK for 5 years. Met friends from different cultures such as Korean, Jpanese and Indian. I feel like we have the same nervous, anxiety, pressure towards future.
It‚Äôs the same in the USA. I am constantly asked by parents what their 5-year old can do to increase their chances of  getting into an Ivy League. I interview students who have devoted their life to curating a resume that will appeal to the admissions team. Many believe that if they don‚Äôt attend Harvard or Yale, they‚Äôre doomed - as if these schools came w/ a guarantee for success and happiness. The focus needs to shift. The real issue is creating an economy that values all contributors and affords everyone at least a living wage.
But the reality is that there are only so many of those top positions, so many if not most will feel like they failed, or were lied to. Maybe both. Economies only have so much demand for high paying white collar jobs.
Malaysia is very similar. Too much focus in class rankings while in secondary school. Imagine from 13 to 18 in a batch of 100+ plus yearly students, you are regularly ranked close to the last places. What does that kind of shame and embarassment do throughout young people's lives? Mental health issues naturally emerge in epidemic levels.

I personally don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs just the education system. Hyper-competitive education system is not uncommon in Asian countries, like in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, India, etc. Also, the Korean education system has always been competitive, and the Korean culture always emphasized getting into prestigious universities, and scoring higher than all their peers for decades and decades.   But today, the suicide rate is higher than ever, the birth rate is lower than ever. It has been like this only the last ten years or so that South Koreans started calling the country ‚ÄúHell Joseon‚Äù and today‚Äôs ‚ÄúMZ generation‚Äù is more miserable than ever.

I have some Korean friends, also one of my cousins marries to Korean guy and live in Busan now.  My cousin mentions that when she meets someone for the first time, she is always asked which school did she graduate or where her husband works.  I was not surprised to hear that because many Koreans ask me about my academic background and the company name on the first meeting. It makes us feel like we are evaluated or compared.  Also, I imagined this could happen any time if you live in Korea.  That might make you feel that you have to graduate from SKY or have to work at investment banks or conglomerates. I am sorry to tell you these, but assume that Koreans need to quit the habit to evaluate others based on status or school.

Not Asian but the best thing my parents did was accept any grade from me that wasn't failing (I was a highly gifted kid anyways, but didn't get A's in any subject I disliked). You (Koreans) have bi-lateral visa programs with many Western nations; leave Korea and return only for the holidays if you have to. It's not worth ending your life over a temporary situation you find yourself in when you have the power to exist and thrive somewhere else. You seem to have a good command of English so you're already halfway there.
Please, consider moving to a western country which may value your skills and have more freedom! I know we need our family and depression for being away from them is also dangerous but the way it's going for you there seems to be even worse. Please don't give up. Life can throw surprises at you and the world you see is not all there is. It is completely possibly for life to suddenly transition into something more fruitful. I hope you will find that there are more people who understand and accept you than you think. When I moved to a different country, I found that the ideals in one country were completely flopped in the other country. People's opinions of you can change all the time. On one day, good, and on another day, bad. Their opinions, however, don't change your worth. And you are worth more than your career success.  One may have qualities that the other lacks, and the same person will lack qualities that the other person has. Don't underestimate yourself!! You'll get to where you need to be.
Try to travel, try to go to a 3rd world country, what you will see, learn and live will definitely give you a new view of life.
It is so difficult when your parents don't understand and just add to the heavy emotional burden you carry. If at all possible, find or create a support group of others who are courageously facing up to their mental health, even two or three others, to meet regularly to encourage each other and listen to each other with compassion and understanding. Creating a new network of support can really help compensate for the lack of support in your natural network. I send you the warmest wishes from Canada, and the biggest hugs (we are big on hugging here, it's good for our mental health, lol!)! I also want you to know, as someone who has suffered from severe depression myself, that putting one foot in front of the other, small steps, whenever you can, will help. What will help most is to find purpose and meaning and support, possibly in different areas of your life. I looked at it as re-building how I lived, and it's working üôÇ

¬†@dlee6976¬† In the West (or at least here in Australia) it would be considered awkward, if not rude, to make positive comments about someone's physical appearance. It might feel nice to the person receiving the positive comment, but it would generally not be viewed positively by any third person observer.
¬†@budawang77¬† I think it's all depends on person. I met plenty of Aussies and they don't seems to mind any compliment on their outlooks. However, I did come across a black guy who didn't like to be told that he looked strong and well built. Maybe it's a racial stereotype thing but who knows? I just think it's stupid to be offended by a compliment like that in a gym. I think some people aren't ready to take any form of compliments because their own complexity issues. These kind of people shouldn't be taken seriously as a "general  norm" in any society and culture.

¬†@dshyon¬†- I agree with you. I live in the US. Sure, poking fun about appearances with close friends is acceptable. But to see two psych professionals on TV offer opinions about their guest‚Äôs looks, body shape or overall appearance when he is there to promote his book? This would be regarded as highly unprofessional and impolite. As the hosts of a foreign guest, it would have been considerate if they‚Äôve done a quick research prior about the social etiquette/norms of his culture. As psychologists, this would have been so easy to do. So while there seem to be several arguments on this thread that what had occurred was no big deal or that all the cultures do it to some extent, I agree with you that it was not proper in the context the scenario has played out.
‚Äã¬†@ztvvtsh65¬†Ïù∏ÎèÑÎÑ§ÏãúÏïÑ ÏùºÎ≥∏ Ï§ëÍµ≠ Îì±Îì± ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù¥ ÏïÑÎãå ÎÇòÎùºÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎßêÏùÄ Ìï©ÎãàÎã§ ÌïúÍµ≠Îßå Í∑∏Îü∞ Í±∞ ÏïÑÎãò
ÏñºÎßàÎÇò ÏûêÏ°¥Í∞êÏù¥ Îñ®Ïñ¥ÏßÄÎ©¥ Ï†ÄÏ†ïÎèÑ ÏïÑÏù¥Ïä§ Î∏åÎ†àÏù¥ÌÇπÏúºÎ°ú ÏùåÏäµÌïòÎã§Í≥† ÌïòÎÉê..„Öã„Öã„Öã ÏùºÎã® ÎØ∏Íµ≠Ï†ïÏÑúÎÇò Î¨∏ÌôîÎäî ÏïÑÏòà Î™®Î•¥Í≥† Í∞ÄÎ≥∏Ï†ÅÏùÄ Ïª§ÎÖï ÎØ∏Íµ≠ ÏπúÍµ¨ ÌïúÎ™ÖÎèÑ ÏóÜÏ£† Îãò? „Öã„Öã
My heart goes out to yall. Generational PTSD is a REAL thing. Wanting to be the best and wanting to be effective for a lot of Koreans is rooted In fear . Being so terrified of being vulnerable or becoming victim to another group again.  I'm American and my ancestors were oppressed for hundreds of years here. Being oppressed for so long and being punished everything we tried to create our own or fight back created a hopeless mentality. It created low self esteem. It has been proven that we inherit our ancestors  traumas and its so obvious nwhen you see how people operate today. I really respect  that you have noticed the issue and that you want to heal it. I'm trying to heal mines as well.
As an American, I‚Äôve lived and worked in a Korean community in NYC throughout the 1990‚Äôs and 2000‚Äôs, so this mindset is very familiar to me. At times, my colleagues were highly critical of me for lacking motivation. Some of it was out of concern that I would be a failure. When I mentioned to a woman that I had a counseling appointment so I had to leave by 5:00, she was shocked. Why would I see a counselor? ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not crazy!‚Äù In her mind, psychologists and psychiatrists were only for ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù people. She just didn‚Äôt understand or accept that I was wrestling with anxiety and depression  brought on by a family problem. To her, it was something shameful.

¬†@gbot9000¬† Korea this video showed was extremely little. Sun shines a lot, garbage piles are not on every corner, depressing dingy looking building are not everywhere in Korea, especially in Seoul. There are older parts of Seoul and newer parts of Seoul. The video addressed the issue very well, but I think it didn't show much of the country as it wasn't necessarily a travel video. If you go there as a visitor, you will rarely feel the issue. Rather, you'll probably have a lot fun, I hope at least. I suggest you to look other travel channels' videos to see the country. Hope that changes your impression. I am Korean living abroad, but my American husband and in-law families who never left the U.S before loved Seoul when they visited.

I'm a Korean in my late 30's. I felt the same feelings with you. I got a professional job and have no special social problem, but I've lived with guilt and anxiety for whole my life.

23:40 This will be my life attitude from now on. I'm Korean, both the video and her words helped me a lot. Thanks.
I'm a Korean-American, born and raised in Korea until high school and immigrated to America in 1981.  This video is spot-on.  When I was living in Korea, I was under so much pressure to excel in school, mercilessly driven to study so very hard to go to a good university - by the time I was in high school, I felt so old, exhausted, and wanted to retire from life.  It was all about studying all the time to get the best grades with no time to play or have fun.  We even pressured to waste as little time as possible on sleeping at night.  I was so stressed, depressed and worn out.  It was brutal.  We never blamed society or others with sense of entitlement that most Americans have, and we just took all responsibility on our individual selves to work hard, improve ourselves and excel.  Some of my Korean friends as adults had to work so hard, couldn't go home at night, had to continue working all night and sleep at their desks, some of them died of failed health - literally working to death.  There is a price in coming so far from the poor and war-torn country to the one now excelling in every field.
It was an honor showing you and Will around Korea. You guys did a phenomenal job showing the best and worst of Korea. Resilience IS the best word to describe Korea and even when things feel hopeless in Korea (especially these days in politics as well) I know Koreans are resilient and will rise to the occasion. We are resilient and super adaptable. I am so proud of my Korean heritage and really appreciate you and your team shining light on Korea. I hope a lot of Koreans watch this :)   üéâüéâmore Mark documentary style travel videos like this please!!!
As a 54yr old Korean-American whose lived in the US since 2yrs old and in Korea for the past 20 years, I think I have enough first-hand personal 'lived experience' to have a deep understanding of the problems Korea faces and the differences between issues in Korea and western societies namely the US.  First I'd like to congratulate and applaud you for putting together a very well-researched and accurate video on the topic and which delves deeply enough to point out and present the root causes. There are way too many Gen Z 'tiktalkers' and 'influencers' that try to present such "Why so-and-so..' videos without having a clue as to what they are talking about. Most of them are pretty much just surface level observations they have experienced one or two times or a 'compilation' of talking points they have put together from other peep's videos online, which never fails to get to the root causes.   Regarding this topic at hand, more often than not it usually comes down to something like this, 'Koreans are too materialistic and fake, not to mention so competitive and narcissistic they have unrealistic beauty standards which drives them to be the cosmetic surgery capital of the world. No wonder they get so depressed if they don't think they're number one.. etc. etc.'  It's true, on the surface there's outward materialism, and competitiveness, and all those things mentioned. However, instead of simply writing it off as negative and undesirable traits as viewed in the west, if one takes the time to try and find out the root causes/reasons for such, they would come to understand why Koreans are such-and-such. Also, in many cases they would see that in many, if not most cases, the 'cause and effect' of such personality/character traits are quite different as compared to the west. Much has to do with Confucianist values of group harmony and unity, respect for elders/others, close family, patriarchal norm, etc. along with the fact Korea went from an agrarian society to the 9-10th largest industrialized economy in the world in a few short decades, which was pointed out in your expose, you get a better understanding of the nuances of why these character traits evolved in the society.   The competitive nature in Korea was not only brought on by parents wanting their children to succeed and outdo the Lee's kids, but even the government was pushing for academic advancement and excellence because without that, how else would Korea became a developed country with advance knowledge in industry, technology, academics, research etc. As a result the overseas travel restrictions were lifted after the 88 Seoul Olympics to encourage study abroad and that's when you saw a sudden influx of Koreans going abroad to the US, UK, CN etc. to study in higher education not only for BA but also masters and doctoral programs. They were the ones literally bringing back textbook theoretical knowledge and putting it into real world applications when they returned and became employed, they had no mentor or higher-uppers to train them like you normally would at your job. I noticed one commenter from the UK who said some Korean exchange students were horrified for not receiving a grade of 100. When Koreans exchange students go abroad to study, they're not going there to just get a grade and graduate, they're going there to actually learn in depth as much as they can as they must apply it when they return and find employment. In doing so, they're not only advancing their personal position, they're contributing to the advancement of their company which in turn contributes to the advancement of Korea overall.   People don't realize or know, understandably since Korean history is not taught in the US (Hell, even a lot of American history isn't taught in schools in the US), but not only was Korea invaded and colonialized by Japan from late 1800's until 1945 with their defeat in WW2, but Korea has been invaded countless times throughout centuries by the Manchurians, Mongols, France, and more recently by China and Russia thru their proxy the North, which led to the Korean War in 1950, just 5 years after the Japanese Imperial Army withdrew. Thus, Korea is a very nationalistic and homogenous country, which also makes them very proud of their 'survival skills' having remained a sovereign nation through all that. How many times has the US been attacked / invaded / occupied, or the UK or AUS?  It's hard to imagine what it feels like if you've not personally experienced it. Since foreigners don't know Korean history they've historically, and incorrectly, labeled Korea as a racist/xenophobic country. Well if your country has been invaded countless times throughout history wouldn't you have an aversion to outsiders as well? It only makes sense. Also, look at what's happening today in European countries like the UK, DN, FR, SW etc. after they opened up their immigration policies. It's not that Korean's are inherently racist or xenophobic, they understand that an influx or foreigners and their culture would disrupt social order and harmony in the host country, which it seems the West is just now finding out.  Boomers onwards in developed countries have never experienced firsthand invasion, war, foreign occupation, industrialization, hyper-development and technological advancement. Korea has experienced all of these within one generation's time period, 1G. My father's generation, born in 1933, has seen, lived through and experienced all of these. Most post-war westerners couldn't even fathom what it would be like to live through an era with such turmoil and change, fortunately for the better, and the immense pressures, hardships, stress and other burdens it puts on a societal and individual level, through all areas of society, also coupled with the values of Confucianism you have a recipe for disaster if not managed well (which you pointed out).  I just wanted to add a little more, my two cents worth, in terms of context because to truly understand a country, you really need to have a deeper understanding of it's historical, cultural, religious etc. aspects as they are all inter-influential in shaping a society. Many young people do not understand this as they lack 'life experience', but yet think they know it all. Take 'materialism' for example, unlike in the west which is all about 'pimping' and vanity, in Korea it stems from a different reason culturally. Sure it's starting to mirror the West from a couple decades ago with the advent of the internet, but the 'effect' of materialism stems from a desire to project the image of success, which not only has a selfish component but also reflects well on your family, it shows that your parents succeeded at parenting and raised you well, it makes them proud (once again pride is very important in Korea), and as a good son or daughter, there's nothing greater you can do for your parents than to be successful and make them proud, which is like showing your gratitude for all the sacrifice they made in raising you, sending you to the best school/after-school academy they could afford. These are concepts which are foreign in the West due to their sense of individualism and independence.   Once again I commend you for your effort in trying to put together as honest and accurate a picture of the topic at hand. You did an excellent job considering the conciseness of your video, the best by a foreigner that I've seen.
Very nice and accurate insight. But most Korean people even do not recognize how depressed they are. I am Korean but have been lived in other countries for more than 10 years. Never coming back.

People nonchalantly mention suicidal thoughts, and wanting to run away and quit everything. How casually they deal with severe mental health issues and substance abuse, and even the news of an acquaintance killing themselves, is shocking. or how much they care about optics (as opposed to how much they don't care about what they feel inside).Their societal, cultural issues have been boggling my mind so much so that I've been getting therapy after witnessing this in person. As a Korean, the pros and cons of my country are evident.  It's a heaven for a consumer, which means manifold and convenient services are surprising and satisfying enough to sustain your life here.  But the reason why it is regarded a hell is that YOU NEED TO CONTRIBUTE to this system as a worker/service provider/students as well. In this sense, we, Koreans denigrate ourselves in an imprecise way because of the stress they got somewhere.   The conclusion should not be like Oh you must leave Korea or No you must live in Korea.  We need to be objective to understand the true pros and cons.

For example, expecting that you/everyone should get a grade A in a class because everyone is special without making efforts to earn it thus fostering an environment of encouraging mediocracy; expecting (and depending on) the government to care of them, losing independence and individual responsibility.  If you read what I said, I was against oppressive Korean cultural environment at the extreme end, which is damaging.
¬†@Treehustle476¬† By sense of entitlement, I meant expecting to be given something you did not make efforts to earn, for example, an expectation and demand that everyone in a glass should be given a grade A, so that no one's ego will be hurt. ¬†@janepark227¬† Someone whose user name is "Caroline's vlogs" posted here "You're Korean not Korean American" 12 days ago, and deleted it.    I looked up the definition of Korean-American, and it means someone who is ethnically Korean but has an American nationality, which is who I am.  I lived most of my life in America, am an American citizen/nationality (I had to give up my Korean nationality when I became an American citizen in the 1980s).  I got educated in America (college & graduate school), worked in the private sector and the federal government for 30+ years, married to an American for 34 years.  I don't have an opportunity to interact with Koreans regularly.  I understand South Korea due to my earlier life, but my identify is more American than Korean.  When I visit Korea, I feel like a foreigner.

Most Korean children, even in the West, are raised with such expectations or goals and they internalize these expectations/goals. ¬†@shae1414¬† Nope, not at all true.  It's just a common figure of speech in Korea.  It's an expression of how fatiguing their life is.  We say "Ï£ΩÍ≥† Ïã∂Ïñ¥" (jook-go ship-uh).  It's s super common figure of speech.  But when they're not very proficient in English, they translate it directly to English without learning what the English equivalent expression is.
¬†@ChristianC-gy1ym¬† oh wow thanks for this because this made me realize that I was the one making literal translations LOL! They would say something similar to that when they forgot about something and all i‚Äôd interpret it as is ‚ÄúI want to d!e‚Äù or ‚ÄúI do not want to be alive anymore‚Äù. Definitely need more exposure to the culture, so many things can be lost in translation without the proper knowledge
‚Äã¬†@JSC-cw8cs¬† You guys might not realize how odd it is for people to even casually mention wanting to kill themselves...even as a joke or a figure of speech. It's a very Korean thing. Have you ever wondered why life and work is exhausting? Why is it so exhausting to the point that people think it's normal to be that tired all the time? As someone who's always prioritized my mental health above all else, it bothers me when people work till 10/11pm at night, or until morning, and don't think that is crazy. No office worker should be working past 5/6pm!! (unless they really want to but def not regularly, or they are in a specific career that asks for late nights like IB/M&A).  To explain what I mean by "casually deal with severe mental health issues and substance abuse" further, I have to share a few more examples. They have public service announcements at subway stations to warn people 1/not to make a scene while you are drunk, 2/not to damage public property while drunk 3/not to assault public servants while drunk, and this is really.....wtf.......? Why does any of that need to be public service announcement? Obviously a lot of people drink themselves to oblivion and don't think that is a problem. I've also heard from many taxi drivers that drunk passengers insult and assault.  It seems as though Koreans busy with their lives/work as they already are, don't notice that this toxic culture is not healthy or sustainable. I really wish Koreans would at least start taking longer vacations.
...and this is why I went to Germany when the army offered it to me.  I miss Korea dearly, especially the food. Korean BBQ isn't the same in Paris or Frankfurt, BUT I ABSOLUTELY DO NOT MISS the constant competition that Koreans do with each other. As a foreigner, if you spend too much time there, the Koreans will rope you in with their foolishness.

But none seems to care, it seems that after high-school and generally once one takes a leap into adulthood, people grown older as we step into society. They are like those casual suicide memes you awkwardly laugh about.
Hmmm, I would say it is most likely more of a numbness. You can get used to speaking about heavy topics without emotions and while that does not allow for you to emotionally bond and get to release internal emotions and open up to empathy, it also builds a shell of resilience. For sure it is not the most healthy thing to do, but it is a simple thing to do, to be detached and dissociate from ones emotions. I feel like the issue the west has is that they do the opposite, they focus on the internal emotions and tie their suffering to immutable external factors (society or even say "I am depressed" (instead of saying that you have depression, which is a key distinction) and then have it as an excuse to not do things. Emotions are extremely complex to navigate and it is often easier to either ignore them or overly focus on them in poor ways(which exacerbates their influence over you, as you become a slave to your misery and identify with an unproductive victim mentality). The way to handle emotions is very difficult without the proper guidance or insight, there are a lot of mental rabbit holes one can fall into and it can be quite comforting to feel like it isnt your fault that you are the way you are; though one needs to be careful to not let this be the excuse that drives you away from the agency that might lead to small incremental improvements in one's life.   The victim mentality is so pervasive in the west where it now dominates. it is somehow a virtue to be oppressed and we overgeneralize oppression to be based on fictional group identities instead of personal experiences(because you exist as an individual not an amorphous group). It does grant an "identity" that one can cling to and external forces to blame (real or imagined) and a sense of belonging and a false sense of comradery, but these people cling to an idea that fundamentally allows one to forfeit positive change in ones life and hurts the people that it implies that it protects.   Well we cannot blame people, like always we foolishly spread ideology onto the masses (psychological jargon for example) without people to teach people how to healthily deal with these internal realities. We as humans are fundamentally lazy and afraid to face terrifying truths, so instead we cling to the idea that it is okay to be a lesser (and is somehow a virtue) or hollow out the human experience by becoming numb to it.  Either way, there is no easy answer, you have to be brave and go on an internal voyage and face yourself, only you can "change" yourself.   ‚ÄúKindly let me help you or you will drown said the monkey putting the fish safely up a tree.‚Äù - Alan Watts  Pain is a emotion, it is not negative, that is what your ego has you to believe. Grow accustomed to it, stop running away from it, sit with it. When you run away from it you create friciton and an inherent adversity in it, as you fear it, but it is just you. Simply signals in your brain that are trying to tell you something. The signal might point to something bad or something wrong, but your reaction to the emotion is YOURS and you deem that the experience and not the underlying thing is the badness that plagues you, if you look closely.  Though for sure, as a society we will for atleast a while continue professing this ideology that all mental health focus is good focus, turning people into their own torturer LMAO.  Imagine you point to a wound on your knee and say that pointing at it is good. Then people go around suddenly poking at it more and more, and say "AWWW IT HURTS", ye dumb() ass you need to et some antibiotics and a bandaid, not rub it in lol.

Here we are very open with most things even the bad things as well like being openly rude, violent and hyper sexual. Koreans care more about how they‚Äôre perceived socially and their status so they tend to do these things in private so it‚Äôs less visible, they have the problem in reverse in the sense that sometimes they‚Äôre too closed off.

I grew up in Korea and I have to say this video is fantastic. That lady explaining that competitions begins when children are 6 or earlier was laughing, but I think it was very much self depreciating and it made me tear up a bit at my childhood memories. I was under immense academic and social pressure from a very early age and rarely was I told that everything is going to be ok, or that everything will work out in the end. It was just every day for me to feel seriously screwed for life and ashamed for the most trivial things, and I was one of the highest-performing kids anywhere I went. All it did was make me want to leave the country so desperately and I did. Now the culture has changed slightly but kids are still forced into the kinds of pressure and competition they should not be exposed to at their age. In the meantime nobody would check up on their mental health.
As a Korean, as rightfully said by Seohyun, it is changing and it will change. It just takes time for all the generations to acknowledge and recognize and value each other. All I can say now is that Korea is still in transition, trying to resolve these complex issues.

I currently live in South Korea (in the Southern area of the country). As an employed guest to this country I gotta say it‚Äôs an amazing place to be and experience. The people are wonderful, food is fantastic, and their history simply amazes me. There are cons, of course. The suicide rate scaling up is tragic and spoken about among my colleagues and friends; however, nothing seems to be changing on a legal or social level. I‚Äôm glad they are discussing it, but there is an umbrella of shame that if they change as a person or as a country that they are failing. The kids I teach are also in this camp. Some kids cry so hard if they miss one question on a 50-question quiz and think they are a failure. This becomes more so when the big school tests come around. I hope South Korea can overcome this, and quickly. If anything I‚Äôve observed is that they really can do anything and in a short amount of time. They‚Äôve accomplished so much. I hope they could also be the leader in accomplishing a social/mental revolution as well. ‚ù§

I used to teach English in a Korean school. Their education is brutal and yet it is very ineffective. They study from 6am to 2am. They memorise thousands of vocabulary words. It‚Äôs crazy and very ineffective. Why do you need to memorise the meaning of these voca when you could understand them using context clues. They memorise the voca and yet they struggle to use it in a sentence.‚ÄôAlso, they very aesthetic, materialistic. They always compare themselves to their classmates and this is the reason of their depression. Be it 6 years old or university student, they adapt the same study approach. It‚Äôs mentally draining.

¬†@sherylyin5219¬† It doesn't really work like that in reality. First comes patriarchy (yes, it still matters), then comes age, then comes social class. Confucianism is all about respect based on birth and social class, not meritocracy. I'm also chinese, but wasn't raised in China. Its merely from my observation of the chinese community around me and relatives in China. Face is probably the worst aspect of Confucianism, but its the one that most Confucian influenced cultures care about the most. Let alone caring about family and community, that probably comes dead last.
From my experience as a Korean, the suicide rate is low because the military and schools leave little room for thinking about other aspects of life. However, Korea is also a highly hierarchical society, especially in the professional sphere, where jobs that require less academic background are often looked down upon as ‚Äústupid‚Äù jobs. This leads to intense competition for education to avoid that stigma. There has long been a notion that people who don't go to college are ‚Äúsurplus human beings,‚Äù and even today, there are many derogatory comments online about those who attended a ‚Äúcrappy local college‚Äù instead of a prestigious university.

Í∑∏Îü¨ÎØÄÎ°ú Ïù¥ Ï†äÏùÄ ÏÑ∏ÎåÄÎäî Ïù¥Í∏∞Ï†ÅÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏöïÏùÑ Î®πÏùÑÏßÄÏñ∏Ï†ï ÌñâÎ≥µÌïòÎäî Î∞©Î≤ïÏùÑ Î∞∞ÏõåÏïºÎßå ÌïúÎã§.

Since the 1980s, the Koreans have been criticizing the pressure that the students get and it was talked about on the media. But it continued to get even more terrible for the later generations. Parents fear that their children might get behind if they don't force them to study more.
Wow could've easily watched a whole series of your experiences in Korea! Your insights into Korea's cultural and educational landscape really resonated with me. Being Korean American, I feel a deep sense of pride in the strong work ethic inherent in my heritage. I'm also grateful to have grown up in America where I had a chance to express my individuality. The blend of Korean resilience and American freedom has instilled in me a confidence that I can achieve anything I set my mind to.
this is a great video. I've been to south korea many times myself and absolutely love it there...as a visitor. having gone so many times, i've seen the good and the bad, especially in seoul. i learned a lot from interacting and making friends with locals but i've learned even more from just observing. the country and its people are beautiful but they have their challenges too. getting to immerse oneself in the culture really opens your eyes from the glitz that represents them in media. you get to see the reality of it all and that's very well reflected in this video. truly, truly well made.   also, heh. 13:06 had to double take to make sure it's felix lmao
As a expat who has been living in Seoul for 4 years, I think this video beautifully sums up the situation in Korea. All of these points are true and I have seen it myself. I have had conversations with coworkers and friends about these things. The differences between Korea and the US/Western world. The biggest difference is definitely the view of mental health and accessibility. I realized how uninformed many Koreans are about mental health and mental disorders. They are surprised at how open I am about these topics and how my friends have been open to me when I tell them stories of my friends' struggles. I will say the younger generations are much more open to talking about mental health and making mental health a priority. Some children I work with are getting help and treated. However, there are so many that view any mental health issues, disorders, or disabilities as a weakness and will try to hide it or choose to ignore the reality that it is happening to them/a loved one. One friend who teaches kindergarten told me how one of their previous students definitely had some kind of mental disability and the parents were in formed this child should be tested. But the parents refused because they say "nothing is wrong with my child." Instead of identifying it early and getting help and treatment that will help their child cope and function well in life, they choose to ignore it because they don't want their child singled out.  The work culture is also brutal. Just as the video says, many work crazy hours even if they don't have work. OR they have so much work, they work crazy hours. I had a friend getting 2-4 hours of time at home (getting home around 4am and back at work at 9am), with no overtime pay, and crazy pressure of having to complete a bucket load of tasks and some of those tasks she was not qualified or had the education to actually do. She did this work schedule for months! And to add another factor into the mix, the birth rate is low and the government is trying to encourage people to have children. However, how can it be expected for a person, who is barely seeing the apartment they rent, to have the time for a relationship and then have time to raise and care for a child? Very unrealistic.   Even as a foreigner, I have felt the pressures as well. I am supposed to be a "role model" and "example of a good citizen." Which is fair, but there is no wiggle room here to be human and make mistakes. I feel judged or that I will be judged. And as an averaged sized American, the stress about my body image during my first year here was strong. I've grown to not care about it now but that first year when you are thrown into a society all about image, you start caring too when you realize how much everyone cares. I love this country. It's beautiful and the culture is beautiful. Generally, the people are wonderful and nice and the food is to die for. However, I have felt weighed down and stifled so I actually am returning home after 4 crazy years of fun but also awful experiences (but mostly fun). And most of my friends feel the same way and are leaving one by one, some of them taking Korean SOs that want out too. There are so many factors to this decision so don't weigh it all on Korean society/mentality as a whole, but it is a factor.
living in seoul for 5 years now, this is the most perfect explanation of how things go here
17:40 This is so freaking true. My mom is clearly suffering mentally in various ways, yet she refuses to seek counseling or help from mental health professionals. I struggled with panic disorder for three years, and she always asks me, 'Can't you just overcome it?' No, mom, this is emotional abuse, seriously.
Brilliant!! Thanks for this video. I have been to SKorea once, and plan to return. I like that this video has an optimistic ending.

Fantastic summary of Korean cultural uniqueness and the events that led to where they're at today. The other layer is the economic decisions that led to the Chaebol dominance in the economy. As someone who has enjoyed learning about Korean culture since discovering KDramas during lockdown (and then learning Korean as a hobby) I have found that KDramas are doing a decent job at exposing and discussing the challenges and taboos in their society. Not just the usual taboo relationship tropes. Dramas like DP that expose the mental health issues in military service and My Liberation Notes that explore the grinding commutes and hopelessness of climbing the ladder.
