As a Korean middle-aged man having two kids, this is a really well-made documentary. I couldn't agree more . A few years ago, I moved to Canada with my family. That's a good opportunity to compare my home country and North American culture. And now I realized how depressed my life was. And I thought that was just normal life that everybody on the planet has. Now I know it's not.
People, family, culture, society and country are inseparably linked. In my country there are thousands of songs and poems about love for the homeland and people. Every time we encounter difficulties, we just need to listen to a song about our homeland to feel all our troubles disappear, life becomes precious and our souls become more peaceful. That's why we value life extremely. Thinking simply and peacefully, happiness will come from the simplest things
I'm a Korean who immigrated to America after college. 3 minutes into this video I realized I'm living the South Korean life even in another continent not because I was forced to but because I volunteered to literally grind myself to excel at work. My biggest challenge while working in the Western corporate environment has been having to work at other people's pace.. Because I wouldn't let emails sit in the inbox for longer than 12 hours, I don't want any dirt on my career, don't wanna take the blame when things go wrong against my wishes whereas my colleagues take that morning coffee and take a full hour lunch outside the office. So I definitely overwork myself and I know it. I just can't help the way i am. It's been helping me progress but at the same time I'm aware this isn't sustainable in the long run. It gets tough when I can't even have the time to seek assistance in mental healthcare although I could. I'll eventually give myself a break but I realize I really need to look after my mental health.   Thank you for covering South Korea with clear insights. Very impressive I am now subscribing your channel!
I am German but live in Korea for the past 4 years. I absolutely love it here, but I know, that is, because the societal norms and pressures for Koreans, don't apply to me as a foreigner. And I don't work a 9-5 job. Korea is a great beautiful country, but it heavily depends on, what you do for work and how financially free you are.
Being a foreigner that lived in Korea, I always pointed out the dichotomy of the society. The glitz and glam that you would often see but a couple streets away it would look more like I stepped back in time a couple decades. Seoul was an amazing experience but I know as someone who didn‚Äôt work in the Korean economy, I didn‚Äôt fall under the societal pressure that they did. I got to experience all the up sides with none of the downsides. I would love to go back to Korea and experience more of the culture and especially the food!

As a Korean, I agree with your points about the importance of mental well-being. However, in Korean society, fierce competition starts at a young age, as early as elementary school. This creates a paradox: while mental health is recognized as crucial, current solutions often fail to address the issue at its root, which is the relentless pressure to compete. Even though individuals pursue success in various aspects of life, from academics and careers to marriage and social standing, the constant struggle to "win" fuels the prevalence of mental health concerns. Eliminating competition entirely, however, wouldn't be a viable solution. Korean society has achieved significant advancements through its emphasis on hard work and pushing individuals to strive for excellence. The challenge lies in adapting to changing times. The current competition-driven model, championed by older generations and politicians, no longer aligns with the needs of today's society. Maintaining this approach only exacerbates the situation, as evidenced by the unprecedented decline in birth rates, surpassing even war-torn nations. While competition can be a positive force, the rigid, one-size-fits-all approach stifles the potential of individuals with diverse talents. To thrive as a nation in the face of evolving global needs, we must cultivate diverse fields for competition, fostering creativity and efficiency across various fields. It's crucial that older generations and policymakers acknowledge the need to move beyond the singular focus on competition and embrace a more multifaceted approach that allows individuals to succeed in different ways.
¬†@Queensaac¬† I had noticed one thing that was said - the old generation teaches to the young one (and this is so in my own country of Bulgaria) that if you have a good education, you will have guaranteed success, e.g. money, good job, pretty wife/husband, etc... since that was true for them, but sadly it is no longer true. Good education does not guarantee you anything anymore. It is only the start, so to say. So, if you approach your life with the mentality that you will be at the end of the race when going out of the university, you will be unpleasantly surprised, confused and not knowing which way to go - all pushing you into depressive states.
I am from eastern asia and now live in Australia and western countries have the opposite problem.  White society wear mental health like a proud badge, even celebrate it.
How could they be informed about mental health when they don't have any mental health?
As you mentioned, low birth rate is a serious social issues in Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Japan.  In these countries, people had to work hard but most of them realize they will not get paid as much as their seniors used to receive.  They recognize their effort will not paid off in their life.  They recognize their quality of life is low and will not be able to earn self-affirmation. If they feel their QL is low, how can they feel comfortable to marry someone hand have a child?  How can they feel happy to have a child? We will not able to solve this issues unless our QL is improved.
It's wrong that all the points are true. It's not true that you have to wait for your boss to leave before leaving yourself, you can't contradict your boss, etc. That may have been true in the past and it's possible some companies are run like that, but as a general rule to apply to the culture it's definitely not true
My family immigrated from Korea to the US when I was 12.  When I went to school in Korea, the pressure to do well was so intense that I still suffer from PTSD after 40 yrs.  My older sister, my younger brother, and I have all done really well (the academic standard in the US is a joke compared to Korea) because of how we were raised in Korea but I feel like I would have never made it had my family stayed in Korea.  Yes, I also refuse to see a psychiatrist because I think being stubborn and being self-reliant is the definition of Korean mentality. hahaha
my parents were pretty open to me getting mental help because we lived in the US for 5 years a long time ago. But they still have the mindset of: "if you're traumatized or hurt by what someone has said/done, that's on you because the same thing might not impact others the same way, so just get an apology and move on".   It's frustrating to me because I bring up the past because I feel like it NEEDS to be addressed for one to actually move on and make peace. Especially when it's caused by your own parents, and we'll have to see them for a long time until they pass.
¬†@mspsys¬† as someone who has overcome depression I think talking with yourself is better than a psychiatrist. Or talking with people that are in the same situation also helps, though they are hard to find. The point is you are not alone in the way that you feel.
Australia is no different to Korea in that case. Heaps of homeless, all our money and resources go overseas
Your description is more suited to Japan. No oil, no coal, tons of disaster especially eartquake, and 70% land covered by mountainous terrains with litte room for 125 mil population, Japan is much worse than Korea. Korea is still pretty normal and better compared to Japan in the terms of the survival.

Great story. But you really need to stop working so hard. You are giving a bad example for the corps what to expect from workers. We don't want to turn into SK üòÇ
As a westerner living in east Asia, I did experience all the pressure at work which has end up with a burn out. But I did manage to go over it and learn my way of handling pressure, simply go with life flow, especially I realized one thing, we all keep thinking ‚Äúafter I do this I will feel that‚Äù, but the reality it‚Äôs we should be living in the present. the energy is real.
I suggest a more concrete gradual approach. I work full throttle in the office. But I take the hour lunch. After eating, I go to shops, but don't buy, or a beautiful church, read in the church garden, etc.. I must plan carefully for my brisk walk back to the office to be on time. I also take super mini breaks by having some clean snack and tea at the desk, so I have to look up to take a bite or sip. This is subject to bosses allowing food, but it does make you slow down a bit. Sign up for yoga or other active class once a week to start. Don't be available for overtime, because you have a class. Good luck.
Your effort will pay you back probably more in the US than Korea.  You are doing the right thing.  If others around you don‚Äôt grind as much then why do they drink and do drugs more than you?  Don‚Äôt stop.  Feel free to slow down temporarily but keep going. Fighting!
what i find is the most important 'quality' to have and that will help your career in western workplaces is knowing whose bum to kiss and suck up to, social manoeuvring, being likeable...if anything, if westerner colleagues see you work hard and do better than them, they will resent you.
I guess that‚Äôs why characters in web toons often have the story of dying from overwork üòÖ, must be a real common thing.
One of the most important things I've learned recently is to put my health and wellbeing first. So no impossible deadlines, no overnight work, no postponing a break or dealing with my issues when I need it, fuck that. Nobody will care for my needs and health if I don't, certainly no an employer. I'm convinced that in the long run, that also makes you a better worker and person overall. A healthy, happy and motivated one.
I worked at Samsung for 2 years and I realise that I took the work ethic of hard work no break no holiday to my next job - I literally overperform and did not take a days leave last year and also since I left Samsung.
I had lived in NYC for 2 decades before I escaped to West coast. I'm Korean. Didn't know there are other way of living until I m here. Growing up in Seoul living NYC is another (fancier) version of living in Korea.. where there are still hierachy (different way),  pressures from unknown others .. you can't completly escape from these anywhere you go.. but by being still or slow it helps you find it, ie. liberating, that begins from the inside.
Your mental health is your first priority.  I'm telling you right now, if you break it will take YEARS to put yourself back together.  Take some time to recharge, see a therapist and just do whatever you want.  Unless you're literally being mentored by a senior college to be the next man up, take it easy, they don't gaf about you or anyone else.
You can take the Korean out of Korea, but you can't take the Korean out of the Korean...

As a korean who will soon turn 19, this video almost made me cry. It is true we suffer and are worried about us and what the future will hold, but the reason why I couldn't give up and kept myself together was that slight hope that I never told anyone that things will get better if I try better, if I try to become that generation to lead the way to a much more acceptable happiness.  As always I was thinking about leaving the country because of the lack of space and acceptance my generation gets, but again I also wish to stay where I laughed, cried and was born.  I believe that we will get through this.

I am Brazilian, my wife is korean and by the exorbitant prices of the apartments, we live here in Korea with her parents. By the apartments prices and the working pace, Korea has got the lowest Birthrate in the world (0,70). This video is really important to raise awareness of this topic. We decided to start our lives here by the safety. But it is quite sad that children until teenagers don't play around, dont do any sports... when we leave the gym (9-10pm), the floor above is an academy (study support), they are all there until this time. I am 30, and I suffered depression in my childhood, and I have ADHD. When I mention it round here that I am going to the psychologist, and after therapy, they don't understand because it is quite unusual here. It concerns a lot the future here... we really hope that society changes. Korean people are so kind and nice. As they are so resilient and strong, I am sure they will overcome this situation well. They deserve more

We showed the world our economic success and now it's time for some self-care. Let us stay sane no matter what, dear fellow Koreans! Huge thanks to this video, Mark!

ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Î¨∏Ï†úÎäî Ï¢ÅÏùÄ ÎïÖÏóê ÏûêÏõêÏù¥ ÏóÜÎäîÎç∞Ïóê ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïò§ÏßÅ Ïù∏Í∞ÑÏùò Îä•Î†•ÏúºÎ°ú Ïô∏Ìôî Î≤åÏù¥ ÌïòÎã§Î≥¥Îãà Í≤ΩÏüÅÏù¥ ÏπòÏó¥ Ìï† Ïàò Î∞ñÏóêÏöî. ÎØ∏Íµ≠Ïù¥ÎÇò Ìò∏Ï£º, Î∏åÎùºÏßà,  Ï§ëÍµ≠Ï†ïÎèÑÏùò ÏûêÏõêÍ≥º ÌÜ†ÏßÄÎßå ÏûàÏñ¥ÎèÑ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ Î®πÏó¨ ÏÇ¥Î¶¨ÎäîÎç∞ ÌÅ∞ Î¨∏Ï†úÎäî ÏóÜÏúºÎãàÍπåÏöî. ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã¬†@caidylan¬†ÏÇ¨Ïã§ ÌòÑÏû¨ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Ïú†Íµê Î¨∏ÌôîÎäî Ïù¥ÏÉÅÌïòÍ≤å Î≥ÄÏßàÎêú Í≤ÉÏù¥ ÎßéÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏòàÎ•º Îì§ÏûêÎ©¥ Ï∞®Î°Ä(Ëå∂Á¶Æ)Î¨∏ÌôîÍ∞Ä ÏûàÏ£†. What an amazing video. I have actually been to Korea last year and it is an amazing country. So good to see you zoom in on the "dark" side of this country. Really seems like being a country thats so awesome, kind and hard working comes at a price to the people living there. Love to Korea and you Mark!
You're killing it with these videos! Keep going, we love 'em.
I am a high school student who was born in Korea. Everyone here studies for 12 years from the first grade of elementary school to the third grade of high school. Most of them start earlier than that. These days, kindergarten-based private academies and kindergarten students prepare for medical schools before they think about the world they want to live in, because their parents don't know much about the world. I still think that the important thing for teenagers is their view of the world and their various experiences. However, the reality is different. You have to endure the pressure that you didn't even experience in the past, the desire to play, the exercise, etc. due to the set period of study. If you exercise, you also have to develop your physical strength to study. When you go to high school, you write down a portfolio like the first year and complete it for three years in high school, and then enter college based on the content and school grades. At this time, you have to write all the activities you do in school in relation to your career hope, and there is an academy that helps you write such a portfolio. Also, the cost of the academy is huge. I think such education in Korea will cause a wider gap between the rich and the poor. Most students these days don't think deeply about their career path and think that they should definitely go to college, and most of their friends who are good at studying want to pursue medicine. Jobs like doctors and dentists are expensive. Meanwhile, I thought I didn't know why I should go to college in my country. I'm still a teenager who hasn't had much experience, and I didn't think it was worth investing in because it would cost me a lot of money to decide on a department and go to college. Later, later than others, but when I had something I wanted to study for, I wanted to go to college. If I fail college at the age of 19, I will be treated as a failure. Even though I am a broken teenager, my dream is to travel around the world. But that means a lot of adults are interfering with other people's lives, such as how they will make money and need to have money to get married in the future. At first, I thought I would make the right mistake and others would get caught up in this world. I knew what I really wanted was to travel around the world, and I believed that I would be happy with the process even if I had a part-time job that wasn't a full-time job. However, it is really upsetting to find myself getting ingrained in this society. Success and failure are divided in teenagers, and if they don't get married on time, pressure from people around them will arise, and the heads of households will have to earn a certain amount of money, compete in new jobs again, and if they don't have children, I think it is natural that Korea has high suicide rates and depression levels. However, no one is trying to change. As a Korean, I want everyone to look back, not just ahead.
Thanks Mark. This new series is awesome. Lived the one about Portugal as well
As an educator in Korea for the last dozen years, I agree with this video. Korea excelled in economics because it needed to survive. Now it must tackle its social problems, inequalities, and depression-inducing educational and work methods if it wants to survive.
This is the most accurate documentary  about South Korea. As a Korean, I appreciate your belief that we will find a way. I too hope that we can overcome all the challenges facing people in this country üôè
Awesome video.  This is my first time watching your content and I loved it as a Korean!

ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏßÄÍ∑πÌûà Ï†ïÏÉÅÏù¥ÏóàÎã§ÎäîÍ±∏ „Öã„Öã Í∑∏ ÎÅîÏ∞çÌïú ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùÑ Í≥ßÏù¥Í≥ßÎåÄÎ°ú Îî∞Î•ºÏàòÏûàÎäî Í∑∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÎπÑÏ†ïÏÉÅÏù¥ÎùºÎäîÍ±∏.. Î®∏Î¶¨ Îí∑ÌÜµÏàò ÎïåÎ†§ÎßûÏùÄ Í∏∞Î∂ÑÏù¥ÏóàÏùå
As a native Korean, i can confirm that he addressed Korean society really well. I always welcome foreign viewpoint of our culture because it promp me to reassess the culture i am living in. Thank you for the documentation :)
Brazil should be the next video! that article you wrote years ago about our culture is remembered till this day!
As an American adopted from Korea as a baby, I was not exposed to Korean culture at all. My adopted parents were successful, but didn‚Äôt have competitive personalities. There was no pressure for me to be the best, and family relationships were prioritized over work and money. Yet, my own perfectionist competitive mindset, the expectations I put on myself, and the shame I experience when I fall short of those expectations are so strong that I sometimes wonder if it‚Äôs possible for a culture/values/mindset to be so internalized through multiple generations that it can be passed on genetically, even to someone who has never been exposed to the culture, and raised in a very different culture
A travel show focusing on culture and mental health around the World would be an incredible series.
As a college student born and raised in Korea, most of my childhood memories revolve around fiercely competing in schools and academies. Even in university, I had to compete constantly to maintain a good GPA. When looking at objective indicators such as birth rates and suicide rates, it's evident that there are problems in our society. However, amidst the fear of starving to death or becoming victims of social shame, many find it difficult to speak up and find their own way to survive.  Although everyone is aware of these grim realities, it's true that opinions don't easily come together for societal improvement. Politicians, who should be at the forefront of change, often show little interest in opinions that don't translate into votes. In this sense, I'm deeply grateful for influential YouTubers like Mark to share his thoughts on our social issues. As a young Korean, I hope there is a future where more people in Korea could become happier and more acceptive to others.
Wow you did a really good job on analyzing Korean society. This was exactly how I felt about the Korean society after I moved back here from the U.S. in 10 years. I never got to experience the real side of this society, even though I was born in Korea and raised untill 15, but now I'm facing thoses societal issues daily at my workplace. I don't think there are analysis that will explain better than this video about the Korean society.  The younger generations who got a different education than my age are showing up as a change maker in the society, but the competitiveness is always there. There should be a systematically change in order to bring a real change in the society. Neverthless, I had a goosebumps by the end of the video when he talked about how considerate the Koreans are besides all of these issues in the society. Korea has so many good sides that no other countries can have and it's just so depressing that we Koreans can't fully enjoy it.
This video is truly GOLD!!! Thanks for shining light on the truth of Korea Mark.

If someone asks me how it is in Korea, I will just share them a link to this video, it has a really good insight, absolutely better than the documentaries made by locals. in 24 minutes it covered so many details with right examples. Thank you for creating this video I don't know how you did it. I really think Korea took capitalism and competition to another level. Everyone is trying at 200 percent every day. In America, I know if I try my best, I could probably make it. In Korea, your average 12-year-old is already putting in 150 percent effort. Loving the content, Mark! üíõ More of these videos, please.  I taught English for 2 years in South Korea at elementary school level - 7, 8, 9 and 10 year olds. The academic pressure is insane even at such a young age. I felt there are no moments for kids to be kids.
I live in Japan which has a lot of the same issues Korea has. I am half Japanese half Spanish though and I was brought up in Spain so I can't really speak Japanese well and I am regarded as a foreigner here, but let me tell you I am glad I was raised in Spain and I am actually also quite glad I am regarded as a foreigner here also. I feel like my Spanish environment really helped me be more relaxed in everything, the pace of living over there is just much more slow and relaxed, and my Spanish friends don't seem to be in a rush to build a successful career nor do they seem to care if they are behind or not, they are just doing their thing and that is also helping me come to terms that I don't need to rush my career and I don't need to rush my life.¬†  Here in Japan I have spoken to plenty of Japanese natives who are even younger than me completely stressed out about being behind everyone else and on having to go through the entire system of graduating from university, get an internship and afterwards get a job. All done within specific time frames also, someone doing a sabbatical year is almost unheard of, and young Japanese people are even afraid to do this sabbatical year even if their mental health is telling them, dude you seriously need a break.¬†Because they feel like they will be behind everyone else.  Being regarded as a foreigner here kinda makes it easier for me because I tend to surround myself with other foreigners and there are no expectations for me from part of Japanese society to do better, or to follow certain rules or standards, they are definitely more lenient on these kind of things for foreigners. Of course foreigners in Japan (especially those without the same privileges as me, who has a passport and doesn't have to worry about visas) deal with many other issues too. But at least there is not this pressure on us to perform better or to follow the "Japanese standard rules". Also, among us foreigners in Japan we are all just escaping in some sense and trying to make it abroad so we tend to have each other's back on our mental health. Korea seems to be a lot like Japan in a sense that the pressure, the societal standards and the amount of rules they need to follow just seem like it's too much for the young generation and that ends up literally killing them.
Thank you for showing both the beauty and the darkside of a culture, they are truly ressilient.
As somebody who's travelled to South Korea and is planning an exchange semester in Seoul, I got a similar verdict, a similar feeling; while at first it seems very shiny and perfect and then concerning and sometimes almost scary, over time, you cannot help but feel that they'll somehow manage to get over it. All koreans I've met so far have been some of the nicest and most fun people you could wish for and they all seemed to have a certain strength and will in them, to not give up, to see and value even the little joys of life. I don't know what the future holds and I'm curious on how my view will evolve after a longer time there, but I really wish for them to find their way as a country, to strike a balance that works for both economic success and a healthy, happy society.    also bro found the key to me actually watching the placement instead of skipping it, respect

I'm 100% korean who has seen korea in the eyes of a half foreigner, and a korean. I've lived in America for 6 years, and for the rest of my life, I've lived in Korea.  I tend to think differently than my classmates. Maybe it's because I was raised in america.  I've been through depression and self harm as well before. Not a surprise.  Korea is safe, and it's comfortable. I'll admit it. No guns, no gender or sexuality wars. We have an amazing environment, a lot of things to learn and see, and a ton of culture and excitement.  Then, why do koreans get so easily depressed in korea? Is the country the problem?  It's mostly the socializing. Yes, the government and people around you pressuring to succeed and work are stressful as well. Very much. Studying is harx, and success is hard.  Yet, what makes it so hard are the people. They pressure you. Especially if your job is related to human interactions. They knock you down, they tackle you, they humiliate you.  The fact that you can stay anonymous on the internet does not help. There's a reason why I don't like to interact with koreans online. It's a total mess. Racism, perfectionists attacking you... It's not great. Although it's what makes korea so safe and uncontroversial, it's suffocating when it's a subject like race, feminism, or appearance.  A quick note on racism, I was literally just talking to my friend on the phone and two little boys started mocking me.. I'm korean though.. the kids in my class mock my pronouncation. Yet, foreigners say I don't even sound korean.  "People are rude here too." "Korea's social system isn't special. It's not a special problem." Go ahead and say that. Just understand that we are always pressured. We never feel free. Besides, the topic is korea, not your countryüòÖ  Thank you for reading.‚ù§
It is good to see more and more people are realising what is happening in my country. The important thing is, make sure that you would not make the mistakes we did. Think carefully about 'what makes your life most meaningful'. Leave no one behind.
You are lucky to have grown up in Spain. I absolutely adore your tapas culture and had a lovely time in Barcelona. Quimet Y Quimet is my favorite tapas bar in the world.üòä
Please girl we are so same. I also thought about the same thing, and like you, I am also a  foreigner raised in a different country. When I came here, depression really hit me. They are so fast paced that I can't catch up with them, and work ethics are super TOXIC. I love Japan, (especially their scenery, architecture, technology- which just shows how much pressure are placed unto them to have reach this far) and I don't want to come back to my country without being successful first, but the stress and pressure here, and how all my relationships are transactional, it's killing me. There are no happy relationships here, everything is transactional :<
I am older Japanese and you may nor believe me but Japanese society is more relaxed than 40-50 years ago. It is still very strict country following SK and China but people realized they have a choice.

I think this comment can be misleading. Japan‚Äôs suicide rate has lowered dramatically over the past 10 years, and now it‚Äôs about the same as the average of European countries‚Äô. If you doubt it, please Google, you‚Äôll be surprised. Compared to those kids in Korea, pressure from parents is much much less. Kids in school in Japan have those school lives you see in anime and Japanese movies. I also want to point out that Japanese media often shows bad manners and behaviours by foreigners on TV news and Japanese people are commenting that they should follow the local rules as long as they‚Äôre in Japan in an interview. Some even say they don‚Äôt want foreign visitors if they don‚Äôt follow the local rules. They‚Äôve been accepting lots of workers mainly from Asia and there are obviously lots of issues that result from cultural differences.
Not a great fan of korea's problem is the same in japan  In korea, domestic industry is harsh because very limited huge companies can earn money in their country kick aside relatively small companies. I liv ed in Korea for 17 years. When I left in 2019, I was the most depressed I had ever been. Mental health is NOT discussed. It is frowned upon to even talk about mental health.
This was great. I especially liked Nick's perspectives, which I thought on sharply on point and one of the best takes on the current situation I've seen recently. Also, as one of the other commenters mentioned, "the worst parts of confucianism and capitalism" does indeed hit on the essence of the problem. Interestingly, the new generation has begun to balk at the ideals of confucianism, which has exacerbated the intergenerational conflict with the older generation. In fact, this intergenerational conflict is one of many conflicts that is driving hate and preventing solutions to major societal problems. There are conflicts and hateful discourse not just based on age, but also based on gender, region in which one lives, socioeconomic class, political parties, etc.

A lot of that is cultural. Confucianism and the imperial exam system have been seen as the only way to succeed for more than 2 millennia, so it's hard to change. So when confronted with a problem outside the sinosphere, like you faced, they just fall back on traditional wisdom - be a studious Confucian gentleman and your life will be miraculously fine, if not, you didn't do it well enough.  That's why China had to destroy Confucianism to progress. It's too toxic and holds back progress.

What an utterly indepthful analysis!  I come from vietnam. Raised in America so there was that expectational disconnect.  My mother simply expected me to be ingrained with the culture of financial acquisiveness first and foremost.  I never truly measured up to the level of hard work to ever earn a semblance of respect in her eyes so my childhood was a mix of buffoonery and disregard.  I my mother has earned a measure of financial success there is a disconnect to the generation that came before her and after her in the realm of familial piety.  She fled Vietnam before the war ended.  She imposed this point of Eastern expectation that an underling or child has no rights except to do what was imposed upon, and do it with a smile.  It's not a far stretch to say that my western value didn't serve me.  I'm 57 and just in the last few years have I come to terms with childhood, values and cultures.  I understood it in a misty, peripheral sort of way. I understood it but it wasn't concrete enough to put to words, to put things according to their weight.  It's so very insightful of you to deconstruct western vs. eastern values. You put it with specificity which ruled out everything else that wasn't that.  I thank you.  It's an enormous weight off my shoulders to put dimensions on the thing that I had been contending with.  Thank you Mark.  Betty ‚ù§

I asked him how many days a week he was doing it and his answer still makes me sad - he was working 90 days straight (yes inclusive of weekends). Teenagers like me have suicidal thoughts and even depression... Children who grow up like this are bound to become even more unhappy.
I gave a birth of my son in 2023 when Korea was suffering the lowest birthrate ever. First of all, I am very thankful to you for investigating the problems happening right now in my country. Normally, most korean women have to quit their jobs because people who work together in a company don't like the woman's maternity leave(it's not compulsory) and give pressure not to use a leave. Also, there's no workflexibility at all(9am to 6pm ). So, they have to send their child to a daycare center until age 7.  Children can stay in a daycare center from 7 am to 6 pm, so there might be no problem before graduating. The problem is when the kids enter into an elementary school. They finish at 1 pm when they are in 1st grade. So moms in korea are devastated because there's nobody to care for their kids. So they have to leave the company and give up their career. I think this can be another reason why Korea is the lowest  birthrate country.

I believe you should also do a similar video about India on the matter of increasing rates of depression and anxiety, because from what I've seen, in India the anxiety is a mixture of show-off like it comes from the western culture, and intense confucinism like from South Korean culture. Thanks for a wonderful video Mark and fellow producer team. Enjoyed the thought provoking dialogue and concepts of confucianism, materialism, social health i.e. relationships, financial stress and health outside of work. In my time living there people walk more than in western countries, 20% of plastic surgery globally takes place in Seoul and garlic consumption is higher than most other countries via kimchi and other foods. Outside of Seoul one will see agriculture in the towns and villages, as all the ingredients are grown for kimchi and made by families. It's interesting to see the natural seasons as the crops are grown. In my opinion there is a bias that working outside of Seoul is viewed as a failure (10million of 52 million), but people in Seosan were much happier non-verbally with a sense of community walking around the town lake (all ages) - daily. Wonderful people however cell phone addiction was noticeable, hence an isolation factor.  I loved S. Korea and am thankful for the experience.
This is the best video I have watched from you Mark. The music, editing, content... everything is perfect. Thanks a lot for all your publications, your newsletter, the books, the podcast. You have supported a lot of people. Thank youu very much!
I live in Indonesia and many Koreans surround me due to their work, and I also have a Korean brother-in-law. This video really reflects how competitive Koreans are. I have a 6-year-old son and he has few Korean classmates, I can tell how competitive Korean parents are, and what surprises me is those Korean expats can backstab each other while they are living abroad (which I thought you should be supportive of each other while living in another country.) They have to show how good their kids are, and it seems like they push their kids to be the best and take pride out of it. I know many Asian parents also do the same, but knowing Koreans, they really take it to another level.
As a teenager in korea, this video gave me lots to think about. Yes, it is a fact that people constantly compare themselves to other people and have lots of mental problems. The shame and the anxiety make people feel like they are a loser, and since they are stressed out with these feelings, they find another way to solve it, by depreciating others, followed by loneliness and depression and hate amongest the community. But at the end of the video mentioning resilience and all the positive stuff we have, I felt that if we focused the positive traits then the negative we would figure out to live a happier life. Thanks for making this video Mark ‚ù§
As a Korean who lives in canada, I think westerners are kidding themselves thinking western countries are far less depressed than Korea. Look at the addiction spread like wild fire among western society.  I personally think if western countries prohibited all this drug uses as strongly as Korea, their suicide rate would've  shot up like crazy. Yes, Korea is bad but any modernized capitalistic society is not that much better than Korea either. I still remember how shocked I was when I found out so many regular students and peopleI know are regular substance users. They call themselves recreational user but there's nothing recreational about drug use.  In Canada, weed is legal. If you have this large group of people that need to use substance on regular basis, that country is far from the happy country. Happy and satisfied people don't use substance. Koreans are honest about their feelings because it's considered ok to express their feelings in Korean culture. On the countrary, people freom western country tend to hide how they really feel and wear fake smile and pretend there's nothing wrong.

Hi Mark! this content is fascinating. We hope you can visit the Philippines to do a documentation on the Filipinos mental health as well.
I am a Korean. Your video is very accurate. We worked hard to live, so we succeeded quickly, but there's a crack there. It's time to take care of the place.
One of the biggest issues in Korea is the tendency for parents to provide full support and direction for their children from birth until they enter the workforce. Perhaps one of the most shocking stories I've heard from a Korean friend exemplifies this. After being raised with such support, this friend, upon securing a job, asked their parents, "What should I do next?" This illustrates a profound lack of self-reliance, where individuals, even at the age of 30, may not know what they are good at or what they should pursue. In essence, many Koreans lack a sense of independence. Regrettably, based on my experiences, 7 out of 10 Korean friends find themselves in such a state of uncertainty. While it may be unpleasant, this underscores a persistent issue in Korean society and its current state
"Today, the country‚Äôs challenge has shifted. Koreans must look inward." This fucking hit home for me. This video explains the situation in the country better than most Koreans could, and that‚Äôs saying a lot coming from a Korean. Respect!

When my children were young they went to a private school with lots of Korean children.  The parents were very kind to us but extremely strict with their children.  It was very normal and accepted for them to expect all A‚Äôs from their children and they would punish for a B.  I couldn‚Äôt understand since I just wanted my children to love learning and do their best.  When they didn‚Äôt do well we just sat down and solved the problem with them, finding another way to teach the concept.  No shame or punishment.  This video helped me understand those parents and sympathize even more for the children.  I hope they use their resilience and hard work to tackle this cultural issue and lower the incidence of depression, anxiety and suicide.

ÏïÖÏùÑ Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú Í≥ºÏÜåÌèâÍ∞ÄÌïòÏßÄ ÎßàÏÑ∏Ïöî. ÏÑ†ÏùÄ Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú ÏïÖÏùÑ ÏïåÏßÄ Î™ªÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÏïÖÏù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÎëêÎ†§ÏõåÌïòÎäî Í±¥ ÏÇ∂Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú ÌñâÎ≥µÍ≥º Í±¥Í∞ïÌïú Í∏∞ÏÅ®, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏûêÍ∏∞ ÏûêÏã†Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú Î™ÖÌôïÌïú Ïù∏ÏãùÍ≥º ÏûêÏ°¥, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïã§Ï°¥ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. I always thought South Korea had all the problems of Japan but on steroids. And I think part of the reason Japan isn‚Äôt as bad anymore is because they‚Äôve been on the world stage for longer. Whereas Korea is a new kid on the block relatively. Maybe a decade and a half at this point. Japan has been held up to outside scrutiny for at least 3 decades. And granted Japan still has its problems they haven‚Äôt gone away but they seem more self aware about them than Korea does.
It‚Äôs so interesting seeing the different aspects of a culture that is completely different to yours. I was born and raised in Australia. Where Korea stigmatises and suppresses depression and anxiety, it is almost worn as a badge of honour in some aspects of Australian/western society. This is a great example of the best thing about something is often always the worst too.
Great video. I'm a Korean born and raised here for 27 years. The problems mentioned are all acknowledged, but many people still think nothing will change anyways, including me. Population is shrinking, and the younger generations are feeling lost right now. We feel like we lost our representation in the political system of this country. But watching your video, I realized that I myself is still lingering to the hope that things might get better here.
I'm American and I spent most of my adult life so far living in Korea. This video was so well done and on point and made me cry at the end. You really hit the nail on the head. It's the resilience, always finding a way through a willingness to move fast and adapt to change.
I'm Mainland Chinese, and everything you said in this video about the work ethics, the social pressure, the fierce competition in education and the level of anxiety... everything is also true herein China, despite vastly different political and economic systems and different contemporary history paths. I guess there's something rooted in our Eastern Asian genes about diligence, conformity, social hierarchy and so on.
Hope he didn't show up to the country with No Reservation
I think while almost everyone like the idea of 'The art of taking it easy', it's not a luxury that we/they cannot afford. I guess the same could be said for other countries as well in today's economy, but the truth is koreans (or rather older generations) overworking themselves is what helped Korea's economy the way it is. Meaning; overworking is quite literally saved them from poverty (aftermath of wars/colonization from japan), and that mindset just happened to carry over to this day. It doesn't help that South Korea relies heavily on other countries financially (trade/export) so they always need to be on their toes. It's why many koreans want N.Korea and S.Korea to unite, because the north has a lot of natural resources which  will allow us some freedom from being too dependent.

Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Í∑∏ ‚ÄòÏö∞Î¶¨‚ÄôÎäî Î∞òÎìúÏãú scapegoat, Ìù¨ÏÉùÏñëÏùÑ ÌïÑÏöîÎ°ú Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïò§Îûò Ïú†ÏßÄÎê† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî ÏßëÎã®ÏùÄ ÏïÑÎãôÎãàÎã§. Ï†ïÏã†Ï†Å Ïú†ÏÇ∞Ïùò Ï∏°Î©¥ÏóêÏÑ† ÏÑúÎ°úÍ∞Ä ÏÑúÎ°úÎ•º Ïû°ÏïÑÎ®πÏñ¥ÏÑú ÏûêÎ©∏Ìï† ÎÇòÎùºÏù¥Í≥† ÎØºÏ°±Ïù¥ÏóêÏöî.

I‚Äôm a second generation Gen X Korean living in the US. I cried watching this segment. ‚ù§
I truly enjoyed the video. What‚Äôs striking to me is in the entire 24-minute presentation, the ‚Äúlove‚Äù never came up‚Äîlove for self; love for others, etc. It‚Äôs almost like some weird dream where millions of folks are chasing after what ultimately leads to emptiness. Love ‚ù§
At first I wasn't going to watch this video because the title felt insulting without understanding. But after watching it, I think you did a nice job summing it up considering the different aspects of Korean society which has led them down this path. As a Korean American, I completely understand the pressures and stresses of Korean culture even though I grew up in the US. Korean parents raise their kids with the expectations of being #1 at everything. Korean parents are notorious for comparing their kids to kids in other families. This is one of the worse things you can do to your kid because it can make them feel insignificant and hopeless.  Despite this, Korean kids have honor and respect engraved in their heads, so they spend their entire lives trying to make their parents and society proud. But Korean parents are never satisfied. You're expected to keep grinding and striving to be the best. A never-ending sense of competition. This self-pressure that Korean people put on themselves is a big reason for the depression. And this depression leads to alcoholism, which then leads to deeper depression. It's a vicious cycle. The ending though gave me some hope... that the younger Korean generations are more open-minded and talking about issues in society.
You can feel the vibes there. At first when you arrive it‚Äôs glitzy and nice but after three days it‚Äôs wild. So depressing. Too many flashing lights
I lived in south korea for 2 years. 1 year in yungsan and 1 year in kunsan. Best thing that happened to me while I was in the army. 2010 feels so much closer than it actually is...I kinda want to go back...
As a South Korean student, this is a very eye-opening video. Confucianism is engraved in the older koreans' veins a lot more than foreign people think. Principles such as being together, respecting the elder and the higher positioned no matter how they are as a person, are present in not just companies and workplaces, but in families and schools as well. I was taught that these were etiquettes (Ex. Don't eat until the most elderly starts to eat) that apply to almost everywhere in South Korea. Also, constant competition seems to be an another problem that causes depression. I live in a region where academics is strongly emphasized by the environment. The biggest factor seems to be normal schools. Even when students have not thought about getting into good universities before, after seeing all these kids compare their scores with each other, talk about a CSAT math problem(in middle school), judging kids with academies they are attending, it's just really hard to ignore the feeling that you are behind everyone else, when you are really not. I also admit that I have thought that way when seeing kids who don't seem to be grinding as others seem to be. But a really harsh fact is that out of those grinding students, roughly 5-6% will get into universities that they are satisfied with. I am not saying that going to a lower-ranked university is a road to failure, but many korean students believe in that way. Students who are actually studying to reach their dreams are very few; others grind since they believe that going to a good university will guarantee them a good, stable life. That is why university of medicine is so popular here; doctors earn a lot of money, have a stable lifestyle, have social respect, and are able to work longer than most workers who are forced to retire at the age around 60. They feel depressed and worthless when they have worked so hard, but still fail to get accepted to a good university, which might lead to a long-term depression.  I can't really say anything about the Korean workplace since I am still a student, but I hope my fellow Koreans can overcome this deep cultural issue, young or old.
Thank you for doing this video. I‚Äôm Australian and I adore Korea and Koreans, I‚Äôve been there twice in the last 12 months, I really didn‚Äôt want to leave and I hope to retire there in a decade. They are wonderful people and it hurts to much to see the way people suffer there for all the reasons you outlined. I really feel that the younger generation will make big changes and for this reason I am hopeful for Korea‚Äôs future.
Hey mark. I really love if  you to do a video on india like you do in korea. The suicide rate among students in india is also rising.
Thank you for your kind and thoughtful video. For those who want to understand this topic a little deeper, I would like to mention the book <ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Ïùò ÌÉÑÏÉù>(The Birth of a Korean) by Hong Dae-sun, which was recently published in Korea.  In Korea, 70% of the country is mountainous and people had to live in a very harsh environment. It has four very distinct seasons, with very hot summers and very cold winters. So Koreans have always been hungry, not just during and after the Korean War, but for the thousands of years that Koreans have been on the Korean Peninsula. So they eat a huge variety of wild plants, they eat almost every part of the animal, they eat a huge variety of seaweed and seafood. They seem to believe that they can probably put almost anything in their mouth if it's organic. (Do you know what a "turtle hand" is?)  It's not just the geography, it's the political environment of having a huge other country, China, right next door that has made life difficult for Koreans for thousands of years. Westerners may not realize it, but South Korea has a completely different language and culture than China, and it shows in the fact that South Korea has managed to survive against China for thousands of years. Of course, it hasn't been easy. Every time China's dynasties changed, the new dynasty aimed to conquer the Korean Peninsula, sent many armies, and at times seemed to succeed, but in the end, all attempts failed. China and Korea eventually came to recognize each other's existence, albeit in a tributary relationship. However, the process left Koreans deeply stressed.  These two elements remain in the DNA of the Korean people. Due to the harshness of the environment, before the dawn of modern agriculture, Koreans went hungry and did whatever it took to survive. If you weren't hardworking, you weren't treated as a person. And the need to fight against the Chinese gave rise to a number of efficient strategies, which required the people to cooperate deeply. At least 100 or 1000 Chinese had to be exchanged for every Korean, so that Korea would not be destroyed.   If you met some Koreans in Korea who worked like crazy, to the point of death, and were never satisfied with themselves, that's perfectly normal, it's in their genes.   But I think that has to change with the times. Our system has reached its limits. Young Koreans are not having children anymore. I am married in Korea and have a stable income as a lawyer, but I have no intention of having children. For people who got married about 10 years earlier than me, there was a common perception that if you get married, you're going to have kids, but by the time I got married, that seemed to have diluted a little bit, and now I think it's become the default idea not to have kids. Even the number of people getting married has decreased.
As someone who has loved Korea, taught English to the very rich and poor, wrote product ads for prestigious companies and have had close, longterm relationships with several Koreans, I have to say that what you did here is spot on. I loved it. There is a darker side to what some of the elderly have to do to survive...although disturbing, I wish things like this would be brought out into the light as (hopefully) something might be done to fix this sad situation. Korea is in my heart, thoughts and prayers. I love this nation in a deep way.
Never thought I'd see someone cover my home country's problem. As someone who has effectively grown up in both the US, Australia, and Korea all the points in this video are 100% true Edit: I'm also a natural born Korean who's first language is Korean so I know the Korean side too well.
For decades, they worked hard and it paid off, because it is linear for a while. But once you hit the top, the rules for enriching yourself aren't about outworking anymore. It's more about being innovative, different, and different strategies.
We've become beyond depressed in various aspects of life here in Canada too. I hope everyone is well. Take care of your mental and physical health because I guarantee if you become disabled, you are automatically on the very bottom of the totem pole permanently unless you somehow are one of the rare lucky few to go into clinical remission (this, however, requires genuine healthcare, which is another terrifyingly sad situation we're experiencing currently given how the wealthy are trying to implement American privatization in that sector of public services.)
I read your book. Thank you Mark. Please make more content. üéâüéâüéâ
ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ ÏïÑÎèàÍπÅÏñ¥ÌçΩÏù¥ ÌÇ¨ÎßÅÌè¨Ïù∏Ìä∏ÏûÑ. Ïù¥Í±∏ ÏßÅÏ†ë Î≥¥Í≥† ÏûàÎäî, Î¨∏Ï†úÏ†êÏùÑ ÎäêÎÅºÎäî Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùÄ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù¥ ÎãπÎ©¥Ìïú Î¨∏Ï†úÏóê ÏÇ¨Î°úÏû°ÌòÄÏÇ¥ÏßÄ ÏïäÏúºÏãúÍ∏∏.
Now I am 21-year-old korean student. When I was in my third year of high school, I suffered from pressure and anxiety when I think about the past days for the CSAT. However, it was painful to know that my fate was reversed throughout the day. I studied very hard to go to a university in Seoul, but I cried for a month and wanted to die because I couldn't go to the university I wanted, let alone get the grades I wanted. Originally, I was supposed to enter a university at the age of 20, but I was preparing for the CSAT again, and I went to the academy from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day and ran 365 days without a break. However, when the grades I wanted did not do as well as I thought, I had despair and depression. Honestly, when I tried again, I thought I was a person who shouldn't do anything and thought of suicide. I still remember the day after I took the CSAT, and I was standing in the Han River for a long time thinking I was going to die. Korea is an academic society, so it competes fiercely to get a better university than others. There is still a high suicide rate among students for this reason. I still don't think this Korea education curriculum will be solved for the rest of my life.
I'm Korean living in an Europe. I could felt many things watching this documentary. Many thanks deeply. I got a say that we, Koreans SHOULD have done this JUST TO SURVIVE so far unfortunately. Nobody understands how our ancestors lived as a tiny country's people who suffered so many invasions, wars and even colonization by Japan. Nevertheless, Korean gets growing and gets great on our way. There's no country have no problem. I hope my country could get over these and get better no matter how.

I don't know (agree) about this DNA thing unless you mean it metaphorically, that is, figuratively. Anyway, what you highlight are the differences, the conflicts, etc, as is typical from the nationalistic propaganda point of view. There's us, and the rest of the world, and the victim card, etc. But the fact is that as Tokyo, Seoul and Beijing form a geographically compact axis comparable, for example, to London, Paris and Rome, or Berlin, what many fail to do, or even see, is to recognize the commonalities and shared characteristics. Those axes denote brother/cousin relationships, though one or the other culture is more deeply a "mother" (China in one case, Greco-Roman in the other). Hopefully someday (maybe BRICS will help) an Asian Union comparable to the integration in progress as the European Union, will become a reality. The question is, will the common currency be the BRICK (from BRICS) or some sort of Yuan/Yen/Won....YAN? üòâ

I enrolled in an online beginner Korean language class and the teacher is South Korean. He is pretty ok but he has a tendency to be sarcastic and put some of the students on the spot who can't understand on the get go what he is teaching. It's not a conducive atmosphere for learning, some of my classmates didn't even come back. I watch some Korean shows so I wasn't that shocked by what was going on. The teaching style is Confucian and he tries to make students compete against each other. I have questions but I end up looking for the answers on my own rather than have the unpleasant experience of being put on the spot for asking for clarification. Anyways, i just have 3 sessions left and I'll just finish them. Thank God I have a good sense of myself and am not a people pleaser otherwise i would have ended up depressed! I don't resent him, I am just accepting that he is like that cause that's how he grew up and that's what Korean society is like in general. I also found out that the reason why he gets all 5 stars on Google reviews is because he will give you a 30% discount for your next enrollment. He also has a very elementary grasp of the English language so it gets confusing sometimes since he starts rattling off in Korean. My goodness, it's a beginner Korean class he should know that his students might not understand what the hell he is saying even if it's a simple Korean sentence. Honestly, i feel like i got duped because of those google reviews. I'm still thinking if I'm going to leave an honest review on Google or chalk this up to experience and do my due diligence next time before spending my money. I don't want to end up hurting this guy even if he is abrasive and condescending.

I'm a Korean who has led the very streotypical(and also successful) life here so far and after my short experience living in America recently (I'm in my mid-twenties) i just can't stop thinking i'd like to flee from this fuxxing country asap. Whenever i'm asked why from people, it was hard to elaborate the reasons why I came to be tremendously tired of my home country where people all around the world are rather praising, but now it feels like i found some clues to explain my anxiety and depression that stem from the huge cultural and societal gaps between two countries. This video explains a lot about dark side of South Korean culture and society, and i wish more people especially more Koreans could watch this and acknowledge this two-faced aspects of their country. All the points that this video has mentioned are the factors that keep destroying my mental health while i'm living here, and i see myself leaving this country in a few years. Beautiful, beautiful video!! Good job! I even cried a littleüòÇ‚ù§ Absolutely loved it :) Thank you for looking into Korea with loving eyes and sharing it with all of us!
I am amazed that Mark could synthesize his insights into Korean society and the impact of history (particularly the 6/25 or Korean War) on our collective and individual narratives. As a Korean (albeit one who lives abroad), I am very proud of my heritage, my family's successes and struggles, and (most of all) our culture of resilience.   Like many Koreans in the comments, I have ambivalent feelings about the collateral damage of our economic, technological, and cultural success. One of my childhood friends lost his life to suicide and my cousins in Korea continue to struggle to find meaning and/or happiness in their daily lives. But despite these tribulations, I also believe that Korea is in a much better place than the US (where I currently live) to navigate these challenges because we have a shared framework of Confucian values that help us relate to one another and, generally speaking, be respectful of others while maintaining a social modesty that puts the collective ahead of our individualism. Confucianism certainly has its downsides (e.g., crushing conformity, and persistent patriarchy). Still, at least we have something that binds us and I believe that Koreans continue to maintain a faith that, in the worst of times, we will come together to solve our problems.   What concerns me is an erosion of this belief amidst wide(ning) economic inequality and the echo-chamber effects of the internet. Moreover, our declining birthrate likely necessitates reforms in our immigration system, along with changes in our cultural norms to facilitate a more heterogenous and inclusive society.   But we are an adaptable people, who combine k-pop with hip-hop, mix kimchi with tacos, and build class-leading products (e.g., electric cars, foldable phones), while maintaining a distinct identity and sense of self. Our national flower is the "mugunghwa," which is reputedly able to regrow and blossom despite being trampled or sown in difficult conditions.   I hope that we can be optimistic about our future, take better care of those who struggle, and be open to change.
As a Korean American with aspirations to return to the motherland, this is a very interesting and nuanced take.
Amazing video. I‚Äôve spent time with several Koreans & have got into Korean drama & music over the past decade. What I admire the most in their culture is their work ethic & unwavering spirit. Thank you for acknowledging that. They‚Äôve overcome a lot & that period of clawing their way to the top does have an effect both good & bad. Well balanced perspective.
I lived and worked in Korea, and recently came back to the EU. It was a good experience, but it made me appreciate things we take for granted in the EU much more, and amazing quality of life I have here. Still, this is not to say I do not like Korea and its people - on the contrary :)

The ego often creates contradictions within our desires and emotions, leading us into a state of inner conflict. In your example about the plants, the ego behaves in a way that can be described as an internal battle where desires are in conflict with each other.  Breaking down the contradictions the ego creates: "I don‚Äôt want plants because they‚Äôre a nuisance": The ego sees the plants as unnecessary disturbances. It might perceive them as obstacles that interfere with its space or comfort. In this moment, the ego rejects the plants because it wants to maintain control and power over its surroundings, rather than embracing harmony with them.  "I want coolness, but I destroy the plants": This is an ironic contradiction. Plants actually provide coolness and comfort, but the ego, in its desire to control the environment, might think that destroying the plants will ensure its personal space or comfort. However, this makes the situation worse‚Äîby destroying the plants, the coolness is lost, and the ego is left with even less comfort.  "I get even angrier": As the ego becomes frustrated and doesn‚Äôt achieve its goal (coolness), the anger intensifies. The ego is trapped in a vicious cycle‚Äîit tries to control and maintain power in situations where the better approach would be to seek balance or work with nature, but it refuses to because of its rigidity and desire to win.  The root cause: Lack of balance and self-awareness The ego often isn‚Äôt aware of its own inflexibility. It seeks instant gratification for its desires without thinking of the long-term consequences. In this example, instead of finding a solution that involves adapting to the surroundings, the ego responds with reactive and destructive behaviors that only worsen the situation.  The solution: Self-awareness and adaptability To break out of this contradictory cycle, the person needs to recognize their inner conflicts and make an effort to consider the long-term effects of their actions. In the case of the plants, they could realize that, instead of destroying them, they could adjust their space or find ways to release frustration without resorting to destructive behaviors.  The solution lies in compassion for the surroundings and learning to adapt rather than engage in a destructive struggle. Instead of destroying the plants out of ego, the person could accept their value in their life‚Äîthey provide coolness, clean air, and beautify the space. The ego would calm down if it recognized that natural balance and respect for others are key to its inner peace.  Conclusion: The ego loves contradictions because it does not allow for flexibility or understanding. Instead of adjusting to natural conditions or others, the ego tries to control and manipulate situations for its own benefit, often to the detriment of long-term harmony and balance. When a person begins to understand that true peace and fulfillment come from adaptation and compassion, rather than from struggle and destruction, they can begin to free themselves from the ego and start living a more harmonious life.

You got a wrong answer for 1/6 * 24 √∑ 64 (2/3+1/6) here how it should be :- 1/6 * 24 √∑ 64 (4/6 + 1/6) 1/6 * 24 √∑ 64 (5/6) 1/6 * 24 √∑ 64*5/6 4 √∑ 64 * 5/6 (4/64)*5/6 1/16*5/6 5/96   for more where ever you get (√∑ x) it simply means (*1/x) just by replacing it clears confusion in order to not to get two answer
¬†@shashank-sp¬† Thank You. This solved my confusion and I confirmed with chatgpt. The answer is 5/96

¬†@shashank-sp¬† Exactly! I am so surprised that people do not know the elementary rules of mathematics. If there is a task, for example, 8:2x5 - this means that FIRST you divide 8 by 2, and only THEN multiply the obtained result by 5.  A farmer has 8 small potatoes and plants two in a hole, each such bush will then yield 5 potatoes. This is what a math problem literally means. You must NOT break the sequence of mathematical operations. The correct answer is 20! NOT the fraction 4/5 And only 5/96 üëçis correct! NOT 3/40ü§¶

¬†@firstlast-pt5pp¬†:  No.  I had a discrete math 4+ decades ago in a course in college as part of my computer science with math emphasis degree.  Without looking it up, it was about math and formulas and problems about, basically, integers, if my 45ish year old memory of the class serves.   Looking it up for a more precise answer (Google):  Discrete math is about countable, distinct, and separate things (like integers, graphs, and logical statements), vs. things like continuous functions.  Google confirms this is useful for computer science today (which makes sense).   Discrete means "individually separate and distinct", BTW, and being on a computer, you could look that up as easily as me.
¬†@YPalsson¬†:  In the US it depends a LOT on where you go to school.  My public schooling was decent in science and math, but A work in the public schools was more like C plus work in the catholic private school system in my city (re various catholic friends in that system -- I lived near a catholic private education complex with K-12 schools).  If they switched from expensive private catholic to public, suddenly the C students became mostly A students.   And we had better private schools in my city than that.  If you combined a great education AND great aptitude and good help from parents or a tutor when needed, then any intelligent kid could do VERY well.   I coasted the whole way through public school because it was too easy, and so boring.  In high school I actually had to take a book home and STUDY for ONE course, with an old school very hard teacher -- chemistry.   The rest -- I did my 90% of my "studying" during lunch hour.    It's kind of sad, really, but if you're not challenged, the vast majority of kids won't PUSH.  So I studied things like chess that interested me on my own. If I had found out about computer science before my senior year of high school ('77), I would have been motivated to study that hard.  MUCH of life is largely a string of accidents.

showing working is literally to show the logic/method you used to arrive at your answer, except showing working is specifically the mathematical method.
you could write out what the 5th grader said and you would still get full credit though
it is showing your work, they‚Äôre practically just using first order logic apply some additional definitions and theorems without having to actually write a proof for it
everyone can use logic when they are taught about logic , The boy already knew how to solve the problem that's why he solved it quickly give him a new problem which he never solved then see what happens .
OTOH, you want someone who knows WHAT THEY ARE DOING (and be able to demonstrate the proper PROCESS), not guessing and perhaps getting lucky re intuition.  The Chinese kid could EXPLAIN and show his logic and process, which proved it wasn't just luck, which is FINE, IMO.   Plus if you make a small error and get the wrong answer but know the process and have the right idea down, you can earn the majority of the credit for the problem, by showing your work. ¬†@varadchougule6955¬†:  That's a valid point.  Like for the rabbits / chickens problem, the engineer (like me) knows how to combine equations algebraically, and solve for N unknown variables with N known linear equations. ¬†@rogergeyer9851¬† Rabbit/chicken problem is using Assumption Method (or the Supposition Method).  It's a common Maths problem for Primary school kids in Singapore too.

Shouldn't the last answer be 10pi because perimeter of rectangle made will be equal to length of circumference which is 2pi(10/2)
¬†@alphachad69¬† correct so if r doesnt = to 1 then the circumference is not 2pi
¬†@alphachad69¬† The solution basically 2*pi*r in this case: 2*pi*5=10*pi. | If you If now you take those 2 halves of the circle and divide them into n slices and then put them like in the video it will be a rectangle, but a rectangle isn't just 2 horizontal parallel sides (a), but it has 2 vertical sides. 1 on the right and 1 on the left. Now how long are these, well since we used slices with r=5 then the vertical sides (b) are 5 long. and since there are two of them it'll be 5+5=10! So now we have 10*pi+ (the 2 sides b) = 10*pi+5*5= 10*pi +10, from this we can deduct that the circumference of the circle is 10 longer than before.  Hope this helps!
My class graded me based on how how close I got to the answer based on my work. So if I added something when I was supposed track my question would still receive partial credit for everything else!

I think you completely misunderstand if you think that there's a massive difference between what the child did and the Engineer. What the engineer did, allows anyone, regardless of intellect, to be able to solve that question. What the child did, requires a pretty strong understanding of logic that isn't just bound to math, what he did has more to do with pattern recognition and overall intellect. It's not something you can just teach someone, especially at his age. In fact, learning math and showing your solution can actually HELP you develop the type of logic and intellect required to solve something like he did.   I'm all for critiquing schools in how they teach, using the last decade or two of scientific research, we can clearly tell that current curriculums are very un-optimised for the human brain. But this partuclar instance is not something that is the fault of the school, as either it's something you're genetically inclined for, or you simply have done a lot of logical training (such as math, certain games, chemistry/physics, puzzles and so on).   What you definitely can critique modern school for though is how we have (at least in the western world) moved away from geometry as a teaching tool. If you go back into older mathmatics, geometry was the #1 methods to discuss and teach math. Precisely because it gives the learner a way to make numbers more tangible. This however doesn't remove the need to "show your work", it simply is just a better way to practice/learn. The reason we moved away from geometry is because the math got too complex to be expressed through geometry but for 95% of the world they will never need that level of math anyway.

Technically, the moon does not appear during a solar eclipse. You are seeing a silhouette of a moon.
¬†@tichu7¬† Idk if this is a reference to a song or whatever but if you are being legit, in a solar eclipse the moon is still present it‚Äôs just not illuminated by the sun
¬†@mrbagginz5963¬† Exactly. It doesn't appear.  We know it's there because of the absense of light, not because of the presence of it.

Had a lot of fun filming this one. Want to highlight a couple points: - was really fascinating to see the difference in ways of thinking. I look back and almost overcomplicated everything, and it's interesting to see that my brain went straight to formulas while that kid had a more simple approach. I think that way of thinking really was etched into me in University and I probably would have just thought about the problem from a non formulaic angle prior to engineering school ü§î no way is right or wrong - it's just interesting to see how university influenced me to go straight to one default way of looking at problems.   2) btw let's appreciate how impressive that kid was. Fun Fact: The Final question is the question that led to the invention of calculus. Greeks trying to understand circles and their properties led to the discovery of concepts like imaginary numbers, and that started a chain of discoveries that would end up with calculus.
I love they are taught the foundations of maths and work anything with this principles. True understanding and a powerful tool.
Last question everyone got wrong.. "how much longer will the rectangle be from the circe?" Does not ask about the PERIMETER of the rectangle. Asks about the length. The length of the rectangle as drawn is the long side, The "diameter" of the circle will serve as its length. Circle "length" is 10. Rectangle length is half the perimeter of the circle, which is (2 * pi * r) / 2, or 5 * pi. So the rectangle is 5 * pi (rectangle length) / 10 (circle "length"), or pi/2 times longer than the circle.
18:20 That is actually taught in middle school. You don't realize how much basic knowledge you have forgotten until you see it again in elementary or middle school textbooks.

No way you passed calculus without being able to solve the last one.
Formulas are fine. They're generic ways to solve problems.  Sure you can apply other techniques like that chicken and rabbit problem. But, that's just another technique (or formula) that's less generic than expressing it as a simultaneous equation.  With the minimum perimeter/area question, I knew it'd be a circle because that's why many things naturally form spheres in life (e.g. water droplets minimizing surface area), but I would have double checked my intuition by writing out all the areas as well.  With the circle question, which was terribly worded, using formulas would have done the same thing once you recognize that the length of the rectangle is half the circumference. The kid was familiar with the concept of slicing a circle into a rectangle (often seen in deriving the area of a circle assuming you know the diameter) so he was able to use that to intuitively answer it.  Intuitive shortcuts are cool but they're specialized at solving a particular type of question. What's impressive from the kid is that he's familiar with all these shortcuts and was able to apply it all within seconds in his head.
¬†@Nil-js4bf¬† It took me two seconds on that circle question. The others I'd be solving through equations.
Same here.  But unless you're some kind of genius or specialist in the subject, I think 99% of westerners would go straight to the PROCESS they learned in school.  The fact that the kid had the completely different approach means he was TAUGHT that and likely DRILLED in that, to be able to handle it so naturally / easily.   Just my opinion, of course.   What we don't know is, is this kid fairly normal in China, or is he a prodigy?  If he's a prodigy I feel better -- we had some scary smart kids in ordinary public school in math and science -- they were just pretty rare.
‚Äã¬†@Nil-js4bf¬†Exactly, the child's question was more a type of memorization of concepts, but analyzing and deducing the answer is more complex than that, hence the child's ease and speed in answering

@Chun350¬† Not exactly. It's a very long process that found it's origins in tbe Greeks as I said. Basically the. Trying to understand concepts like imaginary numbers is what snowballed into full blown calculus.

@ "ur also wrong tho"üòÇ yes you are right i redo my calc and find out that i should dived by 2 but ur answer is right if you understand  the question like that but actually the question is about the difference between the perimeter and yes it is 10 if you calculate it, the wrong was in the way they asked the question.
¬†@SleepyPlanzZ¬† The question is a bit weirdly worded imo. My best guess for what it's asking is "what's the difference between the rectangle's perimeter and the circle's radius". To help visualize, imagine a sliced pizza pie. If you take the slices and align them,  alternating facing up and down, you get something approximating a rectangle (not really exactly though, that'd require infinite slices). The crust can be viewed as both the circumference of the pie, and also sum of the top and bottom of the "rectangle". Both of the remaining sides of the rectangle are just sides of a slice, which equals the radius of the pie. Since there are two sides, added together they equal the diameter. This means the perimeter of the rectangle equals the circumference plus the diameter of the circle, therefore the difference between the perimeter and circumference is just the diameter, which is given as 10.
This is why "√∑" is generally avoided in higher math. Too ambiguous.

11:03 Wait a minute, you can always see a part of the Moon during partial eclipses (either Lunar or Solar). During total solar eclipses, the Moon is in front of the Sun and hides it. During total lunar eclipses, the Moon is behind the Earth which blocks the sun rays and so the Moon appears dark red through gamma rays (best answer in my opinion). The only time a Moon might not be visible would be if it‚Äôs hidden by an object in the sky or maybe during a new Moon phase when it lays between the Sun and the Earth.

I believe the question at 10:21 is incorrect, the correct answer should be 5/96. This is because the 64(2/3+1/6) counts as multiplication and is not included in the brackets, so you would move left to right in order of operations. Then you get: 4/64 (5/6)  = 1/16 (5/6)  = 5/96

¬†@argute_s¬† No you can't. A math problem can only be correctly solved in two different ways if the result is identical! In this case, you are talking about solving two DIFFERENT examples in the same way - using the appropriate order of operations. If the parentheses are changed, a new example is created, giving a different solution. (1/6 x 24) / (64(2/3+1/6)) and 1/6 x 24 / 64(2/3+1/6) are two different examples which requires two different order of operations and giving two different answers each.
Thank GOD someone else said it  It ticks me off just how many people take ‚ÄúPEMDAS/BOMDAS‚Äù too literally to the point they psych themselves out of the correct order
what was involved there was implicit multiplication, 64(5/6), which takes place before explicit multiplication or division, so 64(5/6) needs to be done first  u can also visually think of 64(5/6) grouped together just like how they're all in parentheses as the numbers are "closer together"
64 ain't in the brackets lmao, there's a multiplication between them but it is not necessary to use it since it won't cause confusion ‚Äã¬†@Don-bo7lp¬†
‚Äã@GDPlainAif there is a division right before it you are required to include a parantheses like x=3 6√∑3x is equal to 6 but 6√∑(3x) is equal to 1
¬†@lastorderx20001¬† implicit multiplication does not require them all to be grouped in parentheses so 6√∑3x=2/3. you have to consider 3x as "a term" due to implicit multiplication. as such, implicit multiplication comes before explicit multiplication or division as i previously mentioned
@GDPlainA You are speaking nonsense because we use "__"  in algebric equations. For example 15√∑3x=1 would still be solved with OoO; 15√∑3=5, 5x=1 and x=1/5. What you want to convey here is 15 over 3x=1 which is obviously different since it is equivalent to including a paranthesis. If you wanna see how objectively wrong your solution is, you can simply ask an advanced ai or google

This is proof based on scientific research about implicit multiplication, so it truly does exist and it is not wrong. ‚Äã¬†@Amy_skz0325¬† the order of operations is just a matter of convention, in fact a very simple convention could be go right to left as you accumulate the operators which would yield a different answer, so multiple answers are possible depending on the convention used. its generally best to use brackets wherever possible to denote the order of operations
¬†@argute_s¬† why would you make this assumption out of thin air
