¬†@valenliu6458¬† Exactly! I am so surprised that people do not know the elementary rules of mathematics. If there is a task, for example, 8:2x5 - this means that FIRST you divide 8 by 2, and only THEN multiply the obtained result by 5.    A farmer has 8 small potatoes and plants two in a hole, each such bush will then yield 5 potatoes. This is what a math problem literally means. You must NOT break the sequence of mathematical operations. The correct answer is 20! NOT the fraction 4/5!
¬†@aisolutionsindia7138¬† But in this case we are talking about a unified generally accepted  convention in all schools. And according to it, the answer given by both of them IS WRONG.
¬†@Amy_skz0325¬† the problem with that approach is that it restricts creative thinking and the ability to grapple with unknowns, not a desirable outcome while teaching math.. for example there are programming languages that would interpret 7+3*4 as 40 instead of 19, i think this flexibility should be passed on to learners as well, if not you still got brackets
¬†@aisolutionsindia7138¬† well, no. In no way do I think it limits creative thinking. In arithmetic (and programming) it is necessary to follow an algorithm. One comma in the wrong place throws an error. Of course, part of the work is related to creativity, AND ANOTHER part is related to FOLLOWING GENERALLY ADOPTED RULES. Both are important.
¬†@Don-bo7lp¬† if you had an addition or subtraction sign you would be correct but in this case it counts as a multiplication so its left to right
@GDPlainA Did you read your own source?? The article claims that in some contexts, implicit multiplication might take precedence over division. However, the only proof it provides is a reference to the Style and Notation Guide for Physical Review (a scientific journal), which allegedly suggests treating implicit multiplication as having higher precedence.  This is not a mathematical proof‚Äîit‚Äôs just an editorial convention used in a specific publication. Scientific journals sometimes adopt non-standard notation rules for clarity in their field, but that does not change the actual order of operations in mathematics.  No rigorous mathematical source (such as textbooks, mathematical organizations, or formal logic) supports the idea that implicit multiplication should override division. This claim is entirely based on editorial preference in some niche cases, not on mathematical correctness.

On the last question, my understanding of the answer is this: think of the circle like a pizza and the rectangle like all the pizza slices lined up together  with the crusts facing the outside. Kind of like a mouth full of sharp teeth that is closed. The question is how much longer is the overall perimeter of the rectangle shape than the circumference of the pizza. We also know that the pizza is ten inches wide, which means that every slice is five inches long.  If you think about it, the only difference between the circle pizza and rectangle arrangement is that the length of a slice of pizza is exposed on the right and left side. Since we know the length of a pizza slice is 5 inches and there are two exposed sides, the difference in length is 5+5, or 10.

3/40 is wrong answer.. √ó and without brackets should be done in order.. so 64√ó(...) done before "√∑64" is a mistake.. to avoid this tipe of mistakes is usually recomended to revrite each division like a fraction and solve product in order: 1/6√ó24√ó1/64√ó(5/6)= (24√ó5)/(6√ó64√ó6)=5/96

10:21 The answer is 5/96 There's a common misconception about parenthesis, it's true that we have to do whatever the operation is "INSIDE" the bracket first, but when we are done, we treat the bracket as a simple multiplication and don't give it priority.  After every operation INSIDE the bracket is done, the bracket becomes multiplication and we move left to right doing the operations   Edit: For People Asking for solution 1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64 ( 2/3 + 1/6 ) Do the bracket 1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64 ( 5/6)  This can be written as 1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64 √ó 5/6 Go from Left to Right  = 4 √∑ 64 √ó 5/6 = 1/16 √ó 5/6 = 5/96  For reference I used Wolfram Alpha to cross check and bprp's yt video on order of operations.  Edit 2: I directly claim the ans is 5/96 cuz I have proof. Try to put out your beliefs or atleast don't provide baseless accusations.
Actually, engineers solve the problem directly. That schoolboy solved logical way.
10:22 You both are wrong because you forgot that according to PEMDAS/BODMAS you have to calculate from left to right if there are no brackets left. The real answer is 5√∑96
14:25 The 5th grader took a shortcut here, and he used the difference of the least possible legs and the target number of legs, and then divided that difference by the difference of the number of legs of the rabbits and the chickens. The college graduate took the long route of turning everything into variables, then solving for them (using two equations with two variables), but it works all of the time, not just specifically for this problem, which shows the kid's school prioritizes trick questions, while the college the graduate took prioritized more important and usable maths and logic.
16:50 As a nerd, it is my duty to inform you that the plural of radius is radii.
14:20 This is a fun problem. I did R=4 and C=2. 4x10 = 40 (finding the most legs possible) 40 - 32 = 8 (finding how many legs over 32 I have) 8 / 2 = 4 (finding the chickens I need to reduce the total down to 32) thus C = 4, R = 6 (6*4 + 4*2 = 24 + 8 = 32)

@onlytoxicness Dude whatt??? When theres parenteses next to number or variable and theres no sign, it means multiplication. Thats literally a notation rule.
@zumulie6324 PEMDAS or BODMAS both involve REMOVING bracket when solving, before moving on. Hence if there is no sign, we have to open the bracket, getting (320/6) which can be simplified to (160/3)
@onlytoxicness No it doesnt. PEMDAS or BODMAS involve solving the brackets. That means (2/3 + 1/6) = (5/6) the brackets are already solved so u can just write it as 4 √∑ 64 √ó 5/6. The brackets, without any operation inside them just means multiplication. Thats literally a NOTATION RULE and u can look up on it.
‚Äã¬†@zumulie6324¬†Actually , there's a difference between brackets and multiplication. That person is right , if there's so sign then bracket is completely solved first . I mean it is multiplied with 64 and then the whole product is divided . For ex:  8√∑2(2+2)=1 But  8√∑2√ó(2+2)=16 .  It's simple .
‚Äã¬†@bhaveshsinghbisht¬†fun fact! That's not right! While usually multiplication and division have the same precedence, implied multiplication often has a higher priority. The problem is that there is no standard way of solving it, and every author chooses to either consider implied multiplication more important or not.  When it is explicit, however, the order is clear.  So, what you've said is not a general convention in regards to the order of operations (and, to be fair, one I also disagree with)
I also think 3/40 is not correct. 5/96 is the right answer and that‚Äôs the answer any computer will give you
There's nothing about the notation that says: 1/B(C) = 1/(BC) [wrong] That's not how it works. The notation can be ambiguous, but as written it's: 1/B(C) = (1/B)(C)
¬†@bhaveshsinghbisht¬† you have different notations in operations: Addition="a+a"; Subtraction="a-a"; Multiplication="a.a" "a(a)" "axa" and Division="a/a" "a√∑a". ALSO, addition and substraction go last, multiplication and division go first, but between multiplication and division there isn't any hierarchy, between both you solve first the one on the left. The same between addition and substraction, first the one on the left. In your case, 8√∑2(2+2) or 8√∑2x(2+2) you first resolve the bracket, THEN you have 3 terms "8"√∑"2"("2") or "8"√∑"2"x"2", that last brackets are unnecessary so you replace the form 2(2) for 2.2 or 2x2 now you have two operations one division and one multiplications there isn't a hierarchy so you start form the left. 16 is the only answer.
¬†@Juli√°nLucicMaljkovic¬† implied multiplication has the problem of ambiguity. It is a part of notation that is like that. Both interpretations are correct, that is giving precedence to implied multiplication or not.  That's because things like 1/2x exist, and in this case implied multiplication takes precedence.   I believe that, most often, implied multiplication takes precedence, only when the second member (sorry, I haven't learnt maths in English, only in Italian, so my terminology is not great) is a monomial expression, while parenthesis would immediately stop that priority.
What no I got the same ans i solved it uk 3 ppl won't make the same mistake!!
@tuluppampam 1/2x is ambiguous because there is no metric for what the "/" applies to. In written notation, you can clearly place the x with the 2 in the denominator or you can clearly place the 1/2 beside the x. That's the exact problem the obelus has, where there's no clear measure of what it applies to. It must apply to the very next number or letter, but everything after that is ambiguous. That's why the obelus is avoided in higher math.  1/2x = (1/2)x OR 1/(2x)  It's ambiguous and must be better specified. Likewise, 1√∑2(x) can be (1/2)x OR 1/(2x). It's very much ambiguous. I'm actually surprised all three arbitrarily decided on the same way to solve it.
Okay I rewatched that part and looked through the kid's work out. It seems like he puts some paratheses around 64 and a second one behind 1/6. If that was the question given then I agree with the answer. With the question put up on screen I still believe my answer is right though.
They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together. Also Casio calculators would get you their answer.

The problem is that implicit multiplication (i.e. 64(5/6)) is treated ambigously.  If I told you 1/2x you'd probably treat 2x as the denominator, and in this case multiplication has precendence.  I only give implicit multiplication priority with monomial factors, otherwise I treat it as normal multiplication.  But there are reasons to claim that implicit multiplication should have priority, with which I disagree.

It is my duty, as a nerd, to inform you that the plural of radius may be both radii and radiuses. That is because one follows, by analogy, English rules, while the other is directly from Latin.  I would say, however, even as a massive fan of Latin, that the plural radiuses is, to an extent, a more "correct" option, as that is what appears in speech.  Radii appears much less in speech, although much more in writing, which is more than enough to give it validity

Ok but the answer to 1/6 x 24 √∑ 64 (2/3 +1/6) is 5/96 not 3/40. I was pretty sure but to double check, I put it through chatgpt and wolfram alpha. They also got 5/96. Here‚Äôs what chatgpt thinks happened:   The correct answer is 5/96, as confirmed by both manual calculations and Wolfram Alpha. Here‚Äôs where the contestants likely went wrong:  Order of Operations Error: The problem involves both multiplication and division, which must be handled strictly from left to right. Failing to follow this order could lead to an incorrect answer.  Fraction Mismanagement: When multiplying fractions like (1/16) * (5/6), you simply multiply the numerators and denominators: (1 * 5) / (16 * 6) = 5/96. An error in this calculation or simplification likely caused the wrong result.  Simplification Issues: Simplifying too early or incorrectly, such as during the step 4 / 64, might have led to incorrect fractions or skewed results.  If you follow the math step by step, the correct answer is 5/96, not 3/40. It‚Äôs important to handle order of operations carefully and work accurately with fractions! üòä

Guys, I don't understand the circle problem at 15:40 . The question is talking about the length of rectangle.  So, the length would be circumference √∑ 2 because the circle is cut into triangular slices which is put in both sides equally to make a rectangle.    Diameter = 10 cm  Radius = 10 cm √∑ 2 = 5 cm  Circumference = 2*œÄ*r = 2*œÄ*5 cm = 37.699... cm   Then the length of rectangle would be, 37.699 cm (circumference) √∑ 2 which is around 15.7 cm. Using BODMAS, 1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64(2/3 + 1/6) =1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64(4/6 + 1/6) =1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64(5/6) =1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 320/6 =4 √∑ 320/6 =4 √ó 6/320 =24/320 =3/40

10:14 why do they first multiply 64 by the number in parentheses, and only then divide 4 by this result? sequence is important in math, multiplication does NOT take precedence over division. So, first you need to divide 4 by 64, and only THEN multiply this result by the fraction in brackets ... and you will get another answer - the CORRECT answer 5/96
The solution to the math problem in minute 10 it‚Äôs not 3/40 but it‚Äôs 5/96. When you have multiplication and division you have to follow the order from left to right.

the question comparing circumference and perimeter (the last one i think), was worded horribly.  length is a dimension, a property of a rectangle. you cannot use it to refer to circumference and perimeter interchangeably, when it doesnt refer to either of those.  you should have asked "how much longer is the perimeter of the rectangle, than the circumference of the circle."  which is easy because i know it will be 2w longer, and the width must be equal to the radius, which is d/2, making the answer 10.  i actually did the math quickly bc i wanted to see how long it would take, when i got 15.7 - 10 (or [10*(pi/2)] - 10) and saw that the correct answer was 10, i thought i had lost my mind.

If it is, it's not 10.??? I don't understand.  i get it now. the question should be '' how much longer is the rectangle's PERIMETER from the circle's PERIMETER.''
For those wondering about the last question. It‚Äôs a comparison of circumference and total perimeter. The ‚Äúrectangle‚Äù is formed by let‚Äôs say dividing the circle into 4 equal parts (cool) and running them upward and downward facing next to eachother. Then the length is 2 on the top and 2 on the bottom. The sides added together is just the radius. In this case, we have a diameter of 10-so circumference is 10 PI. For the ‚Äúrectangle‚Äù-10 PI is cut into two (5 PI on the top, 5 PI on the bottom) so we still have 10 PI. BUT, you are adding two radiuses together (5 and 5 on each side when doing a perimeter calculation) for a total of 10 more.   If you had more than 4 parts, eventually this would converge on a rectangle as the curvature of each respective pi gets flatter and flatter and infinitely smaller.m width for each triangle. Say for example we had 200 pieces, each triangle cutout when facing and stacked next to next triangle cutout in the sequence has less and less curve and the sides get flatter. This is basically an integral.  Anyways super impressive to see a little kid come up with this , and I think the question could‚Äôve been framed better to be fair. I think this shows how kids simple thinking sometimes exceeds our overcomplicating thoughts as adults.
Aww man i love these type of content! Very educating and entertaining at the same time

Both you are right. In western math system, multiplication (*) and division (/) have the same precedence and are processed from left to right. But in the Chinese system, multiplication should do first, before division. So their logic probably was 1/6*24=4, 65*(2/3+1/6)=160/3. And then 4/(160/3)=3/40
To be honest, I had heard that Chinese math education had already updated the rules since computers are using the western rules, maybe haven‚Äôt??

If there is a task, for example, 8:2x5 - this means that FIRST you divide 8 by 2, and only THEN multiply the obtained result by 5.  A farmer has 8 small potatoes and plants two in a hole, each such bush will then yield 5 potatoes. This is what a math problem literally means. You must NOT break the sequence of mathematical operations. The correct answer is 20! NOT the fraction 4/5 *And ONLY 5/96 is correct üòã

¬†@albertchen247¬† The "rectangle" is an approximation.  To be precise, the resulting shape is some shape with curvy edges, and you want to compare its perimeter against that of the original circle.
Yes. You are correct, will be curvy and hard to calculate.  However, the thinner the slice you cut the circle, the straighter the curved edges will be.  Imagine if you cut it into infinitely thin slices, the curved edge will appear to flattened out and more and more appropriate a rectangle when you combine the slices. ‚Äã¬†@albertchen247¬†
¬†@albertchen247¬† the more you split the circle into slices, the less curve the length of the arcs will have. so if you cut the slices into infinitely small pieces and arrange them into said rectangle, there will be no curve.

¬†@rogergeyer9851¬† (tldr at the end) i understand that in this case, a pizza will indeed not form a straight line IN REAL LIFE, but i think you are overthinking.   The choice of a pizza is purely for illustration, its just a model that doesn't really affect the math.   The same question could use strings or metal wires, in which case you just straighten out the string into a line (it would result in a completely straight line with no curves). Thats the main point of the question.   While it is true that they should have used a string in the first place as that would be more accurate, i think they decided on the pizza to help the kid solve the question, as its easier to visualise the extra diameter of the rectangle (its 2 breadths) to be the diameter of the pizza (10), so the kid could also get the answer with a bit of critical thinkimg and without much math. In the end, the pizza was just a model of illustration.   You can definitely flatten the pizza edges into a straight line in real life, and even if it still does have curves, it will be so insignificant it will not affect the maths.  Also, if it still bugs you that pizza arranged in real life would form curves (even though the curves are insignificant),  you can definitely get straight lines from pizza crust irl, you just have to cut out only the crust. You can watch veritasium's video about pi, where he cuts out just the crust and straightens it (like it was a string), it can be straightened.  TLDR: curves of the pizza are insignificant and can be ignored

11:07 isn't the correct answer a lunar eclipse? a partial eclipse, by definition, just a skewed version of a solar or lunar eclipse (where the sun or moon, respectively, are not fully covered). A solar eclipse is when the moon covers the sun (aka the moon is VERY visible), and a lunar eclipse is when the earth stands between the moon and the sun, blocking all light from reaching the moon and making it effectively invisible. So, an eclipse where the moon is not seen would be best described as a lunar eclipse, no? In any case, the worst answer is by far a partial eclipse.

Actually 3/40 is wrong, the correct answer is 5/96. Multiplications and divisions have to be resolved from left to right, and there‚Äôs no other hierarchical order between the 2, and numbers next to parentheses just indicate a multiplication, the only difference is that the sign is implicit, they still share the same priority of any other multiplication.

15:39 The question is not phrased properly. According to this question, the answer is: 5pi - 10  The question they meant to ask was this:  Given that the diameter of the circle is 10, how much longer will the rectangle's perimeter be from the *circle's perimeter*?  Then yes, the answer is 10.

10:48 The answer should be none of these. A solar eclipse is a phenomenon where the Moon blocks the Sun. The Moon, though is dark, is still visible since you can still see it cover the Sun. A lunar eclipse is a phenomenon where light from the Sun is blocked by the Earth. It's still visible due to Rayleigh scattering. "Partial eclipse" as an option is really broad. It can either refer to Partial Solar Eclipse or Partial Lunar Eclipse, but the Moon is still visible in both of these events.

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together.

The question didn‚Äôt state the number of pieces. It‚Äôs supposed to be an answer that applies to any number of pieces.
It would still work for any amount of pieces. We can call the number of pieces P, the radius r, and the circumference 2 * pi * r. The arc length would be (2 * pi * r)/ p and the width of the rectangle is always the arc length of the circle times p/2 so the length = ((p/2) * 2 * pi * r)/ p which simplifys to pi * r and the length of the rectangle is always r so now the perimeter is 2 * pi * r + 2 * r and plugging in the circumference of the circle is 2 * pi * r and d = 2 * r, the perimeter of the rectangle is always the circumference of the circle plus its diameter.
The length of the rectangle actually is 15.7units.  Reason: the circumference of the circle=2œÄr as diameter is 10 so radius=5. So, C=2*3.14*5=31.4units.   As one side of the rectangle is half of the circle's circumference so half circumference would be 15.7 units which is the length of the rectangle.
Yes, I said the width is 5 pi, the length is the radius of the circle
eh.. they both had logic but different kinds. The kid had good logic but also encountered lots of familiar problems which gave him a bit of an advantage  Sheldon used "formulas" which are really just definitions of circumference of a circle? And he's able to piece it together to use it to inform his problem solving, not replace it. But it's a bit more a rigorous first pricniples approach which is typically what academia and professionals want, instead of just quick one line "trick" finding. This is better because it actually justifies mathematically from axioms which is the better solution in general, and is good for unfamiliar axiom sets  Also the last question is a bit of a trick. Probably lost in translation, but it DOES matter how many sectors are cut out. If it approaches infinity, then sure it's a rectangle. Otherwise you can't really call it a rectangle b/c of the non zero curvature. I think that's what tripped Sheldon up because he assigned some different variable to what the straight amount was instead of just assuming it was infinite sectors and therefore a straight line and just adding up to a circumference  The latter treatment also requires extreme care in mathematics and a strong grasp of limits and maybe even defining things similar to a Riemannian sum. This is why rigor is important  But of course he could've also just played it smart and realized he was doing elementary school problems
They are both using formulas and you can only use formulas by applying logic anyway. But the kid is dealing with these kind of simple abstract problems frequently and recently, so intuition kicks in right away, while the engineer probably doesn't wrestle with these formulas as often anymore. Also he was probably looking to express the answer as a formula for all diameters while the kid had more of a math competition approach of just outputting the answer.
You don't need pi. However many segments the circle is cut into the curved edges at the end of the segments were all part of the perimeter of the circle, so they must add up to the perimeter (Circumference) of the circle? = C Those curved  edges form the long sides of the rectangle. The number of segments doesn't matter. The Short sides of the rectangle are each the straight side of a segment, which is the radius of the circle  . The circumference (Perimeter) of the circle is C The perimeter of the "rectangle is" C + r+r = C + 2r The difference is (C+2r) - C= 2r = D.... and we Know D= 10

10:01 The expression is not well-defined; do you want to have $1/6 \times 24$ divide $64$ first then times $(2/3+1/6)$, or first compute $a := 64(2/3+1/6)$ then divide $1/6 \times 24$ by $a$?  11:49 All you have to compare is the area of the square and the area of the circle. Given they all have the same perimeter, it is obvious that the square has the largest area among the three quadrilaterals (this is just calculus, if you think about these quadrilaterals as deformation of the square, the area function maximizes at the square). Now without loss of generality assume the perimeter is 4, so that the square has area 1. The circumference formula implies the circle has radius 2/\pi, so it has area \pi (2/\pi)^2 = 4/\pi >1, QED

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together.

When you have a number next to an equation in parentheses, it means that number is essentially distributed to each component of the equation in parentheses.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributive_property  Therefore, PEMDAS says 64(2/3 + 1/6) is the same as 64(2/3) + 64(1/6) = 128/3 + 64/6 = 256/6 + 64/6 = 320/6 = 160/3. Alternatively you could just do it the easy way 64(2/3+1/6) = 64(4/6+1/6) = 64(5/6) = 320/6 = 160/3.   so then you have 1/6*24 / 160/3 = 4 / 160/3 = 4 * 3/160 = 12/160 = 3/40 FINAL ANSWER   this equation is NOT meant to be solved left to right
‚Äã¬†@jg8115¬† Thank you for your effort. I ignored the division and treated the equation as multiplication. Basically calculating:  1/16 * 5/6 instead of: 4 / 64 * ( 5/6), solving 64*(5/6) first

I am a European, and here, the average level of educational difficulty is generally quite high. I believe that the main difference between the "Western" (or at least European) method and the Chinese one is that they tend to apply logic extensively to problem-solving, effectively "bypassing" numerical difficulties and focusing on memorizing the logical processes behind a specific category of exercises.  Here, on the other hand, we almost always work with numbers, formulas, theorems, statements, etc., and then apply these elements practically. With the first approach, students can tackle more complex problems at a younger age, while the second method follows a more gradual progression.  However, I believe that, in the end, both approaches can lead to excellent results by the end of a school education‚Äîprovided they are used intelligently and in the right way.

So, for the last question, if you cut the circle on infinite ammount of sectors and bind them together we will receive very close aproximation to rectangle with small side equal to R of circle and unknown long side. However the AREA of both shapes will be equal, since they are composed of the same parts. We know that circle area is pi*R^2, and we also know that each sector is from center to periphery (radius) so the missing side becomes pi*R^2=r*X, we know that R will be 5, so (25pi/5)=x so X is 5*pi. As far as the question, I simply do not understand what 'longer from a circle' means... The only way you can reach the answer 10 is if the question means How much longer the P of the rectangle will be, comapred to P of circle. And using our previous calculations it will follow that P of the rectangle is 2*5+2*5*pi, 10 + 10pi and the P of circle is 2*pi*5 which is 10 pi and we can see that the first expression is greater than the second by 10.... However the wording of the question was quite bad in english...
The moon question is not C actually, it's A in a total solar eclipse. In a partial eclipse, the moon in a partial eclipse is partially visible.

15:40  Based on the image, it looks like you're referring to unrolling a circle into a nearly rectangular shape by cutting it into triangular sections. This suggests an approximation of the circumference as the length of a rectangle while using the radius as the height.  Given: Diameter of the circle = 10 ‚Üí Radius (r) = 5 Circumference of the circle =  2ùúãùëü=10ùúã 2œÄr=10œÄ  Interpretation from the Drawing: When the circle is "unrolled," it forms an approximate rectangle where: The length ‚âà circumference = 10ùúã 10œÄ ‚âà 31.42 The height = radius = 5  Answer: The rectangle will be approximately 31.42 units long, which is significantly longer than the circle's diameter (10).

Looks like they‚Äôre both wrong on 1/6*24/64(2/3+1/6) Someone correct me if I missed something, but the answer should be 5/96.  Explanation: Since multiplication and division get the same priority in PEMDAS, they‚Äôre done in the order they appear from left to right. That means you‚Äôd have to combine (1/6)*24, then divide 16 from that, and finally multiply that answer to (2/3+1/6). That all simplifies to  4*(1/64)*(5/6)=(1/16)(5/6)=5/96 Another way to think about it is that division is truly multiplication of the reciprocal, so dividing 64 becomes multiplication of (1/64). So there‚Äôs no way 64 should multiply to the (2/3+1/6). Either way, that kid did great! Impressive to beat an engineer.

I think the eclipse question should be Lunar eclipse. This is when the earth is in between the sun and the moon thus blocking and sunlight from reaching the moon thus appearing 'invisible' while solar eclipse/partial eclipse is when the moon is in between.

11:46  Here's how I proceeded: The perimeter of the square is 4S and that of a rectangle is 2(L+W). So, since L>W, it means L=W+e where e>0 and if e=2f where f>0, then 4S=4(W+f), and S=W+f, i.e. A square=(W+f)(W+f)=W¬≤+2f+f¬≤ and A rectangle=(W+2f)(W)=W¬≤+2f=A square-f¬≤. And because it seems that from parallelogram to rectangle to square to circle the shapes become more and more "rounded" and because a parallelogram is a squashed rectangle and that the more you squash it the closer you get to a (straight) line, it seemed to me, intuitively, that the shape with the maximum area would be the circle and the shape with the minimum area would be the parallelogram.  And of course you can apply the same method to express the perimeter of the circle in terms of W and f in order to determine the expression of the radius as I did previous to extract C, and then its area and compare it with the other two. So you'll have: Perimeter of the square=perimeter of the circle, implies that 4(W+f)=2œÄr, i.e. r=(2/œÄ)(W+f), i.e. A circle=œÄ((2/œÄ)(W+f))¬≤=(4/3.14)(A square), and because 4/3.14>1 it follows that A circle>A square.

Correct me if I‚Äôm wrong but the answer to the last question is incorrect. From what I‚Äôm understanding the question has you cut the circle into a large amount of slices so that when rearranged it approximates a rectangle, once done it‚Äôs asking you for the difference between the circle‚Äôs diameter and the long side of the rectangle.   Since the area of the circle must be conserved and the slices all have a height of r (the radius, in this case 5), the long side must have a length of œÄr. If you think about it the rectangle can‚Äôt be 10 longer since that would mean the rectangle is 20 by 5 (the radius) this comes out to an area of 100 which would be the area of a square with side length 10 not a circle.

Tell me what is 1√∑2x? No one interprets that as (1√∑2)x. It would be stupid to do so. 2x is implied to be together. In fact, implicit multiplication being grouped together as a singular term is exactly what we do for fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the correct answer with 0 controversy. Absolutely no one interprets that as 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. In which case implied multiplication such as 2(3) should be grouped together as it makes sense to do so.
¬†@Mlittlelittle¬† yes - 5/96 correct! I am so surprised that people do not know the elementary rules of mathematics. If there is a task, for example, 8:2x5 - this means that FIRST you divide 8 by 2, and only THEN multiply the obtained result by 5.  A farmer has 8 small potatoes and plants two in a hole, each such bush will then yield 5 potatoes. This is what a math problem literally means. You must NOT break the sequence of mathematical operations. The correct answer is 20! NOT the fraction 4/5

The wording in the last question was very poor. With the wording: "how much longer will the rectangle be than the circle" it's already confusing since in 2D space we generally talk about the height and width of figures, or the length of sides. If you assume it asking for length of a side implies it's asking for the difference in width, based on the width being the longer side of the rectangle. Then length rectangle is œÄr and length circle is 2r, difference is œÄ-2. So rectangle is œÄ-2 longer than circle. But what the boy actually solved for was the PERIMETER length of both figures, which obviously is the diameter if you think about it for more than 10 seconds. I'm from Europe btw.

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together.

I feel like the last question is an allegory for western education versus Chinese education. Western education stresses approaching every problem from the bottom up, starting with the nitty gritty details and formulas, and Chinese education stresses taking a step back and looking at clever ways to simplify the problem. One is not inherently better necessarily as sometimes there is no clever simplification and you have to get really in the weeds to solve it, but when there is it is really helpful to find.

if you keep dividing the circle into smaller and smaller pizza slices  and add them like shown in the video it eventually becomes a rectangle. Basically  the pizza slices become so thin that they resemble a straight line and the curly edges smooths out. This method is used in some textbooks to proof that area of a circle is pi times radius squared.   Integration can be used here.
Then you need to cut it to infinitely small pieces to make a circle become rectangle. Then how come an infinite amount of infinitely small pieces can add up to a finite number? You would need calculus to understand that. This is way beyond elementary school student's knowledge. A smart element school kid will look at that image and ask: how is this possible?

Both the Engineer and the 5th graders both violated the PEMDAS or BODMAS rule. Straight to math jail. After the parenthesis the order of operation is from left to right, the correct answer is 5/96 not 3/40.

Hey the answer is wrong to the question "When will the moon not appear during this phenomenon"   Solar Eclipse: The moon doesn't appear in its usual form because it's positioned in front of the sun, blocking it. However, you can see the moon if you're viewing the eclipse safely. Lunar Eclipse: The moon can appear not to be there or very dark when it's in the Earth's umbra. In a total lunar eclipse, it might look red but not disappear entirely. Partial Eclipse: Solar: The moon partially covers the sun, so it's visible but not fully blocking the sun's light. Lunar: Part of the moon is darkened by Earth's shadow, but the rest remains visible.   The question is asked under a false premise.

I'm at 8th grade, but the rectangle-circle with 5 cm diameter is pretty easy. If you don't know how it works, basically you count the perimeter of the circle resulting in 78,5 cm. You divide  it into two, because the perimeter of the circle is ONLY the side across the  corner, the other sides norr the corner doesn't count. If you put it more simply, the rectangle has two long sides, one long side equivalent to 1/2 of the circle's perimeter. Which if you put it even more simply, the difference is the diameter, and always the diameter.  But why is that? One shorter side of the rectangle equals r of the circle. The rectangle has two of those shorter sides, so there are two r's, resulting in a diameter. The total of both the long side's perimeter of the rectangle  is the circle's perimeter. The only difference they have ifs that rectangle has two additional shorter-sides. And each of those shorter sides is the r of the circle.

They used pemdas incorrectly by solving multiplication before division instead of treating multiplication and division as equals and solving from left to right. Very common mistake due to how we are taught pemdas but you must remember that it is parentheses, exponents, then multiplication or division depending on its order from left to right, then addition or subtraction.

15:25 This question confuses me.  If you took a circle of a diameter of 10 and cut it into infinite pieces around the middle you would get a rectangle with a height of 5 units and an area of 78.54 units (taken from the circle). For the last question it is how we derive the area of the circle, as said in the video one size is r, and the two horizontal make up the circumference of the circle so the horizontal is 2pir/2=pir. I don't think that last answer is correct.  If we take a large number of slices of a circle, with the radius of 5 (diameter of 10), the circumference is 10*pi.  If we put all of the slices together, the width will be roughly the radius, which is 5.  These radius width triangle edges will form the inside of the rectangle angle.  The outside circumference of the circle will have to be split in half, where half the slices form the top edge of the rectangle, and the other half of the circle forms the bottom half.  So it will have a length of pi*r, or 5 pi.  That is roughly 15.8 in length, or about 5.8 longer than the circle.

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together. Casio calculators would give the answer 3/40 instead of 5/96.
Question should be whether you were taught that in 5th grade.

Did I missunderstand the question?  How much longer rectangle would be than the circle?  Well, circles length in any direction would be equal and would be the diameter, 10.  Length of the rectangle would be the perimeter divided by 2, since that's what it would approach the smaller the slices taken from the circle would be.  Therefore the difference would be 10*pi/2 - 10, that would approximate to 5,7 rather than 10.

I don't think the answer to the first medium-level math question should be 3/40. The "64" is outside the brackets, so it shouldn't be operated on at the same time as the part inside the brackets. Uhh... the answer to the last question is wrong lol. The answer of 10 is how much larger the perimeter of the rectangle is compared to the perimeter of the circle, but that's not the question. The question is "how much longer will the rectangle be from the circle." The answer is the length of the rectangle minus the diameter of the circle, which is 5œÄ - 10.

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together.

That math problem was just straight up wrong. It was in the form x√∑y√óz, and both interpreted it for no reason as x√∑(yz). 1/6 √ó 24 √∑ 64 (2/3 + 1/6) is a sloppy way to write it precisely because "√∑" is an ambiguous symbol in this case. It could just as easily have been interpreted as (1/6 x 24 √∑ 64) (2/3 + 1/6) instead of (1/6 x 24) √∑ (64 (2/3+1/6))

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped togethe

@ Go on and explain where exactly did I write nonsense. Point them out 1 by 1. Is it when I said 1√∑¬Ω=2 is never 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω? Nope that is a fact. Is it when I made the claim that 2x is a singular term? Nope that's a fact according to algebra. In algebra an equation like 2x+3y+5 is considered to have 3 terms. Not 5 terms. Clearly showing that a term like 2x is considered to be grouped together and not simply 2*x. And no one interprets ab/cd as (ab/c)d. That is a fact. Everything I said so far is exactly how math works.   And then with this, I am making the argument that since fractions are clearly a singular term, as well as implicit multiplication such as 2x being a singular term, it makes far more sense to evaluate 2(3) as a singular term rather than two separate terms.  If you are so hell bent on following orders of operation strictly, are you going to defend interpreting 1√∑¬Ω as 1√∑1√∑2 then? Because the rule of PEMDAS here is already being broken by fractions. problems in this vid: mid math problem is a poorly formed math expression and will give multiple answers even with pedmas, although i agree with how they did it.   the moon question, you need to define "appear" because it's involved in all three although you physically can't see it in C perimeter question, sheldon puts definitions for perimeter and not area, meaning he came to the correct conclusion but not in the correct way.  xianxian doesn't show any work and his explanation was skipped over but what is given is correct - my explanation is that it's similar to a packaging problem and a sphere can hold the most volume/space therefore a circle will have the most area per perimeter, you could also show this with the formulas for area of each and substitute in the perimeters (like what they did but neither proved it). final circle question is also poorly worded as they seem to be trying to compare circumference vs perimeter but "longer" to me would mean you're putting them up against the same coordinates and seeing which goes further by how much on the x axis, i got about (because pi) 5.7 longer for the rectangle. half the circumference which is pi*r (5pi) then minus the diameter 10 is roughly 15.7-10 = [5.7] again kid doesn't show his work, do they not prioritize this in china?
The last question is extremely poorly worded and should be: "Given that the diameter of the circle is 10, how much longer will the PERIMETER of the rectangle be from the PERIMETER of the circle"  In which case the answer is (r+r+(pi*r)*2)-(2*pi*r)=2*r=10  Otherwise it's easy to assume the question is asking how much longer the BASE of the rectangle compared to the DIAMETER of the circle which would be (pi*r)/(2*r)= pi/2  This is a case of an engineer trying to answer an extremely poorly worded question versus a 5th grader regurgitating a memorized answer.  Don't get me wrong, Xianxian is an extremely bright kid for sure, and Sheldon should have come up with one of those 2 answers, but that last question would send any engineer worth a damn scrambling because of how poorly it's written.

The math question would be fine if everyone accepts implied multiplication to be grouped together. However apparently people don't which really doesn't make sense since there is zero controversy in 1√∑¬Ω=2. No one interprets that as 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. An equation like a√∑bc, should always be interpreted as a√∑(bc). The purpose of PEMDAS IMO is to simplify math so that we don't need to write millions of parentheses. Something like 8-2+3 would technically be ambiguous without PEMDAS. Without PEMDAS, we would need to write parentheses such as (8-2)+3 or 8-(2+3). However with PEMDAS, the default for 8-2+3 is (8-2)+3. Using the logic of PEMDAS being created to simplify math, it would make zero sense to interpret a√∑bc as (a√∑b)c because there is a much better unambiguous way of writing it. That being ac√∑b. Therefore the default for a√∑bc should be a√∑(bc) since there is a better way to write the other interpretation.

This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) all over again. In which the answer is either 9 or 1. 9 is what you get while interpreting 2(3) as two separate terms in 2*3 where as 1 is when you see 2(3) as a singular term due to them being implied multiplication. In my opinion 2(3) should be interpreted as a singular term. Why? It simply makes much more sense to do so. WIth something like 1√∑2x, no one interprets that as (1√∑2)x and if you wanted it to mean that, there is a much better way to write it. Being x√∑2. Therefore the default of 1√∑2x should automatically be assumed to be 1√∑(2x). PEMDAS's existence IMO is used to simplify math equations so you aren't writing millions of parentheses. In which case it would be very stupid to interpret 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x since that is such a convoluted way to interpret that when there is a much better unambiguous way of writing it being x√∑2. Not to mention, grouping implicit multiplication as a singular term is literally what we do for fractions. There is 0 controversy over something like 1√∑¬Ω. Everyone agrees the correct answer to that is 2. There is no one claiming this is actually 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω.

The circle problem requires NO education at all.  The 2 longer sides of the rectangle are made by (equal to) the circumstances of the circle.  The DIFFERENCE is the 2 shorter sides, that's 2 radius or diameter or 10.
I think you're overthinking it. As the number of slices goes to infinity, the total length of the  top+bottom equals to the circumference of the circle. That leaves the 2 sides of the rectangle as the extras, which is 10. In the end, the area of both of them should be the same.

They use implied multiplication which groups something like 2(3) as a singular term. This is the infamous 6√∑2(1+2) question all over again. In my opinion, grouping 2(3) as a singular term makes more sense than separating the two as no one interprets 1√∑2x as (1√∑2)x. 2x is implied to be together. This is exactly how we treat fractions. 1√∑¬Ω=2 is the only correct answer with zero controversy. No one claims it is 1√∑1√∑2=¬Ω. So yes I would argue it makes much more sense for implicit multiplication to be grouped together.
¬†@MasterlyRex8789¬† My math teach once explicitly pointed out that it's not a single term, unless brackets are added. I don't like the 2x example, since 2x is like any another number, like 13 let's say, and it's not an expression that's to-be-evaluated.
¬†@MasterlyRex8789¬† 1√∑¬Ω translates to 1/(1/2) which simplifies to 1 * 2, that's why no controversy arises. the division line serves as an implicit bracket of the whole fraction in the expression, like absolute value does for example

PEMDAS  mean  parenteses, exponents, multiplication and division, adition and subtraction, which means multiplication and division have the same value. So in 4 √∑ 64 (5/6), the parenteses was solved and now it just means that its a multiplication. So its just 4 √∑ 64 . 5/6. Then u need to do the division first and thats 1/16 . 5/6. Okay, I understood the question wrong. But if you divide the circle into infinite equal sectors, the longth of thw longer side of tha rectangle should be œÄr.üòÇ
Given the question that they showed us: the rectangle has sides 5 and 5pi, so the rectangle would be 5pi-10 units longer (looking at the 5pi side) and 5 units shorter (looking at the 5 side). The question is probably asking what the difference in perimeter is between the two, so the circumference of the circle is 10pi (2pi*radius) and the perimeter of the rectangle is 10pi+10 (5*2 + 5pi*2), so the difference there is 10. It's likely due to an incorrect translation of the question rather than understanding tho.

No one asked but I graduated highschool in 2020 with a 2.0 gpa (3.0 on a 5.0 scale) and a low SAT so naturally I had no choice but to choose a community college. I attended a community for the first 2 years, had a straight 4.0 for both years, transfered over to a private D1 university and had scholarships which brought my yearly tuition down from $55K to $20K. I've had a straight 4.0 since I've transferred over and I'm planning on going to law school after I graduate in 2024. So far, I was accepted into Yale, Columbia, Duke and UChicago. Would I be able to do all of this without my community college? Absolutely not. It's a wonderful stepping stone and I don't think anyone should be ashamed of it.

¬†@friedsquidgames5584¬† I nominate MY community college Statics, Dynamics, and Engineering Graphics professor. Yes, one guy who taught me 3 different classes. He's a beautiful person.
I was a professor at an elite university.  The difference between a community college professor and an ivy-league professor is subtle.  First of all, there is a glut of highly qualified PhD's.  So, almost all professors are equally qualified to dispense received knowledge.  Tenured--emphasis on Tenured--professors at a CC will often give you close instruction and a one-on-one experience.  They will hold your hand through the learning process and make sure you will learn the material.  But that said, CC's often exploit non-tenured labor--people whom they pay 4K per class--often without benefits--so those people will be less likely to go out of their way for you.  Ivy League Professors are almost always the leading minds of their fields.  They are cutting edge researchers.  And they are hired not so much for their ability to teach or inspire but for their ability to open new intellectual territory.  So, you may or may not get the best teacher.  And you should ask yourself if you really need the leading researcher to teach you the basics of O Chem.  All that said, an Ivy-League professor with a great reputation will be able to write you a letter of recommendation for Med School or a PhD Program.  Those letters will cause people to stop and think twice.  People will know of their reputation.  And their word will hold weight.
I was surprised to see one of my CC professors (the worst one, imo) teaching at my university. But universities hire temp/assistant professors, and get staff/grad students to teach all the time.

¬†@radish1395¬† actually, there are tons and tons of community college professors with PhD's, because there aren't enough full-time jobs out there.
Of course there will be exceptions to this, but community college professors have to have a lot of passion for teaching AND their discipline in order to stick with a job that will grind you to pieces. Every year administrations try to find creative ways to pay us less but get more work out of us, while giving themselves pay raises. We have to work harder just to pay the bills, resulting in less time to devote to continuing to research in our area of expertise. And good luck if you're trying to do this and have a family!   But we love our work, so we try to squeeze in the time (usually at the expense of sleep) to keep working at our discipline, as well as continue to improve our teaching. Because at a community college, your relationship with your students might be what helps them believe that they can do it. Often we're the ones helping them learn how to be a student, whereas the Ivy Leaguers are dealing with people who have known how to be a good student for some time, so I would bet they aren't as good at trying to make those diamonds in the rough shine; they're getting students that already have a high level of polish.   So what will you get with a community college professor? Most of the time, someone who loves their field, is excited to share that love with their students, and is passionate about helping students from all backgrounds find their way and succeed, but who also is tired and overwhelmed a lot, because they're spread thin having to do this for far more students than the Ivy Leaguers will. The average class load for a full-time professor is around five classes per year, maybe four, plus time spent in research, and possibly some committee service. One semester I had six classes between my three schools, I served on a committee (still do), my back had gone out and I was in 24/7 excruciating pain for 9 months, and I was the one because of our work schedules who had to get the 3 month-old and the 3 year-old ready and out the door to go to daycare, then bring them home at the end of the day, feed them, play, get them ready for bed, etc. I'd finish a class, try to field questions as efficiently as I could, sprint to the car, drive as fast as I could legally and safely to my next campus (while trying to eat as much of my lunch as I could), jump out and walk into class right as it's starting and start in with a lecture, or prepping the lab. Rush here, go full speed, rush there, full speed for the next group, just bam bam bam from one thing to the next all day long, then after the kids are finally asleep, try to stay awake to grade and prep for the next day. I think I ended the year having taught 12 or 13 classes, compared to a full-timer's five.   Like I said, it's a grind. Being able to teach two classes in a semester, having TA's to help with grading, and then be expected to do my research (which for me would be photographing, printing in the darkroom, sequencing a book, preparing an exhibit, writing, etc), that would be a dream! Many Ivy Leaguers went straight from grad school to a full-time job and don't have any experience of the life I just described. Not all, but many.   Did I choose to be a dad (my kids are amazing!), an educator, and an artist? Yes. But how often are people honest about the reality of an academic life? Once you're in it, your peers are very candid, but before your get in, you don't often hear real talk about what it's like.   For Ivy League students I would say, be grateful, be very, very, very grateful. For community college students, you make me so proud when I see you persist in the face of real and pervasive obstacles. When you graduate, you can savor that degree because you worked your ass off to get it, in ways that the privileged ones will never understand. And you're why I still do this. To my fellow community college adjuncts, I salute you; you know exactly what I'm talking about.
It is the same knowledge. English professor at Yale and English professor at community college is the same. The difference is just the name and the extra activities each school offer.

I know TWO people who teach at a community College and at a "public ivy" (UT-Austin).  They do not "doctor" their classes for each college: they teach the same class in both colleges, and it's usually because A LOT of those students will VERY LIKELY take an upper division class with them at that public ivy (since a lot of students from that community College transfer to that bigger university very often).    In other words: community colleges tend to get way more hate than they deserve, when in reality, they're severely underrated AND overhated.    More people should go to community colleges, mainly on the basis of cutting costs, and ESPECIALLY if you have no interest in the Greek life.

¬†@svmathtutor¬†  I think what bothers me the most is that people misunderstand 'above average' intelligence with her percentile of intelligence relative to her percentile of academic success... Psychologists have known for ages that IQ correlates poorly with Academic Success relative to other factors. Academic success is far more well correlated with Grades in general for example then it is with Standardized Test Scores, or IQ.  To put this into perspective someone who is a 4.0 student with a dismal 95 IQ has a better chance of getting into Harvard, and a better chance of succeeding in menial labor and projecting 'seeming intelligence' than a 2.0 student with a 150 IQ. Intelligence is a far better measure of the ability of the adapt to new scenarios, and comprehend the abstract, and IQ is the best measure of intelligence. Good students are not necessarily intelligent. No single trait makes for 'good grades' but the strongest traits are extremely good short term memory, and a study style based on frequent repetitive and extremely dry affect and interest in material. That is perseverance to do unpleasant or uninteresting things mindlessly (IE study), not with the goal of retaining the memory long term (Actually learning it), but merely short term (So as to ace the tests or graded assignments and then dump the information).   This is also the reason that high High School and undergrad grades don't actually show predictive success when it comes to BAR test examinations in post grad Law Students. They do well in all their academic endeavors, but benefit from little long term retention.   In any case, what stellar students do have in common is very very few have 'low' IQ's there is SOME correlation between 4.0 students and being 'above average' intelligence, but being the top 1% academically has less than a standard deviation of difference in intelligence, in other words, you could at best assume they are a little above average, but you definitely cannot assume they are 'extremely intelligent' they are at best a little more intelligent than the average person with a lot of other qualities that make them perform well in schools.   As a side good grades and academic performance correlate more strongly with better success in real world markets than high IQ or intelligence. High IQ and intelligence correlate better with success in PhD Research and Publishing than strong academic performance or good grades. So if you're looking to work in the private sector as an employee, then you don't need to be intelligent, but you do need to get good grades. If you're looking to do groundbreaking research and revolutionize the world, don't count on that meaning you'll be economically successful, and it also doesn't mean you'll do well in school, but if you make it your IQ matters a lot more than your previous academic performance.   All around I find these videos disturbing. For the most part people value themselves far too much based on their achievements, and say they believe that their grades, or their admission to this sort of school, or their entry into this special club, or this privileged minority, causes them to believe they are... Intelligent... Successful... Competent... Better... Whatever. In almost all cases they are misleading themselves. Fortunately some minority of them while doing their research will find themselves a small fish in a big lake and realize either through their education, or via comparison to others how false their assumptions were. Impostor syndrome be damned, most people assume too much based on the wrong things. Ask what you want to be and why, and then do yourself a favor and look up what correlates most strongly with whatever it is you desire to see in yourself, you might be surprised to find you've been going about it the wrong way, and judging yourself in the wrong manner.
Aamir Dave not necessarily. I applied to 3 ivy‚Äôs and got into one.

Mara Flores Imagine a sailor in the Navy. Being in the Navy says a lot about that man. He is courageous, a risk-taker, and among other traits, he also has a willingness to serve and defend the country that he loves. What does he do? He serves his country. What does he attend? The Navy. The statement you just quoted is one of the most counterintuitive, contradictory, and redundant statements I have ever heard in my lifetime.  Now, would you say attending an Ivy League school says a lot about who you are? You might think that an Ivy Leaguer is privileged, wealthy, extremely bright, and has good connections. All of those things have a say in that Ivy Leaguer‚Äôs personality; it is not a bad thing to admit, and not everyone who shares those traits have the same personality, there are serval more traits that shape up that Ivy Leaguer. However, they attend an Ivy League school. They attend a school that they worked their entire lives to go to. They do what they attend. Even if you don‚Äôt accomplish something, you are defined by that and your potential to improve.
¬†@bryanmgonzalez¬† Counter-intuitive, sure. Contradictory, absolutely not. Some people become police officers because they're sadists and enjoy shooting a gun. Some people sign up to be nurses and then verbally, and in worse cases physically mistreat their patients. Some teachers act like they love to educate the future generation but are secretly sexual predators. They got the credentials, they've completed "attending" their institutions, but they do misdeeds. And ultimately you are accountable for what you do. Even if it's an accident, even if some negative life event damaged you in some way, what you do (or don't do) defines who you are and who you've become.    He didn't say you're NEVER what you attend; he said you're not necessarily what you attend. Meaning that sure, there are benchmarks that can reasonably justify a certain personal brand or trait. But they don't NEED to define you, and how you define yourself is up to you, no matter how anyone else perceives you. And that's the point.

¬†@bryanmgonzalez¬† If you read the statement too literally -- as I think you've done, in addition to a slightly out-of-context example (you are talking about occupations, Saul's quote talks about education) -- then yes it does become redundant.   If, however, you try to extract the spirit of the quote (rather than be pedantic about its letter), it isn't at all redundant, but rather a humanistic plea to be better at acknowledging/recognizing:¬†1) a person's inherent value e.g. traits, skills and character, in contrast to 2) our tendency to simply/immediately project immense value and worth based on the prestige of affiliated/'attended' institutions: most typically where someone gets their money and/or their degree.

¬†@slumpskd1382¬† I'm confused by what you mean. A bachelor's degree takes 4 years of undergraduate school. I did my first two at a community and I'm finishing my last two at a private D1 school. It takes the same amount of time if not faster. I found that after transfering from a CC, I had more credits than my peers in the same grade. ¬†Joy¬† Congratulations on your achievements thus far! Have you started prepping for the LSAT?
¬†@Nidrizzle¬† Did you do something outside of college that boosted your chances at the end for ivy
¬†@narcommando546¬† replying to this so I get a notification if they answer
¬†@narcommando546¬† I joined a bunch of honor societies (i think around 7 or so) and was super involved on my campus chapters. This gave me the opportunity to have exec board positions which looks nice on a resume or application. I also worked full time time on the side and spent my free time volunteering at an animal shelter. I live in the city so I tried to do as much community service work as I could. Not so it would make me a better candidate but more so because it's a genuine thing to do. I recently finished up a 10 week internship at a law firm but it was more so entry level intern work but it still helped me gain some more connections. All in all, Ivy schools don't just want a book smart 4.0. They want someone who's well rounded and constantly juggling multiple things at once. My advisor told me that it's more impressive to a school if you have a 3.7 gpa with many extracurriculars such as honor societies or sports, hobbies and a job rather than a 4.0 student who has nothing but their grades. Hope that helps!

¬†@qslasher620¬† First off, I'm privileged enough to say that I am not of lower socio-economic background and my parents paid for my undergrad tuition. That being said, all of my scholarships were solely based off merit but I would highly encourage you to join honor societies because I received a pleasant amount which definitely helped cut my total tuition down.  I think going to a local college before transfering to a more prestigious school is totally fine! If anything, it's absolutely normal and many of my friends have taken that path. I'll give you two instances: A close friend of mine had stellar grades, was president of literally every club and everyone knew that he was going to go to an Ivy for sure. He ended up going to a state university and later transferred to Stanford last year. Another one of my friends was in the same boat I was with lower grades yet she had a better SAT score which allowed her to have more options. She also went to a state school and just recently for her last year, she transferred to NYU because her school offered a 3+1 program where they would pay for your last year if you did 3 years at that state school with a certain major. I think the most important thing is making sure that this is what you want to do (and don't ever let anyone try to make you feel bad for your school choices or not being a regular student at a 4 year school).

¬†@deniselim6766¬† Technically, you do. Colleges typically accept more students to account for students that choose to go elsewhere in order to create a normal class size. This is also why wait-lists at ivy schools are almost never used. If a student has very little interest in going, but applies to the school and gets in, they in essence have taken that "spot" out of a student that could of had the eligible skills/background needed. This is regardless if the accepted student chooses not to enroll since the amount of students accepted is more or less constant. Trophy hunting students do exist and the practice is discouraged/frowned upon. Unfortunately, I came from a school were multiple students did this just to gloat. I am hopeful the amount of students that do this is low.

That's entirely wrong. The admission system works with points you get for specific privileges so the less you have, the easier to get in. For example the chance for a female asian immigrant whose parents are divorced and who needs to apply for student loans to get into an ivy league school is much higher than for a white male American student whose parents are married and wealthy although they may have the same grades or his are even slightly better. The exceptions are athletes and students whose family members attended the same university. I think this system is super unfair because it focuses so much on giving everyone a chance and completely neglects the efforts certain students put into getting in this specific school. I would personally feel really bad if I knew I'd only attend this school because of my background rather than what I've achieved.

Now it's been a while since I've seen this video but I'm pretty sure he didn't say he got there through a scholarship of some sorts, unlike the girl who did. Listen man, I'm not hating on the guy. He might be a very good person. Hell, he might even be someone's hero one day for all i know. All I'm saying is this: privilege is when you can provide something for yourself or your family something that the majority of the population cannot, and 90% of the case it's because that majority isn't able to afford it. Having money in itself is privilege. Being able to wake up in the morning with a roof over your head is a privilege. It's just that some people wake up under the roof of a mansion for example. Now his parents may have worked they're asses off, but all he ever did was get good grades and apply to Yale. His parents are the one that paid for it. It isn't the generic notion of privilege that you have come to know, but it's definitely a form of it. It's not unfair, it's just a privilege. That's all.
¬†@jozefya¬† yes but then he is privileged because his parents have given him money to pay for tuition, I still disagree with the fact that you said he is privileged because  if a yale graduate and a normal college graduate apply for the same job, the yale grad would probably get that job, I think that's the way the world should work because on average, the people who went to yale have to work harder.

He's benefiting from his parents' hardships to be where he's at now. And finally, let me just make one last thing clear please. I never said the being privileged is unfair. I don't believe there should be a negative connotation on the word "privilege". It just happens to some people and not for others. That kid didn't choose to be privileged, he just happens to be the son of parents who "made it". That isn't a bad thing or an unfair thing, it's just privilege. Trump's children henceforth were born privileged. See what I mean? ¬†@marcellaaxelrad644¬† Asians are very well-represented in the university population, so the diversity factor doesn't really help them. my former tutor was in Oxbridge admissions and the bell curve for Asians is also a lot higher. that is to say, the average Asian generally has to perform MUCH better than the average person of another race (whether white or non-white) to get in, because they're competing with members of their own race thanks to diversity quotas

¬†@marcellaaxelrad644¬† Because from my knowledge, colleges are required to be relatively representative of our population - so there are racial quotas. So essentially, each race is put into a piece of the pie, but given that Asians are a minority, many people are competing against one another for a limited amount of spots available to them. Additionally, most of their competition (other Asian students) are usually full of crazy credentials/accomplishments because when you're competing with that kind of pool of students, grades aren't enough to make you stand out since the majority of them are straight-A, high ACT/SAT score students.

How does it work? What exactly is the GPA thing? Here, where I live, we have a few pathway options with the most common one involving receiving a selection rank that is calculated based off your performance against all the other students in your state/territory through exams as well as tests/assignments we have throughout our final year of high school. Unis don't usually look at anything else unless you apply for special consideration or a scholarship in which case they may look at things such as financial hardship, illness, where you live, volunteering, leadership etc.

Harmony Alexandria ummm. Not counting those who get in because of athletics, but the majority of students who get into ivy leagues were in the top 1% of they‚Äôre high school. They got into ivy leagues not because they didn‚Äôt have anything exceptional about them, but because they DO have exceptional qualities.  And I‚Äôm not saying you have to go to an Ivy League but you should go to a top ranked college or a good college if you want to get a good education. Why is it that top colleges have good education? One, because the majority of people there got in because they were the top student in their high school. So if most people there are like close to geniuses, then it automatically cranks up the competitive level. And when competition increases, people will strive to become better, and also uplift the educational quality of the school in general. Two, because in order to be a college professor at those schools, you have to have a PhD. So top colleges have some of the best professors. In community college, the teachers don‚Äôt need PhD degrees. Three, top colleges provide the best resources. If you go major in science at a community college, I‚Äôm certain if you do a lab there, the quality and the ability to accomplish in depth labs will be highly limited.  And I‚Äôm also not saying that there‚Äôs nothing wrong about ivy leagues. I personally think Harvard is way too overrated, and of course, many times, they prioritize students (the rich). But still, the majority of students didn‚Äôt get into ivy leagues through money but through their academic achievements or through how much they contributed to society and have shown their leadership skills; only a portion got in through athletics.

¬†@sarakroczyk321¬† I‚Äôve gone through the process as well, and I can say that most people I know at public schools applied to 15-20 schools. So many factors come into play. ¬†@andrewkear5639¬† I don't think so. His statement that he felt the admissions process was fair because of the diversity he saw on campus was fairly incompetent. Schools put a huge focus on being able to develop a diverse environment that they will often take less qualified individuals for the sake of diversity. ¬†@purpleties127¬† The system was never fair, frankly. Back when he was applying, the world was significantly more racist and sexist than it is today... and so white males had a significant advantage over everyone else regardless of merit. Nowadays, schools want to be as diverse as possible for multiple reasons: to show that they "changed"; to enhance the experiences of students; to build a better, more well-rounded community.   The reason he thought the system was a lot more fair now is because he was comparing it to back when he was a kid (a time in which diversity was heavily lacking). He certainly was talking about the process now as only now do we have diversity -- which, again, is a great thing for the students in the college but is certainly an unfair system for those trying to enter based solely on merit.

¬†@aaronmontgomery2055¬† Blame other (East) Asians. Now there are so many they're driving up the competition - making it nearly as competitive as it is back home in their super competitive countries. In the early days it was much easier for the kids of Asian immigrants to get into universities - when there weren't that many and admissions staff were more impressed, and Americans (both white and black or other groups) didn't compete as hard for spots, back in the 80s, 90s, 2000s. In the last 20 years competition has snowballed - and now Indians and other South Asians are also competing amd getting the top spots. Asian immigrants complain - but they're the ones who moved to the U.S. Their choice. And they just have to abide by the way things are there. One of the reasons that many "excellent student" Asian candidates aren't accepted by universities is they are too one dimensional, only great at math, science, IT etc and not equally great at stuff like history, English literature, art etc. And their extra-curriculars are stuff like chess, computer club etc. and they all choose classical violin or piano as instruments, and do sports like ice skating. Asian candidates who do say drama (e.g. musicals, singing), write poetry, play less obvious instruments like oboe or the drums, or do sports like field hockey or rowing, will have way better chances of impressing admissions staff. Some of the more savvy Asian parents have cottoned on to this, but most of them are stuck in culture rut of their countries, where kids do those things (learn violin/piano, ignore sports).
¬†@kiyohmi¬† What makes you say that? In South Korea it's more "fair" in that it's really just an exam score based system for university admission. They don't offer entrance and scholarship to students who are great at some sport. They don't have interviews and write personal essays, and don't have to show they ran some clubs, were school presidents, cheerleaders, or wrote the music or did the art design for their high school plays. And of course, race or ethnicity is not a factor - they're all ethnically Korean.  However, poorer parents can't afford the high cost of extra out-of-school "academy" cram schoil tuition starting from the age of like 5. Those who think that the best prep/private tutoring doesn't make a difference ...well, they just don't know, they haven't seen how it works.  It makes a big difference there in South Korea; but it also makes a difference in the U.S.  Mediocre kids there that get the best exam prep (a private extra expense) on top of their regular school (which could also be a top private school, or a top government/state school) can be elevated to perform at the top level and get into top schools - just on their own "merits."

Although I don't consider myself to have school spirit , i have met a lot of great people at my CC and i am saving money because my scholarships allow me to go to CC for free at the moment. I came to Canada as a skilled immigrant (a mechanical engineer) from the Ukraine, because they said they needed my skills. My wife had a university degree too. The Engineers' society of BC put so many hoops to jump through to prove my degree that it was easier to go to the university the second time and get a local degree. With two teenage kids in the household it was not possible and I started my Canadian career as a car wash person, and a year later migrated to carpentry (my former hobby). I'm in carpentry 22 years later and about to retire. So much about skills.
I been speaking with people living outside of Canada, they are also amazed that we cant afford houses with all that land. We are not even 50 millions, there is no excuses. The corruption runs deep.

Okay, this needs a lot more elaboration.  Back in the day, you'd get a $10k RSP loan, your spouse would get the same,  tax refunds would pay half that loan balance in 60 days, you'd pay the rest within a year.  At the end of the year, repeat. End of 2nd year, you have $40K in an RSP, and that was enough of a downpayment on almost any property up to the 2010s.   Keep in mind that back then, there was no stress test. Having a combined income of $100k was enough qualify for a $500k mortgage, which would have bought a 4bedroom in just about anywhere in Canada.  Between cost of living and skyrocketing  housing prices, that trick to getting on the housing ladder no longer works.
Even if you did buy years ago the upkeep will delete your savings.

35 years ago the mortgage rate was 12.75%,  and the median Canadian wage for an unattached individual was $25, 192.   "At its peak, the average cost for a home was $273,698 in 1989, compared to $102,318 just five years previously in 1984, creating a crisis of affordability. Then in the early 1990's we had a recession - also not a rosy time.
