My dad bought his house in 1978 for $68,000 which in todays dollars is $295,000.   I just checked the real estate and a similar  house is up for sale for $388,000.   I use a Canadian inflation calculator.   So it  is about 30% higher in actual price today than in 1978.   Minimum wage in 1978 was $2.95 per hour and in 2024 it is $15.80.    If minimum wage was $16.80 it would equal $2.95 in 1978 as far as  house inflation goes.   So wages are behind about 1/16 which is not a lot.   So therefore I don't understand the problem in buying a house for young people in 2024.    I bought a house in 1985 for $85,000 and I paid it off in 1989 and my interest rate was up around 9%.  I put $22,000 down and put every spare cent into paying off the mortgage.   I lived at home until I was 28 and saved my money.   I never  borrowed money for anything.   My car I bought for cash in 1981 and it was a used car for $5000 which today would  be $16,000 today.  I worked on the railway and maybe made $25,000 in 1986 which is about $70,000 in todays money.   Also I have two daughters who finished University and I saved up $80,000 to pay for their education.  They didn't pay a cent.   I went to University for 6 years and I paid for it all myself by working 4 months every summer and I also paid my father board and room.   I have had weekend jobs since I was 14 years old working at a car wash, bakery and meat packers on the hog kill floor and then on the CPR pounding spikes.   I can't really understand what is going on and why young adults can't afford housing.   My wife's friends have no money.  They have a house with mortgage to pay and 2 car loans.

¬†@acharat6¬† Thats what we did and while a beautiful city to explore and beautiful country side, there was no future there and still isnt. Have family that stayed. Worst mistake of their lives.
Tell me about it.   I lived in BC for several years and in 1974 I spent a year at a local community college.   The instructors were excellent and I got almost all A' s.   Instead of continuing at UBC or SFU, I transferred to MIT, (yes, that MIT) in Cambridge MA.   When I graduated, with a BSc in Computer Science and Engineering, along with most of an EE degree, I returned to Vancouver.   I thought it would be a good idea to investigate what was required to become a Professional Engineer, and had an interview with the chief honcho of the BC Association of Professional Engineers (BC APE at that time).  I was told my degree, despite being an Engineering degree from a highly accredited Engineering school, was not equivalent to anything offered at UNC.   So if I wanted to become a P.Eng, I would have to first take several courses at UBC.   Then I would have to be sponsored by a local company that was accredited by the BC APE.    I was also told that the term Computer Engineer was syntactically incorrect and that in BC, there was no such thing as a Computer Engineer.    All this was moot because I would still need to get hired by a company that was accredited with the BC APE.   I interviewed with many if the penny-ant "high tech" companies that were starting to grow ( with generous infusions of taxpayer's money ) at that time.  Hiring then was done through the universities.   Few tech jobs were advertised in the local paper ( before the internet ).   I dropped into the recruiting office at UBC one day and was able to copy down a few job listings before I was told to leave.   That's more of my tax dollars at work there.    I was able to find work and helped one entrepreneur earn his retirement.   Eventually I moved to California, where I had over 35 years of well-paying work, at NASA, Microsoft, AMD,  and many other lesser known companies.   I discovered that the Canadian Professional Engineer's Association, which encompasses all the provincial ones, signed an agreement with their US counterpart, over 50 years ago, to recognize engineering degrees from the other country.   So even when I went to the BC APE HQ and talked to their head honcho, this agreement was current.   By telling me I had to have completed a course by course equivalent of local BC accredited courses in order to have my MIT degree accredited by the BC APE, the were not abiding by a signed bilateral agreement.    So I have no regrets for leaving Canada, where my tax dollars would be used to prevent me from being employed and where the provincial Professional Engineer Associatons  do not abide by a bilateral agreement they have signed with their counterparts in the USA.   It is very unfortunate for Canadian tech  comoanies that they are under the thumb of these people.   Did you know that you cannot even call yourself an Engineer in BC if you are not a P.Eng?    It is little wonder so many Canadian Engineering graduates pack up and move to the USA.   When I have flown back to Canada, on Air Canada, close to Christmas, the plane was packed with 20-30 year old men, all originally from Canada, and now working in Silicon Valley.

‚Äã@igorpro8462  yes, it's still Canada, however different rules apply for different peps, i.e., engineers brought by engineering firms from India didn't have to do anything and were employed in their profession, maybe for a tad lower pay however with all the living expenses covered ... just saying...
Did you not do any research before coming to canada? Did you not check to see if your degrees were compatible? Did you research jobs, housing, schools, cost of living? Did you take a trip here beforehand to scope out job opportunities and even better, have one lined up? If the answer is no, then you failed yourself.   When my parents immigrated, they had to have a sponsor that was 100% financially liable for them. They needed proof that they had a job AND a place to live. If they didnt have those, they couldnt come to Canada. They had all their ducks in a row, and they took the initiative to learn English before coming too.   Standards are different country to country. Would you want a structural engineer from a 3rd world country, where building topple over on a daily basis, to just be handed a job here were there are strict building codes? Hell no. A doctor is some remote country that still uses a saw to amputate limbs, does that qualify them to practice here?   Some degrees are transferable,  some are not. But the onus is on the individual to research BEFORE coming. I have zero sympathy for any international student or immigrant that comes here without doing their homework, and then complains that they can't find or afford housing  food, a job. Doctors driving a taxi, should have figured it all out before coming here.

¬†@mikephillips2984¬† About what ?  Calgary altitude ?   On planes the PSI is about 10.  You get dehydrated and maybe a headache.   Once you live in Calgary for a few months you get more blood to compensate for the low air pressure.   But the incidences of stroke are higher.  My cousin just died of a stroke in Calgary.   When you go on your tropical vacation , the weather seems great. for two reasons.   It is nice and hot and humid but the air pressure is higher as sea level and you get more oxygen in your blood.  You can check the air pressure in many cities but there are two measures, the station pressure and the relative pressure.  You need the absolute pressure which is the station pressure.  This is hard to find on the internet for some reason, I don't know.  But planes need to know this to land properly in the thin air.

So‚Ä¶.here is an interesting phenomenon, about North America (I‚Äôm US American). I assume that you LOVE engineering, thats why you worked so hard for a degree.  And, anywhere else in the world, it makes sense that you‚Äôd be working in engineering.  But North America is a phenomenon, when it comes to ‚Äúlabor‚Äù, in that ‚Ä¶most of the world find what they love, and then make a living at it. But in North America (The US and Canada, at least) people tend to do something that they hate, to make money‚Ä¶.and then use the money, to do, what they love.  This phenomenon was actually brought to my attention by a comedian named Jimmy O. Yang.  And although he presented the idea, as a JOKE.    It turns out that he is 100% correct.  The majority of people in North America, don‚Äôt get to DO what they studied in college. I was a computer science major, in the 80‚Äôs.   I ended up owning and operating a boutique hotel, for 30 years‚Ä¶..I NEVER had a job, in computing. @walterrumohr7090¬† No, it has nothing to do with Britain's aristocracy.   BC'rs have always been insular and resent outsiders who move to BC and take jobs from those "born and bred in BC".   When I lived in BC, despite being Canadian, I encountered this xenophobia myself.   Canada has a lot of socialist government policies.   Tech companies in BC quite often get generous government grants.   Those grants might come with strings attached, eg: hire local university grads.  I do know in many cases professors from UBC or SFU have part-time jobs advising tech startups and also serve on committees that determine which companies get gov't grants.   So they can exert their influence for companies to hire their grads.   I don't know how much things have changed in the 30 years since I left BC, but when I was struggling to find decent work in BC, people would say a company was a "UBC company"  or an "SFU  company", meaning the engineers either came from UBC or SFU.  So the available work for engineers was apportioned to SFU grads and UBC grads.   There was no third option.   Several times managers would ask me to come in to advise their engineers on how to solve a tricky problem they had.   Those interviews never led to a job offer.

¬†@eustacemcgoodboy9702¬† Is that so? My Masters (from UK) was not recognised and I had to take Canadian Civil Aviation pilot exams to fly here. As it turned out, they were a joke compared to the UK.
Foreign accreditation NOT being recognized is a generic issue in virtually every field, and throughout the world. It's a huge burden for an employer to scrutinize foreign credentials. It's also quite a workload to "fast-track" a foreigner inside an accreditation program, since it's not simply about pure knowledge, but rather standards, practices, cultural awareness and other ephemeral things learned throughout the schooling. In other words, it's not such an easy thing to just say "a certificate is a certificate - it doesn't matter where it came from."

You can't just build and settle wherever there's empty land. It has to be economical. The rocky rugged landscape makes it difficult to construct buildings and utilities. The short growing season and thin rocky soil make it difficult to grow food. The need for winter heat is a major ongoing expense. The only way to pay for life up north is to extract resources, which is what they do. When the resource is exhausted, the people have no choice but to leave. The fact is, at 40 million Canada is already overpopulated.

‚Äã¬†@andalucish¬†this is idiotic and shows you have no idea what you're talking about. The Yukon or any territory essentially has no economy outside of mining or logging camps, which aren't always near the "cities" in the territories and are usually ran by workers who are flown in and out during the work season.  That means that a city like Whitehorse essentially has no economy inside the city. Groceries are INSANELY expensive because almost nothing ships up there for half the year. People drive 15 hours from Yellowknife to Edmonton just to buy 3 months worth of groceries at Costco to save money. Building materials are also expensive because, again, it's not economical to ship stuff to a city of 20,000 15-20 hours drive away from the nearest hardware store.

This is a development that takes place in all countries. One reason why housing and property price increases have been so large is that housing and property price increases are not included in inflation. My childhood home outside Oslo in Norway was built in the 1950s and cost new around half the average annual salary. When my parents sold it in 1993, it cost two average annual salaries. When it was sold in 2019, it cost 10 average annual salaries. The homes in this area are now nearly 2,000 times more expensive than when they were built. Norway has the world's richest state, but the Norwegian population has the highest household debt in the world. There will soon come a time when almost no one can afford to buy or rent a house anymore as the price of housing and property rises much more than wage growth

FYI the same thing happened in USA in the 1980's.  A sea change happened when people started looking at their homes as a plan B retirement account.  Perhaps you've heard about the serial housing bubbles, reports of being forced from neighborhoods due to gentrification, stagnant wages for a few decades, and the unholy alliances that take place when real estate developers and local governments have no interest in building for the population most in need of housing.  McMansions offer better revenue in their minds, until they run out of millionaires to buy their whales.   The only meaningful fixes I've seen is when no new permits are granted for anyone who isn't supplying low income housing.  When rent controls get imposed on landlords.  When suburbs get expanded augmented with public transportation.  Take a look at California real estate market and know that most people who are leaving are doing so because most of their income is eaten alive by real estate costs, and places like San Diego would rather not have low income people around.  The ripple effect of displaced populations isn't limited to metropolitan areas either.  People who grew up rural can't afford to live rural anymore either.

Unfortunately you likely have no idea what i am talking about, but let me try and explain.  Canada has been on a non-stop importation of people in numbers that no other country in the world has ever seen in the past 2 centuries. While this does cause some pain in various ways, it makes things like our real estate market insane, it lowers productivity significantly across all sectors it drains capital funding and increases the need for discretionary spending.   So why i am claiming this is a good thing?   Demographics, basically our country like most developed countries had way too many people entering the age of retirement with very few people at young age being born to replace future generations. This means as more of the population shifts to retired old people, things like our consumption, productivity and obligations would go out of control.  The cost per person to maintain medical care and etc. would of approached nearly 200% of what it was 10 years ago from what it would be in 10 years.   The insane number of people we imported though, they are better than children, they only disrupt our economy for 2-8 years instead of say 18-25 before a baby becomes productive.   Yes immigration needs to slowdown but we have already fixed our demographic problem, its just a matter of time before things here improve and they will do rapidly compared to other 1st world countries with only maybe France being able to hold on.   Canada is set to explode into an absolute economic juggernaut and likely be one of the greatest world powers 20-30 years from now, being an actual legitimate rival to the power our next door neighbor has in the world today.

¬†@–£–ª—å—è–Ω–∞–û–≤—Å—è–Ω–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤–∞-–∑4—ä¬† The claim that the United States has provided $350 billion in aid to Ukraine since the war began in 2022 is false. As of February 2025, the U.S. has appropriated approximately $175 billion for Ukraine-related assistance. Of this, about $120 billion has been allocated directly to Ukraine, encompassing military assistance, budget support, and humanitarian aid. The remaining funds have been directed toward related activities, such as bolstering European defenses and addressing global food insecurity.
¬†@AD-oy8nm¬† agreed, and the other part of that equation that consistently gets ignored is the fact that the vast majority of that money was spent domestically in the US to military contractors and suppliers, and those weapons and aid related supplies were then shipped to Ukraine. Ukraine may have received $120B worth of military equipment, goods and services, but they DEFINITELY didn't receive anywhere near that much in cash from the US/ US taxpayers.

The positives of obedience can be gained by most other non-violent or authoritative parenting styles, however not necessarily on the first try but with consistency, especially with very young children because they are LEARNING. This video completely misses the mark by ignoring the critical role of non-EU NATO members, especially Turkey. Europe's defense without the U.S. wouldn't just rely on EU countries‚ÄîNATO is much bigger than that. Turkey, for instance, has one of the largest standing armies in NATO, with 355,000 active troops, and plays a massive role in the alliance's southern flank. Acting like NATO would collapse the moment the U.S. leaves is just fearmongering. NATO isn't just the U.S. and Europe‚Äîit's a collective defense system with 31 members, each contributing in their own way. If the U.S. steps out, it would be a huge blow, but NATO isn't going to fall apart overnight. Turkey, the UK, Norway, Canada, and others are still there, and Europe isn't defenseless. This video needs to stop oversimplifying and acknowledge the full picture‚Ä¶

USA stopped Europeans creating their own army, in the 2000s, there were several European military and defense initiatives that faced strong opposition from the United States, which ultimately contributed to their stagnation or failure. Here are the most notable examples:  1. European Security and Defence Policy (ESDP) & The 2003 EU-NATO Tensions 	‚Ä¢	What was it? The ESDP was the EU‚Äôs early attempt to build an independent military capability outside NATO. 	‚Ä¢	US Reaction: The US and UK (then still in the EU) strongly opposed any attempt that would create an alternative to NATO. 	‚Ä¢	Outcome: The EU had to compromise and accept NATO‚Äôs primacy through the ‚ÄúBerlin Plus Agreement‚Äù (2003), which ensured that any EU-led military missions must rely on NATO assets. 	‚Ä¢	Result: The EU remained dependent on NATO for military operations, preventing an independent European military force.  2. The European Operational Headquarters (OHQ) Proposal (2003-2004) 	‚Ä¢	What was it? France, Germany, Belgium, and Luxembourg proposed an independent European military headquarters (OHQ) to plan and conduct military operations without NATO involvement. 	‚Ä¢	US Reaction: The US and the UK blocked the proposal, arguing that it would duplicate NATO‚Äôs structures and weaken transatlantic cooperation. 	‚Ä¢	Outcome: Instead of an independent OHQ, the EU had to settle for a weaker command system, the EU Military Staff (EUMS), which still relies on NATO coordination.  3. EU Battle Groups (2005) ‚Äì Never Used Due to NATO Pressure 	‚Ä¢	What was it? The EU created rapid-response Battle Groups (each 1,500 troops), intended to intervene in global crises. 	‚Ä¢	US Reaction: The US and NATO-aligned EU states (Poland, the Baltics, and others) discouraged their deployment, arguing that crisis management should remain under NATO. 	‚Ä¢	Outcome: The Battle Groups were never deployed due to NATO‚Äôs influence and internal EU disagreements.  4. European Defence Initiative (2010) ‚Äì Blocked by NATO Countries 	‚Ä¢	What was it? A Franco-German push to expand EU defense capabilities. 	‚Ä¢	US Reaction: Washington, through NATO, discouraged deeper EU military integration, warning that it would ‚Äúweaken NATO cohesion.‚Äù 	‚Ä¢	Outcome: The initiative was watered down, and the EU continued to rely on NATO structures.  Key US Motives for Blocking EU Military Independence 	1.	Preserving NATO‚Äôs dominance ‚Äì The US views NATO as its primary tool to control European security policy. 	2.	Preventing EU strategic autonomy ‚Äì A strong EU military could reduce Europe‚Äôs reliance on US weapons and technology. 	3.	UK and Eastern Europe alignment with the US ‚Äì The UK (before Brexit) and countries like Poland opposed an EU army, supporting NATO instead.  Conclusion  While the EU has taken steps toward military cooperation, every serious attempt to create an independent European military structure in the 2000s faced US opposition. The US, often through NATO, successfully blocked or limited these initiatives to maintain transatlantic military influence.

¬†@JimiGosu¬† Europes dependency on USA weapons is largely shaped by NATO commitments, interoperability standards, and security guarantees rather than a lack of domestic manufacturing capability... Despite having five countries in the top 10 arms exporters, EU nations still prefer USA weapons due to strategic trust and logistical integration within NATO. However, if the USA were to reduce its commitment to Europe or impose conditions on arms sales, the EU would likely accelerate defense integration, filling the gaps with French, German, Italian, and UK-made weapons. Europe‚Äôs reliance on the USA is currently a strategic choice, not a weakness‚Äîbut that could change if circumstances force it. France (2nd after the USA) is a global arms powerhouse, but much of its exports go to the Middle East, India, and Southeast Asia..

That being said, the relationship between federal and state/provincial government is itself complicated. In Canada, Quebec actually holds veto power. Theres also the senate where representation is based on province. Supreme Court where representation is based on province. And a very clear distinction between federal government, and provincial government. The differences between federalism and regionalism are less distinct than a republic vs constitutional monarchy. ¬†@jhrusa8125¬† It is absurd to mix European public healthcare with US military spending. In the US, public spending on Medicaid (the public healthcare scheme for the poor) and Medicare (public healthcare scheme for the over 65s) corresponds to 16.5% of GDP, despite the fact that the majority of Americans are not entitled to it and must turn to private healthcare. In Italy, where I live, spending on public healthcare, which covers the entire population, corresponds to 8.4% of GDP. (OECD data 2022). This is because in the US there is absurd speculation on both public and private healthcare spending, which has nothing to do with military spending. If you think that investing less in military spending will improve your healthcare system, you are wrong. Too many people are getting rich off your health and your government will do nothing to stop this speculation. In Europe, even by increasing military spending, healthcare will remain public, simply because in Europe there is less speculation on healthcare which costs us much less than it does for you. You build around defence in depth, with unified pools of armaments set up. You need a limited mobile deployable force that can be rapidly mobilized to reinforce and provide counter attack capability - while relying on a populace that is trained in basic defensive standards and tactics to hold off the assault.   With proper use of terrain, area denial weapons, and so forth - you can pretty much guarantee a 1:1 or 2:1 advantage for the defender, when a reliable assault needs in the order a 3:1 advantage to consistently create results. Point 1 and 3, it's easier to create an armed forces model like that of the USA. So an army, navy, marine corps, air force, space force and coast guard for the problems south of europe..üòÖ copy/paste al those branches and chains of commands might be tricky on the short term, but way more effective in the long term.  Then, besides the EU armed forces, each country can have a national guard just like the USA.   A National Guard is not a separate branch of the U.S. Armed Forces but is a component of both the Army and the Air Force. It consists of:  Army National Guard ‚Äì A reserve force of the U.S. Army that can be activated for federal missions or state emergencies.  Air National Guard ‚Äì A reserve component of the U.S. Air Force responsible for air defense and support operations.  The National Guard operates under a dual state-federal mission:  State Control ‚Äì Under the command of state governors for disaster relief, civil unrest, and emergency response.  Federal Activation ‚Äì The President can federalize the National Guard for overseas deployments or national defense missions.  So while a National Guard will not be a part of the EU military, it is not considered a separate branch but rather a reserve force of the Army and Air Force.  This structure would mirror the U.S. Armed Forces while keeping national autonomy. The EU Armed Forces would be a global military power capable of handling high-intensity conflicts, peacekeeping, and homeland security, while each country maintains a National Guard for local emergencies.

Is it possible? Short answer: Yes. Long answer: Yes, and isn't even a big effort. The only thing we depend on the US for that would be somehow difficult to replace by national efforts are nuclear weapons, high-end missile defense assets and some support assets important to some countries.   The current permanent presence of US ground troops in Europe is minimal and it isn't a big deal if they go. Building up aviation assets to fully replace the US would be a bigger job, but compared to Russia we still outnumber Russia in our combined air combat potential by a wide margin.  As far as numbers of tanks go, playing with these figures here is a little misleading. First of all, tanks are not essential in preventing russian breaktroughs in the Baltic or anywhere else, they are essential in achieving breakthroughs in an offensive, a counter offensive for example. For that effect there is a huge build up of tanks in Poland, which can be joined by other armoured and mechanized forces by other central european countries for an offensive push to overrun russian forces in Kaliningrad and the Baltics. Germany is also deploying a brigade in Lithuania and the host country is itself acquiring a small amount of tanks.  On the Baltic-Nordic region Finland alone has more than 200 main battle tanks, Sweden more than a hundred and some 150 more to be delivered and Norway is due to have some 80 in total. Put together the Nordic front alone is due to have about more than 500 main battle tanks even though the terrain doesn't even favour heavy armour on this front.  We are not running short of mechanized forces very easily then. As for manpower, a couple hundred thousand Americans are not really that much scattered all over Europe, when the small country of Finland alone has a wartime military of 280 000. In my opinion this talk about American withdrawal is across the board paniced and irrational. We don't need an European army to somehow fix this, but the EU could in my opinion take a bigger role in organizing common efforts, harmonizing procurement and funding strategic weapons programs. Last but not least the nuclear non-proliferation question should be taken on the table and reconsidered in light of changing trans-atlantic relations.

A lot of the Russian figures are horribly inflated in reality. Vehicle production and equipment includes mostly old/repaired/salvaged (and reactivated) equipment, often obsolete in nature, and often at much greater cost than Russian leaders anticipated, with much less in reserve than anticipated. (stockpiles and mothballed equipment are stored improperly, falsely reported on, and often parted out and sold on the black market, so much of what they had on paper doesn't actually exist, hence why they're forced to dig into stocks of T-64s among other things and import cheap, less effective Chinese troop transports, etc) That's also ignoring how many figures are inflated on top of that, and how their economy is in crisis.  Their personnel losses are also massive and training and capability of their new troops is lacking, poor in quality, and anything but battle hardened. (if they didn't use tactics based on mass attrition, you might actually have battle hardened troops with improved experience and tactics improved from war-time experience, but the primary strategy is still just sending massive waves with high losses to gain relatively small portions of territory)  Ukraine, on the other hand, genuinely is battle hardened, and would indeed be an asset to the rest of Europe in a post-war scenario. It wouldn't take THAT much more European support to Ukraine to outright break Russia at this point, and would probably be cheaper (more cost effective in money and lives) to give more sooner than later, as the longer things drag out, the more Russia's limited capacity can continue to soldier on. (greater involvement back in 2022 easily could've done the same, and the reasons the US and Europe didn't do so is speculative, but on one end could include simply being cautious about escalation, while on the other could be pure greed and corruption in politics: ie a prolonged war benefits certain special interests in industry for profits and also benefits potential political manipulation for campaigning, legislation, etc, and producing propaganda to garner public support for said politics:   if you successfully end the war by investing more over a shorter period, you lose that potential and also knock Russia out of the picture as a realistic threat to security)  Nuclear weapons are always a concern, but not realistically as a response to any conventional warfare or economic pressure, it's just the same old concern for the MAD scenario and (to a vastly lesser, and even more unlikely case) potential use as scorched earth area denial when withdrawing from occupied territory or losing domestic territory. (Russia has proven unwilling to resort to any of that, and is already on the straits when it comes to popular support)   The biggest real-world risk would be missing this opportunity to properly break Russia (or at least Putin's Regime, or any expansionist style Regime ... opposed to say a return to form with a corrupt, but profitable business oriented, 1990s style Oligarch controlled regime). If another 2019 style ceasefire (or many prior agreements) is allowed to take place without treaties forming to properly, permanently secure the region in ways effectively impossible for subsequent governments (of all nations signing) to back out of or ignore if political winds change with subsequent administrations, then Russia will just start up its games again when it recovers.  If such a treaty can't be established with voluntary Russian withdrawl, then the best case would simply to be continuing the war until Russia actually collapses from lack of resources, economic stress, and internal conflict. ie if Putin/Russia is unwilling to make any sort of reasonable compromise that will actually ensure a lasting end to expansion along its Western borders, the best option is to properly support Ukraine's efforts while bolstering the entirety of Eastern Europe (aside of Russian puppet states), with sufficiently strong conventional military capability to prevent any possible incursions. (and make it very clear to Russia with proper posturing: the latter is what led Putin to invade Ukraine; he was convinced they were much weaker than they actually were and would be unable to obtain outside logistical support before capitulating, more like a large scale version of what happened in Crimea; he wouldn't have invaded had he grasped the reality of the situation in 2022)  Russia's current weakened state makes it the best opportunity to take action than has existed since Putin's expansion efforts originally started, or since he became President the first time around. (Russia was less dramatically posturing back then, and had a smaller sphere of influence, but also had a much larger stockpile of still viable Soviet-era equipment, things that have degraded dramatically in the following 20+ years through improper storage, lack of maintenance and corrupt black-market theft/sale of parts)  Plus, the results in Ukraine have ended a lot of the speculation of Russia's capabilities and technology, giving a more realistic picture of their readiness and real-world limitations. (where as, even at the beginning of 2022, it was much less clear how honest and accurate Russia's own claims of capabilities were)

North Korea calls itself the Democratic People‚Äôs Republic of Korea, yet it is neither democratic nor a republic. The ‚ÄúWorld Series‚Äù in American baseball does not mean the entire world participates. Words have meaning.  The most fundamental divide between the left and the right is their stance on equality. The right believes that some level of inequality is not only inevitable but beneficial to society. The left‚Äîsocialists included‚Äîargue the opposite. You can believe whichever you like; I don‚Äôt care. But let‚Äôs at least be honest about definitions.  Socialism, as opposed to capitalism, is based on the belief that society functions best when economic equality is increased and the working class has greater influence. Hitler did the exact opposite‚Äîhe banned unions, imprisoned socialists in concentration camps, and built an ideology entirely on the belief that human beings are not equal.  Yes, Hitler implemented state intervention in the economy‚Äîbut not to promote equality. He did so to prepare for war against those he deemed inferior. Calling that socialism is like calling North Korea a democracy‚Äîwrong, misleading, and intellectually lazy.

He also incorporated some left wing policies to appeal to the German working class. However, he did not believe in centrally owned means of production, which is the main goal of socialism. Also, as others pointed out, his belief that humans and races are fundamentally unequal too stands in complete contradiction with socialist beliefs, which endorsed internationalism. Lastly, Hitlers political platform during his rise to power was to a large degree based on opposing socialist movements in the Weimar Republic at the time.

‚Äã@StopThatUselessNoise oh jeez - Spengler's Prussian Socialism was a counter-concept to (supposedly foreign) socialism! "The working class must liberate itself from the illusions of Marxism." (Spengler) Therefore, one could argue that the term "socialism" is completely misplaced in Spengler's context, as he stands in direct opposition to its actual meaning. Instead, Spengler celebrated private property, competition, imperialism, capital accumulation, and "wealth, collected in few hands and among the ruling classes"‚Äîhe merely wanted all of this to be understood from a national perspective, which was ultimately meant to benefit the German worker. So if you want - an early form of nationalistic triple down theory.

¬†@Spritz86¬† "The NSDAP introduced a lot of social reforms in the 1930s BTW I am not even German, but at least I did my homework as a free man which is to question everything I have been taught." Well, you did your homework very very poorly, sorry. Labor law, social security, and welfare were expanded based on Bismarck's legislation during the Weimar Republic. The Nazis quickly adapted these programs to their social Darwinist ideas, denying benefits to those they considered "racially inferior" or disabled to maintain the "purity" of the "Aryan race." Work became a tool for fostering loyalty to the national community, with only those willing to work being recognized and temporarily supported.  After 1933, pensions were withdrawn from "enemies of the state" and reduced for Jews and "foreign races."  In short, these social programs were used to promote racist and social Darwinist ideals, contrasting with socialist principles.

@ " but it was a social-revolutionary worker party" No, no, no!! The revolution ideas of the Nazis were NOT a social-revolution. As Spengler (a theorist of the Prussian "socialism") noted: English society is founded on the distinction between rich and poor, Prussian society on the distinction between command and obedience. In other words - the social part was a foreign idea. The German idea of socialism was one, that anyone in his position in the hierachy (remember - its Prussia) should work for the best of the nation, so everyone will profit of it - also the workers. A early form of the tripple down theory, so to speak. So right from the beginning, the Nazis cut social welfare programs to people they claimed were not useful for the health nation: Sick, elderly and of course, people of other races.

@ ""Hitler was not Marxist therefore he must've been Wall Street Rockfeller free market capitalist totally!"" The Prussian ideal of socialism was completely capitalistic. Check Spengler, the Prussian theorist of socialism in Germany:  Spengler strongly opposed labor strikes (he describes them as "the unsocialistic earmark of Marxism"), trade unions, progressive taxation or any imposition of taxes on the rich, any shortening of the working day, as well as any form of government insurance for sickness, old age, accidents, or unemployment. At the same time as he rejected any social democratic provisions, Spengler celebrated private property, competition, imperialism, capital accumulation, and "wealth, collected in few hands and among the ruling classes He argued against the imposition of progressive taxation on the rich ("dry Bolshevism"), any shortening of the working day (he argues that workers should work even on Sundays), as well as any form of government insurance for sickness, old age, accidents, or unemployment.

Nazi ideology was in principle unfavourable to the idea of social welfare.[2] Writing in Mein Kampf about his time spent among the poor in Vienna, Hitler expressed indignation against social welfare for helping the degenerate and the feeble.[3] The Nazis believed that the German race had to be strengthened through a process of natural selection, which required weeding out its weakest elements, so they condemned the goals of charity and philanthropy.[3] They opposed the extensive welfare system of the Weimar Republic for being wasteful, bureaucratic, and helping the wrong people, since it distributed welfare benefits indiscriminately without regard for race and often assisted people that the Nazis considered inferior.[3]

¬†@johnw574¬† Not sure to which commenter you respond. In any case, I have studied the history of my country for a long time. And I can assure you, Hitler was not a socialist. Again, Hitler was not a socialist. In fact, the socialists, were one of the first people who were imprisoned and killed in 1933 in the concentration camps as Hitler considered them (together with the communists and social democrats) his greatest political enemies.
Hitler was mainly a racist and a nationalist. The socialist part was adopted by him to steal votes from the communist party, which was the biggest threat to the NSDAP at this time. This wasn't his primary ideology, rather it was used for pragmatic reasons. Not allowing personal freedom and organizing society in a socialistic manner also greatly supported his goal to gain ultimate power and to fulfill his plans for war and genocide. However, other protagonists, like for example Goebbels, primarily followed a socialistic ideology and only later became nationalists because of Hitler. So although the NSDAP definitely was a socialist party combining aspects of right- as well as left-extreme ideology, Hitler was not primarily a socialist, this is just wrong.

This depends on how one defines socialism. If you look at socialism in abstract terms you can define it as the idea of bringing some form of social justice. In this case, marxism, communism/collectivism, nazism represent the means to achieve this goal and also make it more specific (or less abstract). In this case, one can could argue that he was a socialist (because of his ideas of what social justice is and how it should be achieved). Speaking outside of abstract terms: No, of course Hitler was not a socialist. Any politician who tells you otherwise aims to manipulate you. Any politician who offers simple solutions to complicated problems also wants to manipulate you. This is a very dangerous path, and you don't want to end up where it leads. Populists don't solve problems; they deceive you to gain or maintain power for as long as they can. Ultimately, this ignorance will trigger a powerful social explosion that will hurt everyone severely. I truly hope we can avoid this outcome.

¬†@stuckonautomatic¬† But what does it mean to be a ‚Äúnationalist‚Äù ‚Ä¶ And why does it have a negative connotation ?  A nation is a group of people who agree to work together, share recourses, abide to a set of (agreed upon) laws ‚Ä¶ This ‚Äúnation‚Äù (= collaboration) has to be defined/protected by ‚Äúborders‚Äù ‚Ä¶ If a nation has no borders, or weak borders, people cannot share resources (or won‚Äôt be willing to share resources), there cannot be a welfare state without borders. Without strong borders it will be difficult to enforce the law (since there will be people in your nation that didn‚Äôt agree to follow the rules). So someone please explain me why ‚Äúnationalism‚Äù is a bad thing. Also please explain me why trying to enforce borders (or limit access to a nation/social security) makes a party ‚Äúracist‚Äù ‚Ä¶ As I said without protecting access to the ‚Äúsystem‚Äù (the nation) ‚Ä¶ there will be no ‚Äúcollaboration‚Äù ‚Ä¶ and the system will collapse

Well it depends on which of the different definition of socialism is being referred to. A positive definition would be a system which is concerned about justice, fairness and solidarity. I would call that a social democracy. But socialism in Germany is better know as a totalitarian regime, which controls (not owns, that would be communism) the production centers and most of the social life as well. Opponents are often persecuted and killed. Typically a certain group of people formerly said to be victims of higher powers e.g. working class vs. industrialist/entrepeneurs. The Nazis (National socialist) focused on the german lower and middle class as being the alleged victims of foreign and jewish powers. So the way they operated the state was a socialist regime according to that definition but instead of favoring a specific social class they favored a nationality. So in the end it depends on the definition of socialism that is being used. From my point of view socialism and communism are words that stand for totalitarian regimes with 100 Millionen of victims worldwide. So calling Hitler a socialist certainly is not a praise.

¬†@nexusxmoon¬† No, socialism and fascism are fundamentally incompatible because they are completely opposing ideologies  Socialism aims for social equality, collective control over production, and a fair distribution of resources . Fascism is based on authority, nationalism, hierarchy, and the suppression of minorities and opposition groups.  Fascists only care about themselves or the group they belong to usually the rich and powerful which often go hand in hand. Their wealth and power (has to) grow through exploitation and suffering of others. They have no "socialist" interest in improving life for ‚Äúthe common people‚Äù. To them, workers are just cheap and replaceable. The real divide isn‚Äôt between left and right, but between those at the top and those at the bottom.   In practice, some regimes have combined socialist rhetoric with fascist methods, using state control alongside oppression. But that doesn‚Äôt mean socialism and fascism truly coexist, socialist language is often just used to justify an authoritarian rule.

Yes, Hitler was a National Socialist. He led the Nazi Party, which believed in strong nationalism (pride in the country), extreme control by the government, and racist ideas, especially against Jewish people. They wanted a powerful, authoritarian leader and rejected ideas like democracy and communism. Hitler and the Nazi Party used the word "socialist" in their name, but their version of socialism was very different from traditional socialism. In classic socialism, the focus is on equality and workers controlling the means of production. The Nazis, however, didn't support those ideas. Instead, they focused on the idea of a strong, centralized state, but with private businesses still in control, as long as they supported the regime.  The term "socialist" in Nazi ideology was mostly used for propaganda purposes to appeal to working-class people. It was meant to create a sense of unity and national pride, but it wasn't about true socialism as we understand it today.

Yes these words have meaning. No they don't mean he wasn't a crazy dictator involved and leading the killing of millions. But just getting angry because you get some words into the wrong pipe is really just a you-problem so you should calm down...

¬†@chrismath149¬† seriously,  YOU have an absurd simplified understanding of economics (and politics)  Both in Italy and Germany, fascists fueled the fears of the middle and upper classes regarding socialist movements that threatened to challenge the existing property and power structures. German industrialists were skeptical of the Weimar Republic because they rejected its welfare measures and the influence of the SPD, just as they opposed the introduction of compulsory arbitration in labor disputes between workers and employers.  The economic interventions after the seizure of power initially consisted only of subsidy programs comparable to the "New Deal" in America. While industrialists were politically aligned with nationalist policies, they were granted economic freedom. This is also evident in the fact that the adoption of the F√ºhrer principle by large industries did not weaken their autonomy; on the contrary, it contributed to their strengthening, as industrial interest groups were now optimally coordinated and could present a united front externally. At no point was there a planned economy!  Only later‚Äîactually too late for the course of the war‚Äîwhen the economy had to be converted to a war economy, did direct control take place.  The totalitarianism theroem in economy as described i.e. by Stolper or Lochner, represents an often debunked minority opinion!

Mmmmh, if we don't have it, we'll make it.  "Rindfleischetikettierungs√ºberwachungsaufgaben√ºbertragungsgesetz"  Yes, its's real. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rinderkennzeichnungs-_und_Rindfleischetikettierungs%C3%BCberwachungsaufgaben%C3%BCbertragungsgesetz
We do our best :)  The "modular-wording" is a system of endless possibilities :) Even without a dictionary we can create new valid word combinations for every unthinkable stuff which is upcoming.
We have a unique way of combining words, allowing for an unlimited number of possible word formations. In these compound words, each intermediate word retains its grammatical case, which can be further specified using prepositions and other modifiers.
¬†@xDevoneyx¬† It's not just about spacing‚Äîcompound words in languages like German follow specific grammatical rules, including case retention and linking elements, which English doesn‚Äôt use. Simply removing spaces in English wouldn‚Äôt create the same kind of words because English forms phrases differently, often relying on prepositions instead. The structure of a language determines how words combine, not just whether there are spaces between them. German allows for more precise and efficient word formation because it can create complex compound words while preserving grammatical relationships, something English often requires entire phrases to express. In that way german is "easyer" to use.

¬†@PersonaPariah¬†Because it is right wing. Not ideologically - identity politics is very much a left wing thing in Europe too - but economically. The democrats in the US are essentially just a regular market liberal party. Their closest equal would be the FDP (liberal democratic party) in Germany. Which on an economical spectrum is an economically right wing liberal party and only overtaken by libertarian parties like the AfD on that front. The CDU - the conservatives - would be something between the democrats and republicans. They are ideologically more right wing but not as crazy as Republicans (generally the CDU and the Republicans since Trump stopped having much in common with each other). And their market policy is similar to the FDP. That‚Äòs why those two usually see each other as perfect coalition partners.  Meanwhile SPD is the first actual left wing party in Germany. Although the SPD too has dabbled in Neoliberal policies (which is probably the political core ideology for democrats) they are at heart an ordo-liberal party. Which means   that production shall be regulated by the market but the state intervenes to regulate the market to promote welfare. Then there are left wing parties that actually want to restructure the economy into either a socialized economy (socialism) which would transfer the ownership of companies to workers or the society. (There are many concepts for this.) They often still follow a market economy to a certain degree but that is essentially what is meant when you hear that ‚Äùseize the means of production‚Äú catchphrase. Lastly there are small, mostly irrelevant fringe parties like the MLPD who - if I‚Äòm not mistaken as I never really looked them up - intend to implement a planned economy again such as the GDR had it which would be more in line with actual communism. I think most Americans could stand to learn quite a lot from studying other political landscapes. It would help dissolve this stupid notion of communism being any policy of redistribution, building security networks or accessible welfare services. Communism and socialism are ways of structuring the economy and especially the ownership of the economy. Welfare is not a concept owned by communists or socialists.
¬†@aaronbulmahn7715¬† All that yapping just to prove my point then turn around and try and pedal your Davos WEF crap. Nah hard pass
The reason this happened was because a prominent candidate for European Parliament (Maximillian Krah, AfD) had made a statement, in a podcast concerning the question of whether all members of the paramilitary SS can be considered criminals (Verbrecher), within the context that many were forcibly conscripted or had been in banal positions, he made a, admittedly somewhat poorly worded, claim that one couldn't assign a blanket accusation of criminality to everyone who had been in the SS. This was then ripped out of context in international media, where it was claimed that Krah believed the SS was guilt free, and relativizing the crimes of the SS. The French RN under LePen, which has a strong stance on the historical role of Germany during the 2nd World War then made the decision to exclude the AfD.

That statement is incorrect. Even the BBC noted that Angela Merkel's speech as the leader of the CDU was perceived as strange by us Democrats because it seemed biased toward the left. In her remarks, Merkel discussed the state of Western democracy, addressing various internal debates in Germany and highlighting the threats facing democracy. However, German media characterized it as a conservative speech, which was misleading.  In general, the US Democrats would be positioned far to the right of the CDU, with the exception of societal politics.
